revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox philosopher | name = Abu al-ʿAlaʾ al-Maʿarri | image = Al-Maʿarri bust2.jpg | alt = | caption = | other_names = | birth_name = | birth_date = December 973 | birth_place = [[Maarrat al-Nu'man]], [[Hamdanid]] [[Emirate of Aleppo]] | death_date = May 1057 (aged 83) | death_place = Maarrat al-Nu'man, [[Mirdasid]] Emirate of Aleppo | death_cause = | residence = | region = [[Islamic philosophy]] | era = [[Medieval era]] ([[Islamic Golden Age]]) | school_tradition = [[Islamic philosophy]] | main_interests = [[Poetry]], [[Philosophical skepticism|skepticism]], [[rationalism]], [[ethics]], [[pessimism]] | books = | notable_ideas = | institutions = | influences = [[al-Mutannabi]], [[Abu Tammam]] | influenced = [[Taha Hussein]], [[Turan Dursun]] | signature = | signature_alt = }}
'''Abu al-ʿAlaʾ al-Maʿarri''' ([[Arabic]] {{rtl-lang|ar| أبو العلاء المعري}} ''{{transl|ar|Abū al-ʿAlāʾ al-Maʿarrī}}'', full name {{rtl-lang|ar|أبو العلاء أحمد بن عبد الله بن سليمان التنوخي المعري}} ''{{transl|ar|Abū al-ʿAlāʾ Aḥmad ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn Sulaimān al-Tanūẖī al-Maʿarrī}}''; December 973 – May 1057)<ref name="EB">{{Cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/al-Maarri|title=al-Ma'arri {{!}} Biography {{!}} Britannica.com|website=[[Encyclopædia Britannica Online]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221090622/https://www.britannica.com/biography/al-Maarri|archive-date=21 February 2018|dead-url=no|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> was a blind Arab [[philosopher]], [[poet]], and [[writer]]. Al-Maʿarri held and expressed an [[irreligious]] [[worldview]] which was met with controversy, but in spite of it, he is regarded as one of the greatest [[Arabic poetry|classical Arabic poets]].
Born in the city of [[Maarrat al-Nu'man|Maʿarra]] during the [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid era]], he studied in nearby [[Aleppo]], then in [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]] and [[Antioch]]. Producing popular poems in [[Baghdad]], he nevertheless refused to sell his texts. In 1010, he returned to Syria after his mother began declining in health, and continued writing which gained him local respect.
Described as a "[[Pessimism#Philosophical pessimism|pessimistic]] [[freethinker]]", Al-Maʿarri was a controversial [[rationalist]] of his time, citing [[reason]] as the chief source of [[truth]]. He was pessimistic about life, describing himself as "a double prisoner" of [[blindness]] and [[Social isolation|isolation]]. He [[Criticism of religion|attacked the dogmas of religion]], [[Criticism of Islam|criticized]] and [[Apostasy in Islam|rejected Islam]]{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}}, and became a [[Deism|Deist]]. He was equally critical and sarcastic about [[Criticism of Judaism|Judaism]], [[Criticism of Christianity|Christianity]], and [[Zoroastrianism]]. He advocated [[social justice]] and lived a [[Recluse|secluded]], [[ascetic]] lifestyle. He became a [[vegan]], entreating: "do not desire as food the flesh of slaughtered animals / Or the white milk of mothers who intended its pure draught / for their young".<ref>[http://www.humanistictexts.org/al_ma'arri.htm "I No Longer Steal from Nature"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127200338/http://www.humanistictexts.org/al_ma'arri.htm |date=2016-11-27 }}</ref> Al-Maʿarri held an [[Antinatalism|antinatalist thought]], in line with his general pessimism, suggesting that children should not be born to spare them of the pains and [[suffering]] of life.<ref name="EB" />
Al-Maʿarri wrote three main works that were popular in his time. Among his works are ''The Tinder Spark'', ''Unnecessary Necessity'', and ''The Epistle of Forgiveness'' (''[[Resalat Al-Ghufran]]'') which may be considered a precursor to [[Dante Alighieri|Dante]]'s ''[[Divine Comedy]]''. Al-Maʿarri never married and died at the age of 83 in the city where he was born, Maarrat al-Nuʿman. In 2013, a statue of al-Maʿarri located in his Syrian home town was beheaded by jihadists from the [[al-Nusra Front]].<ref name=statue />
==Life== Abu al-ʿAlaʾ was born in [[Maʿarra]], modern [[Maarrat al-Nu'man]], Syria, near the city of [[Aleppo]], in December 973. At his time, the city was part of the [[Abbasid Caliphate]], the third Islamic caliphate, during the [[Islamic Golden Age|Golden Age of Islam]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Al-Ma'arri – Visionary Free Thinker, The Genius of Disability, The Essay |website=BBC Radio 3|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b04wmklk|accessdate = 2015-07-13}}</ref> He was a member of the ''Banu Sulayman'', a notable family of Maʿarra, belonging to the larger [[Tanukhids|Tanukh tribe]].<ref name="EB" /><ref>1940 {{rtl-lang|ar|أبو العلاء المعري: نسبه وأخباره وشعره ومعتقده، تأليف أحمد تيمور باشا، ص.3، ط}}</ref><ref> Miguel Asín Palacios, ''Islam and the Divine comedy'', Routledge, 1968, {{ISBN|978-0-7146-1995-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=hbHv0Hi-VbsC&pg=PA55&dq=al+maarri p. 55]</ref> One of his ancestors was probably the first [[qadi]] of Maʿarra. The Tanukh tribe had formed part of the aristocracy in Syria for hundreds of years and some members of the ''Banu Sulayman'' had also been noted as good poets.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = The 11th Century poet who pissed off al-Qaeda {{!}} All About History|url = http://www.historyanswers.co.uk/medieval-renaissance/al-maarri-the-11th-century-poet-that-pissed-off-al-qaeda/|website = historyanswers.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-07-13}}</ref>
He lost his eyesight at the age of four due to [[smallpox]]. His later pessimism may be explained by his virtual blindness. Later in his life, he regarded himself as "a double prisoner" which referred to both this blindness and the general isolation that he felt during his life.<ref name=":2">Philip Khuri Hitti, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=6FklfLSxpIkC&pg=PA147&dq=al+ma%27arri#v=onepage&q=al%20ma'arri&f=false Islam, a Way of Life]'', page 147. University of Minnesota Press</ref>
He started his career as a poet at an early age, at about 11 or 12 years old. He was educated at first in Maʿarra and Aleppo, later also in Antioch and other Syrian cities. Among his teachers in Aleppo were companions from the circle of [[Ibn Khalawayh]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> This grammarian and Islamic scholar had died in 980 CE, when al-Maʿarri was still a child.<ref name="al-Maarri">{{Cite book|title = Epistle of Forgiveness: Hypocrites, Heretics, and Other Sinners|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iiegAgAAQBAJ&pg=PR11&dq=epistle+of+forgiveness|publisher = NYU Press|date = 2014-01-01|isbn = 9780814768969|first = Abu l-Ala|last = al-Maarri}}</ref> Al-Maʿarri nevertheless laments the loss of Ibn Khalawayh in strong terms in a poem of his ''[[Resalat Al-Ghufran|Risālat al-ghufrān]]''.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title = The Encyclopaedia of Islam|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_JY3AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA932&dq=al-ma+arri+biography|publisher = Brill Archive|date = 1954-01-01|first = Sir Hamilton Alexander Rosskeen|last = Gibb}}</ref> [[Al-Qifti]] reports that when on his way to [[Tripoli]], al-Maʿarri visited a Christian monastery near [[Latakia]] where he listened to debates about [[Hellenistic philosophy]], which planted in him the seeds of his later scepticism and irreligiosity; but other historians such as [[Ibn al-Adim]] deny that he had been exposed to any theology other than Islamic doctrine.<ref name=":6" />
In 1004–05 al-Maʿarri learned that his father had died and, in reaction, wrote an [[elegy]] where he praised his father.<ref name=":6" /> Years later he would travel to [[Baghdad]] where he became well received in the literary salons of the time, though he was a controversial figure.<ref name=":6" /> After the eighteen months in Baghdad, al-Maʿarri returned home for unknown reasons. He may have returned because his mother was ill, or he may have run out of money in Baghdad, as he refused to sell his works.<ref name="EB" /> He returned to his native town of Maʿarra in about 1010 and learned that his mother had died before his arrival.<ref name=":0" />
He remained in Maʿarra for the rest of his life, where he opted for an ascetic lifestyle, refusing to sell his poems, living in seclusion and observing a strict [[Vegetarianism|vegetarian diet]].<ref>[[David Samuel Margoliouth|D. S. Margoliouth]], [https://archive.org/stream/journalroyalasi69irelgoog#page/n323/mode/1up Abu 'l-ʿAla al-Maʿarri's correspondence on vegetarianism], ''[[Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society]]'', 1902, p. 289.</ref> His personal confinement to his house was only broken one time when violence had struck his town.<ref name=":6" /> Though he was confined, he lived out his later years continuing his work and collaborating with others.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Abu-L-Ala al-Maarri Facts|url = http://biography.yourdictionary.com/abu-l-ala-al-maarri|website = biography.yourdictionary.com|accessdate = 2015-07-13}}</ref> He enjoyed great respect and attracted many students locally, as well as actively holding correspondence with scholars abroad.<ref name="EB"/> Despite his intentions of living a secluded lifestyle, in his seventies, he became rich and was the most revered person in his area.<ref name=":0" /> Al-Maʿarri never married and died in May 1057 in his home town.<ref name="EB" /><ref name=":2" />
==Philosophy==
===Opposition to religion=== Al-Maʿarri was a [[philosophical skepticism|sceptic]] in his beliefs<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-35745962|title = Museum of Lost Objects: The unacceptable poet - BBC News|website = BBC News|language = en-GB|access-date = 2016-03-09}}</ref> who denounced superstition and dogmatism in religion. This, along with his general negative view on life, has made him described as a [[pessimism|pessimistic]] [[Freethought|freethinker]]. One of the recurring themes of his philosophy was the right of [[reason]] against the claims of custom, tradition, and authority.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title = Al Ma'arri|url = http://www.humanistictexts.org/al_ma'arri.htm|website = humanistictexts.org|accessdate = 2015-07-13|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161127200338/http://www.humanistictexts.org/al_ma'arri.htm|archivedate = 2016-11-27|df = }}</ref> Al-Maʿarri taught that religion was a "fable invented by the ancients", worthless except for those who exploit the credulous masses.<ref name="Nicholson318">Reynold Alleyne Nicholson, 1962, ''A Literary History of the Arabs'', page 318. Routledge</ref>
{{quote|Do not suppose the statements of the prophets to be true; they are all fabrications. Men lived comfortably till they came and spoiled life. The sacred books are only such a set of idle tales as any age could have and indeed did actually produce.<ref>James Hastings, ''Encyclopedia of Religion and Ethics, Part 2'', page 190. Kessinger Publishing.</ref>}}
Al-Maʿarri criticized many of the dogmas of [[Islam]], such as the [[Hajj]], which he called "a pagan's journey".<ref name="Nicholson319">Nicholson, ''A Literary History of the Arabs'', 319.</ref> He rejected claims of any [[divine revelation]] and his creed was that of a philosopher and ascetic, for whom [[reason]] provides a moral guide, and [[virtue]] is its own reward.<ref name="Nicholson317">Nicholson, ''A Literary History of the Arabs'', 317.</ref><ref name="Nicholson323">Nicholson, ''A Literary History of the Arabs'', 323.</ref>
His [[religious skepticism|religious scepticism]] and positively [[antireligious]] views extended beyond Islam and included both [[Judaism]] and [[Christianity]], as well. Al-Maʿarri remarked that [[monk]]s in their [[cloister]]s or devotees in their mosques were blindly following the beliefs of their locality: if they were born among [[Magi]]ans or [[Sabians]] they would have become Magians or Sabians.<ref>Reynold A. Nicholson ''Adapted from Studies in Islamic Poetry'' Cambridge University Press, 1921, Cambridge, England. pp. 1–32</ref> Encapsulating his view on organized religion, he once stated: "The inhabitants of the earth are of two sorts: those with brains, but no religion, and those with religion, but no brains."<ref>Cyril Glasse, (2001), ''The New Encyclopedia of Islam'', p. 278. Rowman Altamira.</ref>
===Asceticism and veganism=== Al-Maʿarri was an ascetic, renouncing worldly desires and living secluded from others while producing his works. He opposed all forms of violence.<ref name=":0" /> In Baghdad, while being well received, he decided not to sell his texts, which made it difficult for him to live.<ref name="EB" /> This ascetic lifestyle has been compared to similar thought in [[India]] during his time.<ref name=":3" />
In al-Maʿarri's later years, he became a [[vegan]], neither consuming meat nor any other animal products. He wrote: {{poemquote|Do not unjustly eat fish the water has given up, And do not desire as food the flesh of slaughtered animals, Or the white milk of mothers who intended its pure draught for their young, not noble ladies. And do not grieve the unsuspecting birds by taking eggs; for injustice is the worst of crimes. And spare the honey which the bees get industriously from the flowers of fragrant plants; For they did not store it that it might belong to others, Nor did they gather it for bounty and gifts. I washed my hands of all this; and wish that I Perceived my way before my hair went gray!<ref name=":4" />}}
=== Antinatalism === Al-Maʿarri's fundamental [[pessimism]] is expressed in his antinatalist recommendation that no children should be begotten, so as to spare them the pains of life.<ref name="statue">{{Cite web|title = Syrian rebels have taken iconoclasm to new depths, with shrines, statues and even a tree destroyed – but to what end?|url = https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/syrian-rebels-have-taken-iconoclasm-to-new-depths-with-shrines-statues-and-even-a-tree-destroyed--but-to-what-end-9021017.html|accessdate = 2015-07-13}}</ref> In an [[elegy]] composed by him over the loss of a relative, he combines his grief with observations on the ephemerality of this life: {{poemquote|Soften your tread. Methinks the earth's surface is but bodies of the dead, Walk slowly in the air, so you do not trample on the remains of God's servants.<ref name="EB" />}} Even on al-Maʿarri's [[epitaph]], he wanted it written that his life was a wrong done by his father and not one that was done by himself.<ref name=":0" />
==Modern views== Al-Maʿarri is controversial even today as he was sceptical of Islam, the dominant religion of the [[Arab world]].<ref name=":3" /> In 2013, almost a thousand years after his death, the [[al-Nusra Front]], a branch of [[al-Qaeda]], beheaded a statue of al-Maʿarri during the [[Syrian civil war]].<ref name=":5" /> The statue had been crafted by the sculptor Fathi Muhammad.<ref name=":1" /> The motive behind the beheading is disputed; theories range from the fact that he was a heretic to the fact that he is believed by some to be related to the [[Assad family]].<ref name=":5">[[France24]], "[http://observers.france24.com/content/20130214-jihadists-behead-statue-syrian-poet-abul-ala-al-maari Jihadists behead statue of Syrian poet Abul Ala al-Maari]", 14 February 2013</ref>
Still, al-Maʿarri is sometimes referred to as one of the greatest classical Arab poets. Some have drawn connections between him and the Roman poet [[Lucretius]], calling them progressive for their time.<ref name=":1" />
== Works == {{listen |filename=Poem by Abu 'ala al-Ma'arri ("I no longer steal from nature") read in Arabic.ogg|title=Poem from Luzūmīyāt, read in Arabic|description=The restrictive rhyme and meter can be heard in the start of poem 197<ref>[[Reynold Nicholson]], [https://archive.org/stream/studiesinislamic00nichuoft#page/134/mode/2up Studies in Islamic Poetry and Mysticism], 1921, p. 134.</ref>}}
An early [[Diwan (poetry)|collection]] of his poems appeared as ''The Tinder Spark'' (''Saqṭ al-zand''; {{rtl-lang|ar|سقط الزند}}). The collection of poems included praise of notable people of Aleppo and the [[Hamdanid dynasty|Hamdanid]] ruler [[Sa'd al-Dawla]]. It gained great popularity and established his reputation as a poet. A few poems in the collection were about armour.<ref name="EB" />
A second, more original collection appeared under the title ''Unnecessary Necessity'' (''Luzūm mā lam yalzam'' {{rtl-lang|ar| لزوم ما لا يلزم أو اللزوميات }}), also simply ''Luzūmīyāt'' or ''Necessities''. The title refers to how al-Maʿarri saw the business of living and alludes to the unnecessary complexity of the rhyme scheme used.<ref name="EB" />
His third famous work is a work of prose known as ''The Epistle of Forgiveness'' (''[[Resalat Al-Ghufran]]'' {{rtl-lang|ar|رسالة الغفران}}). The work was written as a direct response to the Arabic poet Ibn al-Qarih, whom al-Maʿarri mocks for his religious views.<ref name="al-Maarri"/><ref>{{Cite book|title = The Epistle of Forgiveness: Volume Two: Hypocrites, Heretics, and Other Sinners|url = https://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780814768969|publisher = NYU Press|date = 2014|location = New York|isbn = 9780814768969|first = Abu l-Ala|last = al-Maarri|first2 = Geert Jan Van|last2 = Gelder|first3 = Gregor|last3 = Schoeler}}</ref> In this work, the poet visits [[Jannah|paradise]] and meets the [[Arabic poetry|Arab poets]] of the [[Jahiliyyah|pagan period]], contrary to Muslim doctrine which holds that only those who believe in God can find [[Salvation#Islam|salvation]]. Because of the aspect of [[Bangsian fantasy|conversing with the deceased]] in paradise, the ''Resalat Al-Ghufran'' has been compared to the ''[[Divine Comedy]]'' of Dante<ref>William Montgomery Watt and Pierre Cachia, ''A History of Islamic Spain'', 2nd edition, Edinburgh University Press, 1996, pp. 125–126, {{ISBN|0-7486-0847-8}}.</ref> which came hundreds of years after. The work has also been noted to be similar to Ibn Shuhayd's ''Risala al-tawabi' wa al-zawabi'', though there is no evidence that al-Maʿarri was inspired by Ibn Shahayd nor is there any evidence that Dante was inspired by al-Maʿarri.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Biographical Encyclopedia of Islamic Philosophy|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iX-8BwAAQBAJ&pg=PT364&lpg=PT364&dq=al+qifti+al-ma+arri|publisher = Bloomsbury Publishing|date = 2015-07-16|isbn = 9781472569462|first = Oliver|last = Leaman}}</ref> [[Algeria]] reportedly banned ''The Epistle of Forgiveness'' from the International Book Fair held in [[Algiers]] in 2007.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5" />
''Paragraphs and Periods'' (''Al-Fuṣūl wa al-ghāyāt'') is a collection of homilies. The work has also been called a [[parody]] of the [[Quran]].<ref name="EB" />
<gallery> File:Saqt al-Zand.jpg|''Saqt al-Zand'' File:Risalat al-Gufran.jpg|''Risalat al-Gufran'' </gallery>
==Editions== * ''Risalat ul Ghufran, a Divine Comedy.'' Translated by G. Brackenbury 1943. * ''The Epistle of Forgiveness: Volume One: A Vision of Heaven and Hell.'' Translated by Geert Jan Van Gelder and Gregor Schoeler. Library of Arabic Literature, New York University Press 2013. * ''The Epistle of Forgiveness: Volume Two: Hypocrites, Heretics, and Other Sinners.'' Translated by Geert Jan Van Gelder and Gregor Schoeler. Library of Arabic Literature, New York University Press 2014.

Smith | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Barbara Elaine Smith | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|8|24|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = John Robert Powers Modeling School | spouse = Donald Anderson (1986-1992)
Dan Gasby (1992-present) | style = Global eclectic with Southern influences | ratings = | restaurants = | prevrests = | television = | awards = | website = {{URL|www.bsmith.com}} | module = }} '''Barbara Elaine Smith'''{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS; Barbara Smith and Dan Gasby|quote=Barbara Elaine Smith, the owner of B. Smith's Restaurant in New York, was married on Wednesday to Clarence Alvin Daniel Gasby, the senior vice president of marketing at Camelot Entertainment Sales, Inc., a syndicator of television programs in New York.|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 27, 1992|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/27/style/weddings-barbara-smith-and-dan-gasby.html|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} (born August 24, 1949), known as '''B. Smith''', is an American [[restaurateur]], model, author, and television host.{{cite news|url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00C13F8355D0C718EDDA10894D1494D81|title=Can B. Smith Be Martha?|last=Reed|first=Julia|date=22 August 1999|work=The New York Times|accessdate=30 March 2011}}{{cite book|last=Penrice|first=Ronda Racha|title=African American History for Dummies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c56EwwYBG1EC&pg=PA223|accessdate=March 30, 2011|year=2007|publisher=For Dummies|isbn=978-0-7645-5469-8|page=223}} ==Early life and education== Smith was raised in [[Scottdale, Pennsylvania]] and attended [[Southmoreland High School]].{{cite news|author=Rebecca Sodergren|title=B. Smith's career takes another turn -- cookbook author|quote=Growing up in Scottdale, Westmoreland County, B. Smith was denied membership in the Future Homemakers of America.|newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|date=February 4, 2010|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/life/food/2010/02/04/B-Smith-s-career-takes-another-turn-cookbook-author/stories/201002040433|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} Her mother Florence was a maid and her father William a steelworker.{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS; Barbara Smith and Dan Gasby|newspaper =The New York Times|date=December 27, 1992|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/27/style/weddings-barbara-smith-and-dan-gasby.html|accessdate=November 26, 2014}}{{cite news|author=Julia Reed|title=All She Can B.|quote=Like Smith's, his mother was a maid, but his father was a bookie.|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] via [[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=November 5, 1999|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1999-11-05/lifestyle/9911040572_1_dan-gasby-martha-stewart-smith-and-gasby/2|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} ==Career== ===Model=== Smith was the second black model to be on the cover of ''[[Mademoiselle (magazine)|Mademoiselle]]'' magazine in 1976, after Joli Jones was in 1969.{{cite news|author=[[Farai Chideya]]|title=B. Smith Becomes Face of Betty Crocker Cornbread|newspaper=NPR|date=January 2, 2007|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6709989|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} ===Restaurateur=== Smith owned multiple restaurants, called B. Smith; the first opened in 1986, on [[Restaurant Row (Manhattan)]] and in [[Sag Harbor, New York|Sag Harbor, Long Island, New York]]. She also owned a restaurant in the historic Beaux-Arts [[Union Station (Washington)|Union Station]] in Washington, D.C.; in September 2013, it was reported that restaurant would close.{{cite news|author=Jonathan O'Connell|title=B. Smith’s restaurant in Union Station to close after almost 20 years in business|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=September 13, 2013|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/b-smiths-restaurant-in-union-station-to-close-after-almost-20-years-in-business/2013/09/13/f1fc4c1e-1c91-11e3-82ef-a059e54c49d0_story.html|accessdate =November 26, 2014}} In 2014, the Sag Harbor restaurant was shuttered, followed by the Manhattan location in January, 2015.{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Stephanie|last2=Mohr|first2=Ian|title=B. Smith's last remaining restaurant closes its doors|url=http://pagesix.com/2015/01/19/the-last-b-smith-manhattan-restaurant-closes-its-doors/|accessdate=22 May 2016|work=Page Six|publisher=New York Post|date=19 January 2015}} ===Retailer=== Smith’s interest in [[décor]] and restaurant design led to the development of her first home collection, which debuted at [[Bed Bath & Beyond]] in Spring 2001.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/16/fashion/b-smith-a-renaissance-woman-returns-to-the-stage-up-close.html?ref=fashion|work=The New York Times|first=Lola|last=Ogunnaike|title=B. Smith, a Renaissance Woman, Returns to the Stage: Up Close|date=June 15, 2011}} She also launched a line of serveware in 2004. In Spring 2007, Smith debuted her first furniture collection with the [[La-Z-Boy]] company Clayton Marcus.{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Gary|title=B. Smith picks fabrics for new Clayton Marcus line|url=http://www.furnituretoday.com/article/447480-b-smith-picks-fabrics-for-new-clayton-marcus-line|publisher=Furniture Today|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=25 December 2006}} ===Stage acting=== Smith accepted a role in the [[Off Broadway]] play ''[[Love, Loss, and What I Wore]]'' for an April 27 through May 29, 2011 run with [[Conchata Ferrell]], [[AnnaLynne McCord]], [[Anne Meara]], and [[Minka Kelly]].{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/149900-Minka-Kelly-Susan-Sullivan-Set-for-Love-Loss-Off-Broadway|title=Minka Kelly, Susan Sullivan Set for Love, Loss... Off-Broadway|accessdate=2011-04-21|date=2011-04-14|work=[[Playbill]]|author=Gans, Andrew}} ===Television=== Smith made two appearances on ''[[Mister Rogers' Neighborhood]]'', once as a model for Queen Sara's wedding dress and once giving a tour of her restaurant, B. Smith, and making raspberry custard with [[Mister Rogers|Fred Rogers]] and her head chef Henry. During the episode, she taught child viewers about the importance of washing hands and shared the excitement of using huge bowls and mixers. She has said her dream was to feed people, which began at an early age when she fed her dolls. Her half-hour television show, ''B. Smith With Style'', aired on weekdays on [[Bornfree Technologies Network|BTN]] and [[Bounce TV]], featuring home decor and cooking segments.{{cite web|title=B. Smith with Style Episodes|url=http://www.foodnetwork.com/shows/bsmith-with-style/episodes.html|website=foodnetwork.com|accessdate=22 May 2016}} ===Author=== B. Smith authored three books concentrating on recipes and presentation: ''B. Smith's Entertaining and Cooking for Friends'' (1995), ''B. Smith's Rituals and Celebrations'' (1999), and ''B. Smith Cooks Southern Style'' (2009).{{cite web|title=Cookbooks - B. Smith|url=http://www.bsmith.com/cookbooks/|website=bsmith.com|accessdate=22 May 2016}} Smith and her husband released ''Before I Forget'' in early 2016, detailing their journey following her diagnosis of early-onset Alzheimer's.{{cite web|title=Nonfiction Book Review: Before I Forget: Love, Hope, Help, and Acceptance in Our Fight Against Alzheimer's|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-553-44712-5|website=Publishers Weekly|accessdate=22 May 2016|date=23 November 2015}} The book was written with [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] contributing editor [[Michael Shnayerson]]. ==Personal life== Smith has been married twice. Her first marriage was to former [[HBO]] executive Donald Anderson.{{cite news|author=Jeannine Stein|title=Poised for Everything|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 3, 2000|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/feb/03/news/cl-60674|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} Smith married her current husband, her business partner Clarence "Dan" Gasby, in 1992 at [[St. Luke's Lutheran Church (Manhattan)|St. Luke's Lutheran Church]] in Manhattan. He was the executive producer of the [[Essence Awards]] and the senior vice president of marketing at [[King World Productions|Camelot Entertainment Sales Inc.]]{{cite news|title=WEDDINGS; Barbara Smith and Dan Gasby|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 27, 1992|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/27/style/weddings-barbara-smith-and-dan-gasby.html|accessdate=November 26, 2014}}{{cite news|title=About Thank You Dan| quote=In 1985, Gasby joined Camelot Advertising Sales, a division of [[King World Entertainment]], as an Account Executive in the National Barter Syndication division, where he sold ''[[Wheel of Fortune (U.S. game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'', Jeopardy and the ''[[Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', the three most successful shows in the history of TV syndication.|newspaper=BSmith.com|url=http://bsmith.com/about/about-dan|accessdate=November 26, 2014}}{{cite news|author=Jeannine Stein|title=Poised for Everything|quote=His background in television production and ad sales and marketing for TV companies King World and Petry Inc. made it easy for him to segue to becoming publisher of B. Smith Style magazine (he sold 60 pages of ads in the premier issue); partner in her three B. Smith's restaurants in Manhattan, Washington, D.C., and Sag Harbor in New York's tony Hamptons; and creator of the show.|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 3, 2000|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/feb/03/news/cl-60674|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} Smith has no children but is stepmother to Gasby's daughter Dana.{{cite news|author=William L. Hamilton|title =AT HOME WITH: B. SMITH; A Move Up (Martha Who?)|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]| date=April 22, 2004|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/22/garden/at-home-with-b-smith-a-move-up-martha-who.html|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} Smith lives in [[Sag Harbor, New York]].{{cite news|author=Julia Reed|title=All She Can B.|quote=Now at 50, she has a big Manhattan apartment near her Times Square restaurant and a house in an exclusive black section of Sag Harbor, where she lives with Gasby and his 13-year-old daughter, Dana. She and Gasby are cut from the same cloth.|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] via [[Sun-Sentinel]]|date=November 5, 1999|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1999-11-05/lifestyle/9911040572_1_dan-gasby-martha-stewart-smith-and-gasby/2|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} She previously lived on [[Central Park South]] and had a second apartment she used as an office.{{cite news|title=B. Smith Closes a Chapter|author=Harris, Elizabeth |work=[[The New York Times]]|date= April 11, 2010}}{{cite news|author=Chris Pomorski|title=Bed, Bath and Way Beyond: Décor Maven Drops Central Park Co-op for $5.6 M.|newspaper=[[The New York Observer]]|date=April 8, 2014|url=http://observer.com/2014/04/bed-bath-and-way-beyond-decor-maven-drops-central-park-co-op-for-5-6-m|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} In June 2014, Smith revealed that she had been diagnosed with early-onset [[Alzheimer's disease]], stating that she came out with the information to counter the stigma associated with the disease.{{cite news|author=Ann Oldenburg|title=B. Smith reveals she has Alzheimer's|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=June 6, 2014|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2014/06/06/b-smith-reveals-she-has-alzheimers/10056007|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} In November 2014, Smith's husband Dan Gasby reported her missing from [[Southampton, New York]].{{cite news|title=Former model and restaurateur B. Smith missing|newspaper=[[WNYW|MyFoxNY]]|date=November 26, 2014|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/story/27488023/former-model-and-restaurateur-b-smith-missing|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} She was reportedly found the next day in New York City near one of her former residences.{{cite news|author=Maria Puente|title=Missing restaurateur B. Smith reported found in NYC|newspaper=USA Today|date=November 26, 2014|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2014/11/26/ailing-restaurateur-b-smith-reported-missing-in-ny/19527787|accessdate=November 26, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} *{{official website}} ==See also== * [[List of Prisoner characters – inmates|Bea Smith]], a fictional protagonist of: **[[Prisoner (TV series)|''Prisoner'' (TV series)]] (also known as ''Caged Women'' in Canada and as ''Prisoner: Cell Block H'' in Britain and the United States) **[[Prisoner (TV series)#Spin-offs.2C remakes.2C and specials|''Prisoner'' spin-offs, remakes, and specials]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, B.}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Pittsburgh]] [[Category:American restaurateurs]] [[Category:American television chefs]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People with Alzheimer's disease]] [[Category:People from Sag Harbor, New York]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:People from Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Women chefs]]

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Ben Quayle |birth_name = Benjamin Eugene Quayle |image = Benjamin Quayle, Official Portrait, 112th Congress.JPG |state = [[Arizona]] |district = {{ushr|AZ|3|3rd}} |term_start = January 3, 2011 |term_end = January 3, 2013 |predecessor = [[John Shadegg]] |successor = [[Raul Grijalva]] |spouse = Tiffany Crane |children = 1 |parents = [[Dan Quayle]] (father)
[[Marilyn Quayle]] (mother) |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|11|05}} |birth_place = [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]], U.S. |residence = [[Phoenix, Arizona]], U.S. |alma_mater = [[Duke University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[Vanderbilt University Law School|Vanderbilt University]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) |occupation = {{Hlist|[[Attorney at law|Attorney]]|[[Businessman]]| [[Lobbyist]]}} |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |religion = [[Christian]] }} '''Benjamin Eugene Quayle''' (born November 5, 1976){{cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=Q000024|title=QUAYLE, Ben|work=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]|accessdate=April 15, 2013}} is an American lawyer and politician who is a former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|AZ|3}}. A member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], he is the son of 44th [[Vice President of the United States]] [[Dan Quayle]]. He is a member of the [[Tea Party movement]], which had many of its members swept into office during the [[United States elections, 2010|2010 elections]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/daily/family-life-and-consulting-work-are-filling-ben-quayle-s-time-in-phoenix-20130827 |title=Family Life and Consulting Work Are Filling Ben Quayle's Time in Phoenix |publisher=NationalJournal.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} Prior to serving in [[United States Congress|Congress]] he worked as an associate lawyer and eventually founded his own security company as well as writing for the Scottsdale gossip blog, ''The Dirty''. In the 2010 Republican primary he defeated 10 other candidates and went on to win a majority in the general election. In his first bid for re-election, due to [[2010 United States Census|redistricting]], he faced a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] challenge from fellow Representative [[David Schweikert]], ultimately losing the seat in the primary. He currently works for the lobbying firm Clark Hill.{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/business-a-lobbying/307343-former-rep-ben-quayle-joins-lobby-firm |title=Former Rep. Ben Quayle joins lobby firm; won't run in 2014 |publisher=TheHill |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} ==Early life, education, and career== Quayle was born in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] on November 5, 1976, three days after his father was first elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]].{{cite news|date=2010-02-12|work=Fort Wayne Observed|title=Quayle to Run for Congress in 3rd District ... of Arizona|url=http://indiana.typepad.com/fwob/2010/02/quayle-to-run-for-congress-in-3rd-district-of-arizona.html}} As a child, Quayle frequently visited the [[White House]] with his family during the [[Reagan administration]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0211/48915.html |title=Opinion: President Reagan's jelly beans – Rep. Ben Quayle |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} Quayle moved to the [[Phoenix, Arizona]] area with his family in 1996. Quayle graduated from [[Duke University]] in 1998 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in history and earned his [[Juris Doctor]] from [[Vanderbilt University Law School]] in 2002. Quayle has been admitted to the Arizona, New York, and California bar. Quayle worked as an associate lawyer at [[Schulte Roth & Zabel]] from 2004 to 2005, and [[Snell & Wilmer]] from 2006 to 2007. In 2007, Quayle founded Tynwald Capital, a firm specializing in the acquisition and nurturing of small businesses.{{cite news|date=2010-02-12|work=[[CNN]]|title=Former Vice President's son running for Congress|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2010/02/12/former-vice-presidents-son-running-for-congress/?fbid=9QrjVLRQLmm}} Quayle was a founding member of APG-Southwest, a full-service provider of security services for businesses, for which he served as the managing partner of its Arizona branch. Quayle currently works for the Washington lobbying firm Clark Hill. ==U.S. House of Representatives== ===Elections=== ;2010 After Republican Congressman [[John Shadegg]] decided to retire, Quayle launched his campaign following his father's announcement on ''[[America Live with Megyn Kelly]]'' that Ben was a candidate for {{ushr|AZ|3}}.{{cite news|date=February 16, 2010|title=Ben Quayle, son of ex-veep, running for Shadegg's seat|url=http://www.azcentral.com/members/Blog/azdc/73856|publisher=Azcentral.com|accessdate=2015-03-09}} On August 11, 2010, Quayle released an advertisement in which he called [[Barack Obama]] the "worst President in history".{{cite news|date=August 13, 2010|title=Quayle stands by 'worst president in history' critique|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2010/08/13/quayle-stands-by-worst-president-in-history-critique/|work=[[CNN]]}}{{cite news|date=August 11, 2010|title=Best 2010 Candidate Storyline: This Guy, Ben Quayle|url=http://swampland.blogs.time.com/2010/08/11/best-2010-candidate-storyline-this-guy-ben-quayle/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}{{cite news|title=Former VP's son dubs Obama "worst president in history"|url=http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2010/08/12/4875573-former-vps-son-dubs-obama-worst-president-in-history|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815041800/http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2010/08/12/4875573-former-vps-son-dubs-obama-worst-president-in-history|archivedate=2010-08-15|df=}}{{cite news|date=August 11, 2010|title=Ben Quayle: Obama 'the worst president in history'|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/08/ben-quayle-the-worst-president.html | work=The Washington Post}}{{cite news|date=August 13, 2010|title=Mocking Quayle|url=http://politicalwire.com/archives/2010/08/13/mocking_quayle.html|publisher=Politicalwire.com|accessdate=2015-03-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121118195752/http://politicalwire.com/archives/2010/08/13/mocking_quayle.html|archivedate=November 18, 2012|df=}} Quayle's prior involvement with the controversial rumor and gossip website "DirtyScottsdale.com" complicated his run for office. According to the site's founder, Quayle was one of the "original contributors" to the site, which covered Scottsdale nightlife with features including sexy photos of women, and was the predecessor to the gossip website TheDirty.com.{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2010/08/ben-quayle-denies-writing-for.html |title=44 – Ben Quayle admits writing for 'Dirty Scottsdale' Web site |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} Quayle initially denied the rumors,{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0810/40893.html |title=Ben Quayle denies link to Dirty Scottsdale website – Kasie Hunt and Scott Wong |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} before admitting several weeks later that he did, in fact, write material for the site using the [[pen name]] '''Brock Landers'''.{{cite web |url=http://ktar.com/?sid=1325150&nid=6 |title=Racy website link hurting Ben Quayle |date=16 August 2010 |publisher=KTAR |accessdate=8 September 2010}}{{cite news| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2010/08/25/quayle-still-on-the-attack-in-arizona/ | work=CNN | title=Quayle still on the attack in Arizona}}{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0810/40937.html |title=Ben Quayle changes story on website – Scott Wong |publisher=Politico.Com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-19| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101106133457/http://www.politico.com//news//stories//0810//40937.html| archivedate= 6 November 2010 | deadurl= no}} Quayle won the 10-candidate Republican primary on August 24, 2010 with a plurality of 23% of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=512834 |title=AZ District 03 – R Primary Race – Aug 24, 2010 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} In the general election in November, Quayle defeated [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] candidate [[Jon Hulburd]] 52%–41%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=487768 |title=AZ – District 03 Race – Nov 02, 2010 |publisher=Our Campaigns |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} ;2012 After redistricting, Quayle's district was renumbered as the {{ushr|AZ|6|6th district}}, while his home in Phoenix was drawn into the {{ushr|AZ|9|9th district}}. However, Quayle's home was just a few yards outside the 6th, leading a source close to Quayle to tell ''[[National Journal]]'' that Quayle would run in his original district.{{cite web|url=http://hotlineoncall.nationaljournal.com/archives/2011/10/house-democrats.php|title=House Democrats Gain With New Arizona Map|date=October 5, 2011|accessdate=October 7, 2011|work=[[National Journal]]|first=Jessica|last=Taylor|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006163330/http://hotlineoncall.nationaljournal.com/archives/2011/10/house-democrats.php|archivedate=October 6, 2011|df=}} While the 6th is as heavily Republican as its predecessor, the 9th was drawn as a fair-fight district. On February 6, 2012; Quayle confirmed that he would indeed run in the 6th. Quayle faced fellow freshman Republican Congressman [[David Schweikert]] in the Republican primary—the real contest in this heavily Republican district. In an unusual twist, Schweikert's home in [[Fountain Hills, Arizona|Fountain Hills]] had been drawn into the 6th, while as mentioned above Quayle's home had been drawn into the 9th, the geographic successor to Schweikert's 5th.{{cite web|url=http://atr.rollcall.com/quayle-chooses-to-run-against-schweikert/|title=Arizona: Quayle Opts to Run Against Schweikert|date=February 6, 2012|accessdate=February 7, 2012|work=[[Roll Call]]|first=Abby|last=Livingston}}{{cite web|last=Sullivan |first=Sean |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2012/08/29/schweikert-beats-quayle-in-arizona/ |title=Schweikert defeats Quayle in Arizona |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2012-08-29 |accessdate=2015-03-09}} During the bitter primary campaign, Schweikert was widely criticised for a mailer that accused Quayle of "going both ways", suggesting that he was [[bisexual]]. On the reverse, the mailer listed issues on which it claimed Quayle had taken both liberal and conservative positions. Senator [[Jon Kyl]] said that "such campaign tactics insult the voters, degrade politics and expose those who stoop to them as unworthy of high office" and Senator [[John McCain]] said the mailer was one of the "worst that I have seen" and that it "crosses the boundary of decent political dialogue and discourse". Quayle's spokeswoman called the mailer "utterly false" and "a sleazy smear tactic". Schweikert's spokesman responded that people "should get their minds out of the gutter" because the mailer was "obviously" referring to "both ways – as in liberal and conservative". ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' asked two political scientists to review the mailer, who both said that they had "never seen anybody accuse someone of flip-flopping [on political issues] that way" and said that it was "difficult to believe" that the sexual suggestion was unintentional.{{cite web|url=http://dailycaller.com/2012/08/08/schweikert-quayle-goes-both-ways-on-important-conservative-issues/ |title=Schweikert says Quayle 'goes both ways' |publisher=The Daily Caller |date=2012-08-08 |accessdate=2015-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2012/08/06/kyl-faults-schweikert-after-mailer.html |title=Kyl faults Schweikert after mailer says Quayle 'goes both ways' – Phoenix Business Journal |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date=2012-08-06 |accessdate=2015-03-09}}{{cite web|last=Nowicki |first=Dan |url=http://www.azcentral.com/news/articles/2012/08/03/20120803district-6-schweikert-like-fight-in-dc.html |title=District 6 race: David Schweikert says 'I like the fight' in D.C |publisher=Azcentral.com |date=2012-08-03 |accessdate=2015-03-09}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://archive.azcentral.com/members/Blog/azdc/169420 |title=azcentral.com staff blogs – AZ/DC Blog – azdc – McCain endorses Quayle, scolds Schweikert for mailer |publisher=Archive.azcentral.com |date=2012-08-15 |accessdate=2015-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/house-races/243973-mccain-blasts-arizona-republican-who-accused-quayle-of-going-both-ways |title=McCain blasts Arizona Republican who accused Quayle of ‘going both ways’ |publisher=TheHill |date=2012-08-16 |accessdate=2015-03-09}} Although the 6th contained almost two-thirds of Quayle's constituents, Schweikert defeated Quayle in the Republican primary by 53 percent to Quayle's 47 percent.{{cite news |last=Zapler |first=Mike|last2=Isenstadt|first2=Alex|title=Arizona House primary results: Ben Quayle booted from Congress|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0812/80331.html?hp=r2 |newspaper=Politico |date=August 29, 2012}} Matt Jette, a business professor at the [[Thunderbird School of Global Management]] who ran for [[List of Governors of Arizona|Governor of Arizona]] as a Republican in [[Arizona gubernatorial election, 2010|2010]], won the Democratic nomination.{{cite news|url=http://www.wausaudailyherald.com/usatoday/article/38760165|title=1st Democrat announces run for Ariz. 6th District|date=March 9, 2012|accessdate=March 9, 2012|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Wausau Daily Herald]]|first=Bob|last=Christie}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Schweikert defeated Jette in the November 6, 2012, general election with 62% of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/2012-election/map/#/House/2012/AZ |title=2014 Election Results Senate: Map by State, Live Midterm Voting Updates |publisher=Politico |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}} ===Tenure=== After being elected to Congress, Quayle announced that he would opt out of the taxpayer funded Congressional health care and pension plan.{{cite news|date=2011-12-09|work=Washington Times|title=EDITORIAL: Make congressional pensions passe|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/dec/9/make-congressional-pensions-passe}} In 2012, Quayle was named "The Most Conservative Member of the House of Representatives" by the [[National Journal]].{{cite news|date=2012-02-23|work=National Journal|title=Most Conservative Members of Congress|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/magazine/most-liberal-most-conservative-20120223}} He was awarded the 2011 "National Taxpayers’ Friend Award"{{cite news|date=2012-04-30|title=NTU Presents Taxpayer Friend Awards|url=http://www.ntu.org/governmentbytes/ntu-presents-taxpayer-friend.html|publisher=Ntu.org|accessdate=2015-03-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121227110725/http://ntu.org/governmentbytes/ntu-presents-taxpayer-friend.html|archivedate=2012-12-27|df=}} by the [[National Taxpayers Union]], the "Spirit of Enterprise Award"{{cite news|title=Spirit of Enterprise Awards 2011|url=http://www.uschamber.com/issues/legislators/spirit-enterprise-awards-2011|publisher=Uschamber.com|accessdate=2015-03-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313074953/https://www.uschamber.com/issues/legislators/spirit-enterprise-awards-2011|archivedate=2014-03-13|df=}} by the [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]], and was given a 98% scorecard {{cite news|title=Congressional Scorecard|url=http://www.clubforgrowth.org/projects/scorecard/?year=2011&chamber=2&state=Any&party=Any&memberName=quayle|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130414125118/http://www.clubforgrowth.org/projects/scorecard/?year=2011&chamber=2&state=Any&party=Any&memberName=quayle|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-04-14|publisher=Clubforgrowth.org|accessdate=2015-03-09}} by the [[Club for Growth]]. Controversy arose after a bill to increase combat pay for military personnel was rejected, and Quayle and [[David Schweikert]] [[high-five]]d, happy about the bill's failure. After the incident, Maria Meacham, the mother of an active-duty soldier upset about the vote, began shouting from the gallery, and was removed by [[United States Capitol Police|security]].{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/maria-meacham-gets-arrested-in-dc-2012-9|title=Congressmen High-Fived After Blocking A Military Pay Raise, And Then Arrested An Army Mom|author=Geoffrey Ingersoll|date=September 19, 2012|accessdate=January 6, 2013|work=[[Business Insider]]}} Quayle introduced legislation related to border security, guns, small business, government transparency, and health care{{cite news|title=Library of Congress|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/home/thomas.php|publisher=Thomas.loc.gov|accessdate=2015-03-09}} and successfully sponsored H.R. 3862, the Sunshine for Regulatory Decrees and Settlements Act "to impose certain limitations on consent decrees and settlement agreements by agencies that require the agencies to take regulatory action in accordance with the terms thereof, and for other purposes".{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/112/hr3862/text/ih |title=Text of H.R. 3862 (112th): Sunshine for Regulatory Decrees and Settlements Act of 2012 (Introduced version) |publisher=GovTrack.us |date=2012-02-01 |accessdate=2015-03-09}} According to the [[Congressional Budget Office]], "Under the bill, complaints against federal agencies, the terms of the consent decrees or settlement agreements, and the award of attorneys’ fees would need to be published in an accessible manner, including electronically. The legislation would require that any proposed consent decree or settlement agreement be published in the Federal Register for 60 days of public comment prior to filing with the court."{{cite web|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/43351 |title=H.R. 3862, Sunshine for Regulatory Decrees and Settlements Act of 2012 | Congressional Budget Office |publisher=Cbo.gov |date=2012-06-25 |accessdate=2015-03-09}} ===Committee assignments=== Quayle served on the following committees during his tenure.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollcall.com/members/32400.html|title=Rep. Ben Quayle (R-Ariz.)|publisher=[[Roll Call]] ([[Congressional Quarterly|CQ]])|accessdate=2015-03-09}} * '''[[United States House Committee on Homeland Security|Committee on Homeland Security]]''' ** [[United States House Homeland Security Subcommittee on Border and Maritime Security|Subcommittee on Border and Maritime Security]] (Vice Chair) ** [[United States House Homeland Security Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence|Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence]] * '''[[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|Committee on the Judiciary]]''' ** [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Courts, Commercial and Administrative Law|Subcommittee on Courts, Commercial and Administrative Law]] ** [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Intellectual Property, Competition, and the Internet|Subcommittee on Intellectual Property, Competition, and the Internet]] (Vice Chair) * '''[[United States House Committee on Science, Space and Technology|Committee on Science, Space and Technology]]''' ** [[United States House Science Subcommittee on Research and Science Education|Subcommittee on Research and Science Education]] ** [[United States House Science Subcommittee on Technology and Innovation|Subcommittee on Technology and Innovation]] (Chairman) ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} * {{CongLinks | congbio=Q000024 | votesmart=123506 | fec=H0AZ03362 | congress= }} * {{C-SPAN|Ben Quayle}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Arizona | district=3 | years=2011–2013 | before=[[John Shadegg]] | after=[[Raul Grijalva]]}} {{end}} {{ArizonaUSRepresentatives}} {{USCongRep-start|congresses= 112th [[United States Congress]] |state=[[Arizona]]}} {{USCongRep/AZ/112}} {{USCongRep-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Quayle, Benjamin}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Lawyers from Phoenix, Arizona]] [[Category:American people of Manx descent]] {{Use American English|date=March 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Benjamin Harvey Hill | image = Benjamin Harvey Hill - Brady-Handy.jpg | jr/sr = United States Senator | state = [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | term_start = March 4, 1877 | term_end = August 16, 1882 | predecessor = [[Thomas M. Norwood|Thomas Norwood]] | successor = [[Middleton P. Barrow|Middleton Barrow]] | state2 = [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | district2 = {{ushr|Georgia|9|9th}} | term_start2 = May 5, 1875 | term_end2 = March 4, 1877 | predecessor2 = [[Hiram Parks Bell|Hiram Bell]] | successor2 = Hiram Bell | office3 = [[Congress of the Confederate States|Confederate States Senator]]
from [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | term_start3 = February 18, 1862 | term_end3 = May 10, 1865 | predecessor3 = ''Position established'' | successor3 = ''Position abolished'' | office4 = Deputy to the [[Provisional Confederate States Congress|C.S. Congress]]
from [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | term_start4 = February 8, 1861 | term_end4 = February 17, 1862 | predecessor4 = ''Position established'' | successor4 = ''Position abolished'' | birth_date = {{birth date|1823|9|14}} | birth_place = [[Jasper County, Georgia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1882|8|16|1823|9|14}} | death_place = [[Gurley, Alabama]] | nationality = American | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | otherparty = [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] (Before 1855)
[[Know Nothing|American]] (1855–1859)
[[Constitutional Union Party (United States)|Constitutional Union]] (1859–1861) | alma_mater = [[University of Georgia]] }} '''Benjamin Harvey Hill''' (September 14, 1823 – August 16, 1882) was a politician whose career spanned state and national politics, and the Civil War. He served in the Georgia legislature in both houses. Although he had opposed secession, he stayed with the South and served as a [[Confederate States Senate|Confederate senator]] representing Georgia. After the war and near the end of the [[Reconstruction era]], Hill was elected in 1874 to the [[United States House of Representatives]], and in 1877 as a [[United States Senate|U.S. senator]] from Georgia. He served in the Senate until his death in 1882. ==Early life== Hill was born September 14, 1823, in [[Hillsboro, Georgia]], in [[Jasper County, Georgia|Jasper County]]. He was of [[Welsh American|Welsh]] and [[Ireland|Irish American]] ancestry.''Senator Benjamin H. Hill of Georgia: his life, speeches and writings'', page 9 He attended the [[University of Georgia]] in [[Athens, Georgia]], where he was a member of the [[Demosthenian Literary Society]]. He graduated in 1844 with first honors. He was admitted to the Georgia bar later in 1844. He married Caroline E. Holt in [[Athens, Georgia]] in 1845. ==Early career== [[File:Bellevue (LaGrange, Georgia).JPG|thumb|left|alt=Bellevue plantation house|Hill's home, [[Bellevue (LaGrange, Georgia)|Bellevue]]]] As a politician, Hill was affiliated with a number of parties, reflecting the volatile politics before and after the [[American Civil War]]. He was elected to the state legislature of Georgia in 1851 as a member of the [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig Party]]. He supported [[Millard Fillmore]] running on the [[Know-Nothing]] ticket in 1856, and was an elector for that party in the [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral College]]. In 1857, he ran for governor of Georgia unsuccessfully against the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee [[Joseph E. Brown]]. In 1859, he was elected to the state senate as a [[Union (American Civil War)|Unionist]]. In 1860, he was again an elector, this time for [[John Bell (Tennessee politician)|John Bell]] and the [[Union (American Civil War)|Unionist]] party. Hill was known as {{anchor|the peerless orator}}"the peerless orator" for his skill in delivering speeches,Candler, Allen Daniel (1909). [https://books.google.com/books?id=D3QOAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA757 ''The Confederate records of the State of Georgia, Volume 1'']. Atlanta, GA: C. P. Byrd publishing. {{ISBN|978-1147068887}}. Retrieved July 22, 2013 and he was the only non-Democratic member of the [[Ordinance of Secession|Georgia secession convention]] on January 16, 1861. He spoke publicly against the dissolution of the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]], along with [[Alexander Stephens]], a former opponent. Following Stephens' highly regarded argument, based on a conservative reading of the Constitution, Hill struck a more pragmatic tone. His arguments related to the conservative belief that disunion would ultimately lead to the abolition of [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] and the downfall of Southern society. He quoted [[Henry Ward Beecher]], a Northern [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]], who enthusiastically supported the dissolution of the Union as a means to end slavery, and described the anti-slavery [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] as a "disunionist" party, in contrast to the "Union men and Southern men" participating in the convention. Acknowledging the need to respond to the threat of Lincoln's election, Hill argued that his fellow Georgians should continue to resist Lincoln democratically within the bounds of the Constitution. He compared this course to [[George Washington]], "so cool, so brave, and so thoughtful." He argued that the Northern states would eventually follow the British course of rising abolitionist thought, followed by acceptance again of slavery due to economic necessity. But he allowed that the South should prepare for secession and war if it should become necessary.Freehling, William W., and Craig M. Simpson, ''Secession Debated: Georgia's Showdown in 1860'', New York: Oxford University Press, 1992. Hill voted against secession,{{Cite book|title = The Civil War: The First Year Told by Those Who Lived It|last = |first = |publisher = The Library of America|year = 2011|isbn = 978-1-59853-088-9|location = |pages = 14}} but became a political ally of [[Jefferson Davis]], who was elected as president of the Confederacy. When the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate government]] was formed, Hill transferred to the [[Confederate Provisional Congress]]. He was subsequently elected by the Georgia legislature to the [[Confederate States Senate]], a term which he held throughout its existence. At one point in the Confederate Senate, Hill and fellow senator [[William Lowndes Yancey]] had to be separated by other members after a bloody scuffle on the floor.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB115231052552401057] Ferguson, Stuart, "The Zealotry of the Convert: Slavery's Firebrand Defender," book review of Eric H. Walther's ''William Lowndes Yancey and the Coming of the Civil War,'' in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', 8 July 2006; page P9; accessed on July 14, 2006 At the end of the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], Hill was arrested as a Confederate official by the Union and confined in [[Fort Lafayette]] from May until July 1865. ==Later career== Unlike many Confederate politicians, Hill had a long and distinguished career as a "reconstructed" Southerner and U.S. politician. He ultimately became a Democrat after the Civil War ended. He spoke out passionately against Radical Reconstruction and in the summer of 1867 made a series of speeches in Atlanta, the most famous being the Davis House speech of July 16, 1867, denouncing the Reconstruction Acts of 1867. His courage and eloquence enhanced his regional fame and won him national recognition.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=August 2018}} In 1874, he was elected to the U. S. House of Representatives, serving from May 5, 1875 - March 3, 1877. He quickly won a reputation as a spokesman for the South. He was later elected by the Georgia legislature to the U.S. Senate on January 26, 1877, as Reconstruction was ending. He served in the U.S. Senate from March 4, 1877, until his death on August 16, 1882. His obituary was featured on the front page of the ''[[Atlanta Constitution]],'' on August 17, 1882. ==Death== Hill is buried in historic [[Oakland Cemetery (Atlanta)|Oakland Cemetery]] in Atlanta, Georgia. ==Legacy and honors== * A life-size statue of Hill looking down from atop a similarly sized plinth was installed inside the [[Georgia State Capitol]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. * A larger than life portrait of Hill hangs in the Capitol Rotunda. * [[Ben Hill County, Georgia]], founded in 1906, was named in his honor.{{cite book | url=http://www.kenkrakow.com/gpn/b.pdf | title=Georgia Place-Names: Their History and Origins | publisher=Winship Press | author=Krakow, Kenneth K. | year=1975 | location=Macon, GA | pages=16 | isbn=0-915430-00-2}} ==See also== *[[List of signers of the Georgia Ordinance of Secession]] *[[List of United States Congress members who died in office (1790–1899)]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} {{CongBio|H000587}} *[http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/Article.jsp?id=h-2490 Benjamin Harvey Hill] at the ''[[New Georgia Encyclopedia]]'' *[http://georgiainfo.galileo.usg.edu/topics/historical_markers/county/jasper/birthplace-of-benjamin-harvey-hill Birthplace of Benjamin Harvey Hill] historical marker {{Navboxes |title=Offices and distinctions |list1= {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | title = Deputy in the [[Provisional Confederate States Congress|C.S. Congress]]
from [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | years = February 8, 1861 – February 17, 1862 | before = Position established | after = Position abolished}}{{s-par|cs-sen}} {{succession box | title = [[List of members of the Confederate Senate|Confederate States Senator (Class 3) from Georgia]] | years = February 18, 1862 – May 10, 1865 | before = Position established | after = Position abolished | alongside = [[John Wood Lewis, Sr.|John Lewis]], [[Herschel Vespasian Johnson|Herschel Johnson]]}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{s-bef|before=[[Hiram Parks Bell|Hiram Bell]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from Georgia|U.S. House of Representatives]]
from [[Georgia's 9th congressional district]]|years=1875–1877}} {{s-aft|after=[[Hiram Parks Bell|Hiram Bell]]}} {{s-par|us-sen}} {{s-bef|before=[[Thomas M. Norwood|Thomas Norwood]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of United States Senators from Georgia|United States Senator (Class 2) from Georgia]]|years=1877–1882|alongside=[[John Brown Gordon|John Gordon]], [[Joseph E. Brown|Joseph Brown]]}} {{s-aft|after=[[Middleton P. Barrow|Middleton Barrow]]}} {{s-end}} }} {{Navboxes |title=Articles related to Benjamin Harvey Hill |list1= {{CSProvisionalConstitutionSig}} {{Confederate States Constitution signatories}} {{USSenGA}} {{C.S. Senators}} }} {{Portal bar|American Civil War|Biography|Georgia (U.S. state)|Politics}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hill, Benjamin H.}} [[Category:1823 births]] [[Category:1882 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American politicians]] [[Category:American slave owners]] [[Category:Burials at Oakland Cemetery (Atlanta)]] [[Category:Confederate States Senators]] [[Category:Democratic Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Democratic Party United States Senators]] [[Category:Deputies and delegates to the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States]] [[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) Democrats]] [[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) Know Nothings]] [[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) state senators]] [[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) Whigs]] [[Category:Members of the Georgia House of Representatives]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:People from Jasper County, Georgia]] [[Category:People of Georgia (U.S. state) in the American Civil War]] [[Category:Signers of the Confederate States Constitution]] [[Category:Signers of the Provisional Constitution of the Confederate States]] [[Category:Signers of the Georgia Ordinance of Secession]] [[Category:University of Georgia alumni]] [[Category:United States Senators from Georgia (U.S. state)]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2008}} [[File:Reggie Love and Dr. Jeffrey Kuhlman in Cadillac One.jpg|thumb|[[Reggie Love]], left, Barack Obama's body man from 2009 to 2011, is seen here in a presidential motorcade outside Strasbourg for the NATO Summit, April 2009]] [[File:President Bill Clinton in January 1995 at the Conference on Trade Investment in Central & Eastern Europe with Presidential Aide Elliott Frutkin.jpg|thumb|Elliott Frutkin, acting as President Bill Clinton's Interim body man in 1994-1995, seen here far right, screens line approaching the President during meet and greet at the Conference on Trade & Investment-Central and Eastern Europe, January 1995]] A '''body man''' or '''body woman''' is, in U.S. political jargon, a civilian [[personal assistant]] and sometimes [[valet]] to a politician or political candidate. Such a person accompanies the politician or candidate virtually everywhere, often arranging lodging, transportation, and meals, and providing snacks, a cell phone, and any other necessary assistance.
==List of notable body men and body women== <!-- As a general guideline, if a person is not notable enough for an article, they are not notable enough to be listed here. --> * [[Kris Engskov]], aide to President [[Bill Clinton]], 1997–2000 * [[Blake Gottesman]], aide to President [[George W. Bush]], 2001–2006 * [[Jared Weinstein]], aide to President [[George W. Bush]], 2006–2009 * [[Reggie Love]], aide to President [[Barack Obama]], 2009–2011 * [[John McEntee (politician)|John McEntee]], aide to President [[Donald Trump]], 2017- March 2018 * Jordan Karem, aide to President Donald Trump, March 2018 - January 2019<ref name="Cook 2018">{{cite web |last=Cook |first=Nancy |title=Trump's trusted body man to depart White House |website=POLITICO |date=2018-11-26 |url=https://politi.co/2r7mG5u |access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref>
===Fictional=== * Jane Basdin (played by [[Samantha Mathis]]), personal aide to President [[Andrew Shepherd]] in the 1995 movie, ''[[The American President]]'' * [[Charlie Young]] (played by [[Dulé Hill]]), personal assistant to President [[Josiah Bartlet]] for the first six years of the [[NBC]] [[TV]] series, ''[[The West Wing (television)|The West Wing]]'' * Gary Walsh (played by [[Tony Hale]]), personal aide to Vice-President [[Selina Meyer]] in the [[HBO]] TV series ''[[Veep (TV series)|Veep]]'' * Blake Moran (played by [[Erich Bergen]]), personal aide to Secretary of State [[Elizabeth McCord (character)|Elizabeth McCord]] in the [[CBS]] TV series ''[[Madam Secretary (TV series)|Madam Secretary]]'' * Marissa Gold (played by [[Sarah Steele]]), personal aide to Cook County State's Attorney [[Alicia Florrick]] in the [[CBS]] TV series ''[[The Good Wife]]'' * Dembe Zuma (played by [[Hisham Tawfiq]]), personal assistant and bodyguard to FBI Task Force [[informant]] [[Raymond Reddington]] in the [[NBC]] TV series ''[[The Blacklist (TV series)|The Blacklist]]''
==See also== * [[Aide-de-camp]], a military assistant to a senior official
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Body man}} [[Category:Political professionals]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer |birth_name = | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = July 21 1971{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} | birth_place = [[Auckland]], New Zealand | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Writer, game designer | spouse = | nationality = New Zealander | period = | genre = [[Role-playing game]]s | influences = [[Neil Gaiman]], [[Roger Zelazny]]<ref name="Goodreads">{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/author/show/201367.Cam_Banks|title=Cam Banks|author=Cam Banks|work=Goodreads}}</ref> }}
'''Cam Banks''' is a game designer who was lead designer for the ''[[Marvel Heroic Roleplaying]]'',<ref name="39th Origins">{{cite web|url=http://www.gama.org/OriginsAwards/39thOriginsAwards/tabid/3265/Default.aspx |title=39th Origins Awards|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227150807/http://gama.org/OriginsAwards/39thOriginsAwards/tabid/3265/Default.aspx |archivedate=2013-12-27 }}</ref><ref name="ENnies">{{cite web|url=http://www.ennie-awards.com/blog/congratulations-to-the-2012-ennie-award-winners/|title=Congratulations to the 2012 ENnie Award winners!|work=ennie-awards.com}}</ref> and the supplement to ''[[Serenity Role Playing Game]]'', the ''Big Damn Heroes Handbook''.<ref name="36th Origins">{{Cite web |url=http://www.gama.org/OriginsAwards/OriginsAwardsWinnersThe2000s/The2009OriginsAwards/tabid/3196/Default.aspx# |title=36th Annual Origins Awards |access-date=2014-01-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227143655/http://gama.org/OriginsAwards/OriginsAwardsWinnersThe2000s/The2009OriginsAwards/tabid/3196/Default.aspx# |archive-date=2013-12-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Career== Cam Banks and [[Christopher Coyle]] wrote a new [[Dragonlance]] campaign saga produced by [[Sovereign Press]] in three parts: ''Key of Destiny'' (2004), ''Spectre of Sorrows'' (2005) and ''Price of Courage'' (2006). The series totalled 730 pages and detailed major events in the Age of Mortals.<ref name="designers">{{Cite book|author=Shannon Appelcline|title=Designers & Dragons|publisher=Mongoose Publishing|year=2011| isbn= 978-1-907702- 58-7}}</ref>{{rp|353}} His first novel was published in 2007.<ref name="NYT">https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/24/books/jim-butcher-one-of-the-authors-from-ambermush.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0</ref> He wrote the 2008 Dragonlance novel ''[[List of Dragonlance novels#Anvil of Time|The Sellsword]]''.<ref name="wizardsbio">{{cite web|url=http://ww2.wizards.com/Books/Wizards/Bios/default.aspx?doc=CamBanks|title=Cam Banks|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090224004008/http://ww2.wizards.com/Books/Wizards/Bios/default.aspx?doc=CamBanks|archivedate=February 24, 2009}}</ref> Banks was later the [[Cortex System]] line editor for [[Margaret Weis Productions]], and in 2010 the system was renovated into the [[Cortex Plus]] system.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|354}} Banks was the line developer for the ''[[Smallville Roleplaying Game]]'' (2010), which he co-designed with indie publisher [[Josh Roby]].<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|354}} Banks co-designed ''[[Leverage: The Roleplaying Game]]'' (2011) with [[Evil Hat Productions]]' [[Rob Donoghue]], [[Clark Valentine]], and others.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|354}}
A native of New Zealand, Banks lives in [[St Paul, Minnesota]], where he has been working as a brand manager and production specialist for [[Atlas Games]] since February 2013.<ref name="Atlas Announcement">{{cite web|url=http://blog.atlas-games.com/2013/01/cam-banks-to-join-atlas-games.html|title=Atlas Games: Cam Banks to Join Atlas Games|work=atlas-games.com}}</ref> Before this he was a [[line developer]] at [[Margaret Weis Productions]], where he led the development of the ''[[Smallville Roleplaying Game]]'', ''[[Leverage: The Roleplaying Game]]'', and ''[[Marvel Heroic Roleplaying]]'' in addition to continuing with Margaret Weis' historical properties, leading the development of the ''Big Damn Heroes'' supplement for the ''[[Serenity Role Playing Game]]'', and working on the [[Dragonlance]] setting.
On November 1, 2016, [[Margaret Weis Productions]] released a statement announcing that Cam Banks and his new design studio [[Magic Vacuum]] had licensed the original [[Cortex System]] and [[Cortex Plus]] system and would be "taking over the design, development, and publishing of games based on these rules... for 2017 and beyond," coinciding with "Margaret’s retirement from RPG development to focus on her current novel and film projects."<ref>[https://margaretweis.com/blogs/news/cam-banks-acquires-cortex-license Statement on Margaret Weis Productions web site]</ref>
==Bibliography==
===Roleplaying Games and Supplements===
Cam Banks has been a freelance writer and designer for [[Sovereign Press]], and a designer and line developer for [[Margaret Weis Productions]] where he first produced supplements for the [[Cortex System]] games designed by [[Jamie Chambers]]. Then he led the design of the [[Cortex Plus]] games.
====Dragonlance====
* Design Credits: ''Dragonlance Dungeon Master's Screen'' 2003 * Additional Design Credits: ''Age of Mortals'' 2003 * Additional Design Credits: ''Towers of High Sorcery'' 2004 * Additional Design Credits: ''War of the Lance'' 2004 * Design Credits: ''Bestiary of Krynn'' 2004 ENnie Awards: Best Art, Interior and Best Monster Supplement: Silver Awards * Author: Dragons of Krynn 2006 * Author: Bestiary of Krynn (revised) 2007 * Co-author: ''Key of Destiny'' 2004 * Co-author: ''Spectre of Sorrows'' 2005 * Co-author: ''Price of Courage'' 2006 * ''Dragonlance: Dragons of Autumn'' (Updated version of the original adventures) * ''Dragonlance: Dragons of Winter'' (Updated version of the original adventures)
====Cortex System Games and Supplements with Margaret Weis Productions====
* Lead Designer: ''[[Serenity Role Playing Game]]'' supplement: ''The Big Damn Heroes Handbook'' 2009 – Origins Award: Best Roleplaying Supplement<ref name="36th Origins"/> * Lead Designer: ''[[Supernatural Role Playing Game]]'' supplement: ''Supernatural: Guide To The Hunted'' 2010
====Cortex Plus games with Margaret Weis Productions====
* Lead Designer: ''[[Smallville Roleplaying Game]]'' - 2009 * Lead Designer: ''[[Leverage: The Roleplaying Game]]'' - 2010 * Lead Designer: ''[[Marvel Heroic Roleplaying]] Basic Game'' - 2011 Origins Award: Best Roleplaying Game <ref name="39th Origins"/> 2012 [[ENnies]]: Best Roleplaying Game Silver Award<ref name="ENnies"/> * Lead Designer: ''Marvel Heroic Roleplaying Civil War Event Book Essentials Edition'' – 2011 Origins Award: Best Roleplaying Supplement <ref name="39th Origins"/> 2012 [[ENnies]]: Best Roleplaying Game Supplement<ref name="ENnies"/> * Lead Designer: ''Marvel Heroic Roleplaying Civil War Event Book Premium Edition'' (the same as the Essentials Edition, but containing the game rules from the Basic Set).
===Books=== * [[List of Dragonlance novels#Anvil of Time|The Sellsword]]
==Critical reception==
<!--Can someone from the Dragonlance project have a look at this-->
As a lead designer on pre-existing products, Cam Banks was responsible for [[Margaret Weis Productions]] second ever [[Origins Award]] with ''Big Damn Heroes''. His ''Supernatural: Guide to the Hunted'' was applauded for the design and detail work although criticized slightly for the adherence to Supernatural's canon.<ref name="Flames Guide">{{cite web|url=http://www.flamesrising.com/guide-to-the-hunted-review/|title=Guide to the Hunted Review - Supernatural - Flames Rising Horror Webzine|work=flamesrising.com}}</ref> After becoming line developer he ceased to use the [[Cortex System]], instead working with members of [[Evil Hat Productions]] to produce all the new games he created using the [[Cortex Plus]].
Reception for the Cortex Plus games has been generally positive. Both [[io9]] and RPGamer reviewed the ''[[Smallville Roleplaying Game]]'', Banks's first game as lead designer. They praised the way the game "had the heart of an independent role playing game and focused on conflict rather than powers."<ref name="io9">{{cite web|url=http://io9.com/5630255/smallville-rpg-wields-big-drama|title=Smallville RPG wields big drama|author=Ed Grabianowski - Robot Viking|work=io9}}</ref><ref name="RPGamer">{{cite web|url=http://www.rpgamer.com/savingthrow/reviews/rev-SV.html|title=RPGamer > The Saving Throw > Review|work=rpgamer.com}}</ref> [[Leverage: The Roleplaying Game]] was nominated for an Origins Award, and [[Marvel Heroic Roleplaying]] won two Origins Awards and an ENnie and was praised by SF Signal for how "authentic and true to the characters the representations felt."<ref name="SFSignal">{{cite web|url=http://www.sfsignal.com/archives/2013/03/roll-perception-plus-awareness-the-marvel-heroic-roleplaying-game/|title=Roll Perception Plus Awareness: The Marvel Heroic Roleplaying Game|work=sfsignal.com}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
