=== Television and fame === Martin is not comfortable with being a public figure and rejects any notion that he is a celebrity, turning down offers such as Top Gear's [[Star in a Reasonably Priced Car|Star In A Reasonably Priced Car]] segment.<ref name="driving.co.uk">{{Cite web|url=http://www.driving.co.uk/news/guy-martin-on-his-indian-motorbike-adventure/|title=Guy Martin on his Indian motorbike adventure|website=Sunday Times Driving|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-08}}</ref> After struggling to come to terms with the fame brought about by his media work, Martin was diagnosed with [[Asperger syndrome]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/guy-martin-profile-jeremy-clarksons-perfect-replacement-on-top-gear-10237190.html |title=Guy Martin profile: Jeremy Clarkson's perfect replacement on Top Gear |last1=Usborne |first1=Simon |date=8 May 2015 |website=[[independent.co.uk]]|access-date=31 May 2015}}</ref> Skeptical of the psychiatrist's findings, he says "It hasn't changed anything, it just confirms why I do certain things in a certain way."<ref name=":275"/> As a result of his BBC work, he had begun to be recognized by non-racing fans even before the release of the TT3D film.<ref name=":20"/> He would be quite happy if nobody watched his shows, as it would mean he would never get recognized.<ref name=":275"/> While not wanting to seem unappreciative of the public's support, he tries to cope with fame by avoiding crowded situations.<ref name="driving.co.uk" /> He prefers to live out of his van while racing or on television shoots.<ref name=":4" />
He does not see TV work as a job in itself and would not miss it if it were to end; he views it as a means to do things he otherwise could not,<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":16"/> gaining invaluable sources of information and experiences from the people it allows him to meet.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> As such, he frequently turns down offers of television work if they don't interest him, and has said his existing TV workload was already becoming an issue.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3" /> He fears being seen as inauthentic if he became a full-time presenter, seeing some in the industry as "passionate about anything that they're told to be passionate about".<ref name=":21"/> He has only watched one of his shows, the Pike's Peak episode of Speed, and only on the recommendation of a usually unimpressed friend.<ref name=":92" /> While appreciating the things his fame has brought him, he's deliberately avoided getting into an unsustainable financial position by living to excess.<ref name=":21"/>
=== Racing and thrill seeking === Although following in his father's footsteps into motorcycle racing, Martin is clear that it was his own choice, his father never pressured him into it. His passion for the TT was ignited at age 16 with the invitation from Baz Kirk to return to the island.<ref name=":6" /> Although he has raced in track events, he is attracted to road racing, and the TT in particular, due to their dangerous nature. He hopes to win a TT before the event is banned for health and safety reasons.<ref name="mbr.co.uk"/> He says "I like a bit of danger. I haven't got a death wish but it makes things exciting, doesn't it?".<ref name=":18"/> He likes the appeal of reaching 200 mph all the time in road races, and their unforgiving nature, something he believes series like the [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|MotoGP]] or [[Superbike World Championship|Superbikes]] simply don't offer.<ref name="mbr.co.uk"/>
Mindful of the risks, he would not regret dying in a race, but he is prepared to go beyond the line (beyond which you risk crashing), in order to win.<ref name=":16"/> The danger feeds his need to feel in control of his destiny,<ref name=":21"/> although he conceded the inherent risks mean he would be doing well if he lived to age 60.<ref name=":275"/> His major crashes of 2010 and 2015 have not changed his outlook;<ref name=":18"/> he has described the moment before losing control in 2010 crash as priceless, the ultimate feeling of danger.<ref name=":25">{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/10511832/Guy-Martin-why-I-like-to-go-dangerously-fast.html|title=Guy Martin: why I like to go dangerously fast|website=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-09}}</ref> He wants to go fast and get near death, while also walking away.<ref name="driving.co.uk" /> He denies he is reckless and believes everything he does is calculated;<ref name=":275"/> believing you get out of life what you put in, he ensures he trains and prepares hard for dangerous activities so he is in control of, and can even enjoy, the experience.<ref>Speed with Guy Martin, Pike's Peak episode, Channel 4, 2 November 2014</ref> His television producer agrees, stating "he's not stubborn, or reckless, he's calculating".<ref name=":2"/> This attraction of the combination of speed and a sense of danger was part of the motivation for him doing his ''Speed'' series.<ref name=":25"/>
He has never wanted to race motorbikes full-time, believing he would get sick of the sight of them,<ref name=":16"/> and liking the ability of being able to point to his amateur status to professionals, as both an excuse when he loses and a way to gloat when he wins.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> He decided to prioritise cycling over the TT in 2016 as he felt he was nearing the point where he would be too old to compete properly, and after 11 seasons at the TT he was beginning to find the routine of the motorcycle season monotonous.<ref name=":17" /> While not seeing it as thrilling as motorbikes,<ref name=":92" /> he is attracted by the isolation it offers,<ref name=":21"/> and the equal combination of both a physical and mental challenge,<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> feeding into a new found desire to break himself simply for the sense of achievement.<ref name="driving.co.uk" />
== Hobbies and interests == Martin owns a [[Rolls-Royce Merlin|Merlin aero engine]] from a 1942 [[Avro Lancaster|Lancaster bomber]], which he plans to install in his front room, alongside a [[Scania 4-series|Scania 144 530]] truck engine. He is also hoping to acquire a Daimler 600 engine from a [[Messerschmitt]].<ref name=":92" /> He also has a 1915 [[Amanco]] ''Chore Boy'' [[stationary engine]] with original [[ignition magneto|low tension magneto]] in his kitchen.<ref name="About Guy"/>
Martin is not particularly interested in watching television or spending time on the internet – he doesn't own a TV and has a pre-smartphone era mobile phone.<ref name=":4" /> He is a fan of [[BBC Radio 4]], in particular ''[[Woman's Hour]]'' and [[The Afternoon Play (BBC)|''The Afternoon Play'']], listening while working on trucks or out in his van.<ref name=":2"/><ref name=":20"/> He is also a fan of the rock band [[The Stone Roses]], but has never seen them live.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/>
When living at home, his usual evening routine is to make and fix things in his shed until around 11pm.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> On Sunday mornings he prefers to ride his mountain bike.<ref name=":20"/>
Despite having presented a programme on [[Formula One]], Martin's interest in it extends only to the technology – he has no interest in the sport in general, in particular being dissuaded by its politics.<ref name=":18"/>
== Vehicles owned == Martin owns a 2013 [[Ford Transit]] van and a unique Volvo Vöx supercar.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://www.driving.co.uk/news/guy-martin-on-his-volvo-fastest-car-in-britain/|title=Guy Martin on his Volvo: the fastest car in Britain|website=Sunday Times Driving|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref> The van is for general transport while the Vöx is just for special occasions,<ref name=":11"/> however he does his daily commute to his truck job on his mountain bike.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> He has owned various [[Opel Astra|Vauxhall Astra vans]], until a bad example put him off the type.<ref name="driving.co.uk" /> He now swears by the reliability of the Transit,<ref name=":19"/> driving it around 40,000 miles a year.<ref name="About Guy"/>
He bought the Vöx in 2012 from [[Koenigsegg]] engineer Mattias Vöcks "for the price of a BMW M3", which he considers was a bargain for what it is – based on a 1967 [[Volvo Amazon]], it was upgraded and customised by Vöcks into an E85 biofuel powered 788 bhp vehicle, which Martin claims has reached 205 mph on a racetrack.<ref name=":11"/> The Vöx followed a string of high performance cars Martin bought for special occasions (only ever owning one at a time, and sometimes only owning his van).<ref name=":22" /> At age 21 he bought a [[BMW 3 Series (E46)|BMW E46]] M3 CSL,<ref name=":11"/> followed by a [[Porsche 911 GT3|Porsche GT3]] RS at age 24,<ref name="driving.co.uk" /> then a new [[BMW E92]] M3 V8,<ref name=":22" /> and lastly before the Vöx, a 2010 [[Aston Martin V12 Vantage]] bought new at age 28.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=http://www.evo.co.uk/aston-martin/v12-vantage/11773/guy-martin-and-his-aston-martin-v12-vantage|title=Guy Martin and his Aston Martin V12 Vantage|website=Evo|access-date=2016-04-10}}</ref> He found all to be a disappointment or unsuitable in one way or another, being particularly unimpressed with the Vantage, which had been his dream car, but which he found ostentatious, ultimately selling it cheaply,<ref name=":11"/><ref name=":19"/><ref name=":22" /> although he had not driven it in 2011 due to the insurance cost, as a result of his speeding points.<ref name=":20"/> He now deems supercars by marques such as Aston and Ferrari to be "fake" and for people who "don't know anything about cars".<ref name=":11"/>
He also owns a large collection of bicycles and motorcycles, including a [[Bimota]] which he stored in his kitchen.<ref name="About Guy"/> In bicycles, he has owned a [[Raleigh Chopper]], then a Raleigh Mustang, Falcon Fattrack, but describes his first proper bike as being a Whyte 46 bought in 2005, followed by an Orange 224, Scott Ransom 10, Alpine 160, finally settling on a Cotic, which has become his workhorse, requiring multiple parts replacements due to the wear and tear of constant use.<ref name=":20"/>
=== Speeding === By late 2011 he had accrued 21 penalty points on his standard [[Driving licence in the United Kingdom|UK driving licence]], having been caught speeding several times in his Transit van. He avoided a driving ban when on 18 points, being given another three in lieu of a ban, after the judge showed leniency due to the effect it would have on his livelihood, had he lost it.<ref name=":11"/><ref name=":20"/> After a period of "driving like a saint" he was expecting to have regained a clean record by April 2015.<ref name="driving.co.uk" />
Following claims made in his 7 April 2015 Sunday Times review of the Aston Martin Vanquish, in which he recounted testing the car on an early morning lap of the TT course, police opened an investigation. Driving almost the full length of the TT course (joining at Quarterbridge garage and finishing at Governor's Bridge), he said he was impressed at how fast it really was, reaching 180 mph down Sulby Straight and becoming airborne at Ballacrye corner, resulting in "something like a 22-minute lap".<ref name=":19"/> On 27 May police confirmed that after taking advice from the Attorney General's Chambers, they would be taking no further action, while reminding residents and visitors that "Where there is no upper speed limit, road users must at all times be aware that there is a fine line between what is fast and what is dangerous."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-isle-of-man-32897791|title=Guy Martin will face no police action over 180mph claim|website=BBC News|access-date=2016-04-08}}</ref> A few days later in a radio interview, Martin repeated the claims, and stated he had not broken the law as he had only reached high speeds on derestricted roads (i.e., those with no upper speed limit).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scunthorpetelegraph.co.uk/Isle-Man-TT-2015-Guy-Martin-confirms-driving/story-26641818-detail/story.html|title=Isle of Man TT 2015: Guy Martin confirms driving at up to 180mph in Aston Martin supercar but did not break the law|website=Scunthorpe Telegraph|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-04-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151108205436/http://www.scunthorpetelegraph.co.uk/Isle-Man-TT-2015-Guy-Martin-confirms-driving/story-26641818-detail/story.html|archive-date=8 November 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Motorcycle racing seasons== {{BLP sources section|date=July 2018}} {{Overly detailed|date=May 2016|section=yes}}
===Early years=== {{Expand section|date=July 2018}} A successful debut year on the roads that saw him win the Cock o' the North and [[International Gold Cup]] races at [[Oliver's Mount]], [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]] as well as the Irish 750cc Support Championship.
===2006 season=== The International road race meetings had mixed results: the [[North West 200]] never went particularly well, The [[Isle of Man TT]] looked promising but problems soon led to it being another disappointment. At the final international of the year, the [[Ulster Grand Prix]], he took 4 race wins and a 2nd making him the Man of the Meeting.
[[File:Guy Podium.JPG|thumb|right|Guy after winning the 2007 Ulster Grand Prix Supersport race]]
=== 2007 season === In the early season Martin took part in British Superbike and Supersport rounds to prepare for the road racing season. The first major international of the year was the [[North West 200]] in which he finished with an eighth, a fourth, two thirds and a second. In the CP Hire Superstock race after a bad start Martin finished third. The [[Isle of Man TT]] was the next major race on the calendar and he got a third, two seconds and a DNF after running out of fuel with fewer than three miles to go until his first pit stop. In the Senior race he just missed out on becoming only the second rider, at the time, to have lapped at more than 130 mph, his best lap falling short at 129.816 mph. Later video footage showed him run wide on the entry to Windy Corner and it was this mistake that led him to miss out on the magical 130 mph lap.
Martin continued to race on the English scene and he regained his Cock o' the North title at the Scarborough circuit before going to Ireland for the Kells Road Races in which he took one race win. This was preparation for the [[Ulster Grand Prix]] and in the first race Martin brought home a fifth position, in race two a win, and in the superbike race, which was shortened due to weather, a second. After this red flag the day's racing was cancelled due to bad weather and that meant for the second year in a row Martin was the Man of the Meeting. The Scarborough Gold Cup meeting ended with him winning all the races on the final day including the Gold Cup and the second 600 race of the day after a good battle with John McGuinness and Ian Lougher who were also both on the same Hondas as Martin.
=== 2008 season === As well as contesting a full season in the British Superbike Championship, in 2008 Martin again competed in the three International road races but was denied his first TT win when he broke down whilst comfortably leading the opening Superbike race. He was eleven seconds in the lead when an electrical problem forced him out on the fourth lap. He claimed a podium, third, in the Superstock race but suffered further retirements in the Senior and second Supersport races. In September 2008 it was back to Oliver's Mount for the International Gold Cup. Martin won the feature event and now has won 6 Gold Cups in a row, a new record, and also has the lap record for the 1000cc bikes at Scarborough with a time of 1:45.3.
=== 2009 season === In 2009 Martin contested all three Internationals as well as selected British Championship and Irish National races. In a move from previous seasons, Martin moved away from the main Hydrex team, preferring instead to run a smaller, close knit team and after a steady North West 200 meeting, confidence was high going into the TT, his number one event of the year, as he sought to win a race at the 37.73 mile circuit on the Isle of Man.
2009 was expected to be the year he broke the seal, but after claiming two seconds and a third on the Superstock, Superbike and Supersport bikes early in the week Martin's engine gave up after coming onto the pit lane in the 2nd 600 race. More grief was to come when putting the bike into gear at the end of his 2nd pit stop during the Senior race his chain snapped, meaning he ended up with another DNF.
Martin regrouped to claim the Southern 100 Championship on the Billown road course in July, after finishing second on no less than three occasions – 2005, 2006 and 2007 – before heading to the third International race of the season, the Ulster Grand Prix. After taking third in the Dundrod 150 Superbike race, Martin repeated the result in the feature UGP Superbike race, held over eight laps, but he ensured he would not be without an International win in 2009 when he won a thrilling second Superbike race, just over a tenth of a second in front of fellow Lincolnshire rider Gary Johnson. He also placed fourth and fifth in the equally close Superstock and Supersport races. At the 2009 Gold Cup at Oliver's Mount, Martin won the Steve Henshaw Gold Cup feature race, becoming the first rider to win seven consecutive meetings.
===2010 season=== [[File:Guy martin tt 2010.jpg|upright|thumbnail|right|Martin at the 2010 Isle of Man TT]] In 2010 he failed to take a podium at the [[2010 North West 200 Races|North West 200]], with his best result being fourth in the second Superbike race. He went to the [[2010 Isle of Man TT|Isle of Man TT]], looking to achieve his first TT victory. However, the meeting was dominated by [[Ian Hutchinson (motorcycle racer)|Ian Hutchinson]], who took a record-breaking five victories in all the solo races, and Martin suffered serious injuries in a major crash in the final race.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iomtt.com/en/News/2010/06/11/History-man-Hutchinson-makes-it-a-clean-sweep-at-the-2010-TT.aspx|title=History man Hutchinson makes it a clean sweep at the 2010 TT|date=2010-06-11|accessdate=2010-06-14|work=[[Isle of Man TT]]|publisher=ACU Events Ltd.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613232511/http://www.iomtt.com/en/News/2010/06/11/History-man-Hutchinson-makes-it-a-clean-sweep-at-the-2010-TT.aspx|archive-date=13 June 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Prior to that crash, during the Superbike race, Martin received a 30-second penalty for exceeding the posted pit lane speed limit of 60 km/h by just 0.112 km/h. Had he not received the penalty, his overall time would have been 1:46:48.05 and put him in 2nd place, behind [[Ian Hutchinson (motorcycle racer)|Ian Hutchinson]] who finished with a time of 1:46:31.82.
His performance at the TT was criticised by [[1989 Nations motorcycle Grand Prix#500 cc classification|Simon Buckmaster]], whose Performance Technical Racing built the bikes which Martin was running. He accused Martin of not listening to his race advice, arguing "He needs to stop being distracted and lift his professionalism. Instead of being a TV star and courting publicity 24x7, he should be concentrating on racing and what's needed to win. Get his focus and concentration into racing, not promoting his name and money-spinning deals." He also cited disrespectful behavior during the race and bad language and criticism directed toward a member of PTR in a magazine interview.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.crash.net/road+racing/news/160828/1/buckmaster_launches_scathing_attack_on_martin.html|title=Buckmaster launches scathing attack on Martin|work=crash.net|publisher=Crash Media Group|date=2010-06-21|accessdate=2010-06-22}}</ref> Martin received considerable public support over both the nature and timing of Buckmaster's comments, coming as Martin was still recovering from the crash, but in a subsequent interview Buckmaster defended what he had said, arguing he was not slating him and stating Martin had no issue with the comments.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.crash.net/road+racing/news/161331/1/buckmaster_tells_fans_to_get_courage_or_shut_up.html|title=Buckmaster tells fans to get courage or shut up|work=crash.net|publisher=Crash Media Group|date=2010-07-07|accessdate=2010-07-07}}</ref>
==== 2010 TT crash ==== In the final race, the [[Senior TT]], Martin was a challenger to stop Hutchinson achieving the clean sweep, but was involved in an incident on the third lap of the race at Ballagarey, having led the race just before the first pit stop.<ref name="Martin">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/8735624.stm|title=Ian Hutchinson clinches five-timer at Isle of Man TT|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=BBC|date=2010-06-11|accessdate=2010-06-11}}</ref>
Recollecting the crash in 2012, Martin recounted how he has been pushing too hard going into the corner at 160-170 mph, having willingly crossed the line [which if you push beyond you might crash] in order to win. He recalled being thrown from the bike and accepting he was not going to survive the approaching high speed impact with a wall, attributing it to luck that he hit it at the right angle to get away with it.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9614490/How-Britain-Worked-Channel-4-Preview.html|title=How Britain Worked, Channel 4, Preview|website=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-04-06}}</ref>
Airlifted to Noble's Hospital in [[Douglas, Isle of Man|Douglas]] with chest injuries, he was later diagnosed as suffering bruising to both lungs and minor fractures to his upper spine.<ref name="Martin" />
====2011 Ulster GP==== A superbike race 2 win at the Ulster Grand Prix followed for Martin after his consistent TT. He finished second in the opening superbike race behind Bruce Anstey on the Padgetts racing Honda Fireblade.
===2012 season=== [[File:2013 Isle of Man TT 5.jpg|upright|thumbnail|right|Martin at the 2013 Isle of Man TT]] Martin made his first 2012 appearance at the [[Cookstown|Cookstown 100]] meeting in preparation for the [[North West 200]] and [[Isle of Man TT]]. Martin brought his race season to a close winning five races at Scarborough's Oliver Mount Gold Cup. He also took part in the [[Ryan Farquhar]] Parade lap on one of Ryan's own KMR Kawasaki's.
====2012 North West 200==== Following on from the Cookstown meeting, Martin was set to campaign in all the main races at the North West 200, as a prelude to working up for the [[Isle of Man TT]]. However, during the [[Super sport (motorcycle)|Supersport]] race he crashed. As a consequence, he was left with a suspected head injury, which resulted in his team manager, Philip Neill, withdrawing Martin from the remainder of the racing programme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://2wheeltuesday.com/2012/05/guy-martins-north-west-200-crash/ |title=Guy Martin's North West 200 Crash |publisher=2WheelTuesday |date=2012-05-21 |accessdate=2012-10-21}}</ref>
This led to rumours of a 'bust-up' with the Suzuki Team, and resulted in Martin's team boss, Hector Neill, being interviewed on [[Manx Radio|Manx Radio TT 365]] prior to the TT, during which Neill scotched such rumours as; ''"Media inspired skulduggery. Paddock tittle-tattle and unfounded hear-say"''.<ref>http://www.Manxradiott365.com/RadioTT{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} News, Monday, 28 May 2012.</ref>
====2012 TT==== Martin's start to the 2012 TT Festival saw him competing – in a private capacity – at the Pre-TT Classic races at the [[Billown Circuit]], [[Castletown, Isle of Man|Castletown]]. Martin was lucky to escape injury while competing in the superbike race, and was battling for the lead of the race on a Suzuki XR69 with Jamie Coward, when he crashed on the final lap. This again led to reports of tension, as the Pre-TT races do not form any part of the main TT racing programme, and posed a potential injury risk to Martin before the TT had begun in earnest. During the practice week for the 2012 Isle of Man TT, Martin made steady progress – albeit amid rumours of differing opinions with his team's management regarding machinery set-up and the team's choice of [[Pirelli]] tyres.
Martin made a good start to the Superbike TT, and at the end of the first lap he was lying in third place behind [[John McGuinness (motorcycle racer)|John McGuinness]] and [[Cameron Donald]]. He continued to hold station during the following three laps, but a problem during his final pit stop at the end of lap four, resulted in the team being unable to replace his rear tyre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/sport/isleofmantt/ |title=Isle of Man TT | ITV Sport |publisher=Itv.com |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2012-10-21}}</ref> As a consequence of diminishing grip from a fading tyre, Martin was overtaken on corrected time by [[Bruce Anstey]] by the end of lap five, although he did hold on to finish fourth with a time of 1hr.47.20 at an average speed of 126.54 mph.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cdn.iomtt.com/~/media/Files/2012/Results/020612/Superbike/Superbike%20-%20Lap%20by%20lap%20-%202.6.ashx |title=Isle of Man TT Races Fuelled by Monster Energy: Positions at the end of Lap One |publisher=Iomtt.com |accessdate=2012-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026032605/http://cdn.iomtt.com/~/media/Files/2012/Results/020612/Superbike/Superbike%20-%20Lap%20by%20lap%20-%202.6.ashx |archivedate=26 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> This was followed by fifth place in the [[Superstock TT|Superstock]] race, a retirement in the first [[Super sport (motorcycle)|Supersport]] race and 8th place in the second Supersport outing.<ref name="iomtt.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.iomtt.com/TT-2012/2012-TT-Results.aspx|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614100327/http://www.iomtt.com/TT-2012/2012-TT-Results.aspx|archivedate=14 June 2012|deadurl=yes|title=2012 TT Results}}</ref>
Rumours continued to circulate throughout the week about Martin's differences with his team, perhaps instigated by Martin's lateness of signing a contract at the start of the season, although as practice week went on, it was obvious the rumours regarding Martin's split from his team were untrue. The Senior race was scheduled to take place on its traditional Friday – 8 June. However, following adverse weather, the race was postponed until Saturday, 9 June. As a consequence of continued poor weather, the decision to cancel the Senior TT was taken. This was the first time in the race's 105-year history that the Senior had been cancelled due to weather.
=== 2013 season ===
[[File:Guy Martin TT 2013 02.jpg|thumb|Martin at the [[2013 Isle of Man TT]]]]
====2013 Ulster Grand Prix====
Since first competing in 2004, Martin has notched up 11 wins including a hat trick of victories at the 2013 meeting winning the Supersport 1, UGP Superbike and Superbike categories.
===2015 season=== Martin joined his teammates in early March, 2015, for pre-season testing. This initially took the form of a four-day test programme at Cartagena and following this the squad deployed to the BMW Motorrad test camp at Almeria in Spain for the next three days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tycobmw.com/almeria-next-up-after-positive-test-at-cartagena-for-tyco-bmw/|title=Almeria next up after positive test for TYCO BMW at Cartagena|work=tycobmw.com}}</ref>
====2015 early season====
Martin opened his 2015 season at the [[Oliver's Mount|Oliver's Mount Circuit]] on Saturday 11 April,<ref name="tycobmw.com">{{cite web|url=http://tycobmw.com/spring-cup-victory-for-martin-tyco-bmw/|title=SPRING CUP VICTORY FOR MARTIN & TYCO BMW|work=tycobmw.com}}</ref> at which he recorded a maiden victory on his [[BMW S1000RR]] [[Superstock TT|Superstock]] at the Scarborough venue.<ref name="tycobmw.com" /> Finishing fourth the following day in treacherous conditions, Martin went on to lift the main prize of the meeting, the Spring Cup.<ref name="tycobmw.com" />
Following their success at Scarborough, the Tyco Team headed to the opening event in the Irish Racing Calendar, the [[Cookstown 100]]. Martin continued his fine early season form by winning the opening Royal Hotel Superbike Race, and then sealing a brace of superbike wins at the feature race, the KDM Cookstown 100, again accomplished on [[Superstock TT|Superstock machinery]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tycobmw.com/764/|title=COOKSTOWN 100 DOUBLE FOR GUY MARTIN & TYCO BMW|work=tycobmw.com}}</ref>
====2015 Northwest 200====
Martin was introduced to his factory [[BMW S1000RR]] [[Superbike]] during a day's testing at [[RAF Kirkistown#Current use|Kirkistown]] on 7 May, in preparation for the team's campaign at the [[Vauxhall Motors|Vauxhall]] [[North West 200|International North West 200]] for the opening practice session on 12 May. Martin's arrival at the triangle circuit generated the usual media interest, however the attention continued following some controversial comments concerning the circuit by Martin. On return from a practice lap on his Supersport machine, Martin was briefly interviewed by [[BBC Sport#Motorcycling|BBC Sport]] presenter Stephen Watson.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/northern-ireland/32756049|title=BBC Sport - North West 200: Chicanes a pain says frustrated Guy Martin|work=BBC Sport}}</ref> Struggling to qualify, Martin said he was "bored" riding the course, citing the number of [[chicanes]] which had been introduced in an effort to improve safety.<ref name="bbc.co.uk" /> As on previous occasions this resulted in Martin's team boss, Hector Neill, again having to rally to his rider's defence. Interviewed by the [[BBC Sport#Motorcycling|BBC]] and other assorted media Neill downplayed the comments, merely alluding to the fact that Martin was becoming concerned that the course was starting to resemble more a purpose-built racing track as opposed to a pure road circuit.<ref name="bbc.co.uk" /> This brought reaction from various commentators and competitors, with [[Philip McCallen]] questioning Martin's commitment to the sport as well as his indiscreet criticism of the course.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/motor-sport/northwest-200/north-west-200-guy-martin-should-question-himself-not-the-track-says-phillip-mccallen-31223820.html|title=North West 200: Guy Martin should question himself, not the track, says Phillip McCallen|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk}}</ref>
In a further interview with [[BBC Sport#Motorcycling|BBC Sport]], again conducted by Watson and with event director Mervyn Whyte in attendance,<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/northern-ireland/32763195|title=BBC Sport - Guy Martin explains his North West 200 chicanery|work=BBC Sport}}</ref> Martin apologized for his comments and whilst he was supportive of the event, describing it as a "''mega event,''" he continued that he was not too stuck on the circuit, and that he simply didn't like chicanes.<ref name="ReferenceB" /> Watson drew Martin's attention to the fact that the comments by this time had been seen by over 300,000 people on [[Facebook]]. Martin made light of the situation, stating that he was "''caught in the heat of the moment, and simply let rip.''"<ref name="ReferenceB" /> He then questioned why he was generating such attention for his comments, when the main attention should not have been directed towards him but rather directed towards the racing, and to the fact that [[Alastair Seeley]] had qualified on [[pole position]] and had subsequently gone on to win the opening race.<ref name="ReferenceB" />
The 2015 [[Vauxhall Motors|Vauxhall]] [[North West 200|International North West 200]] was blighted by a series of incidents resulting in races being red flagged.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/northern-ireland/32769194|title=BBC Sport - Seeley matches Dunlop's NW 200 record after two more wins|work=BBC Sport}}</ref> Martin did not make an impression in any of the races, and failed to finish in the top six.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
====2015 TT==== Martin's 2015 [[Isle of Man TT]] provided mixed results. Opening his account with a retirement in the [[Superbike|Superbike Race]], he followed this up by taking a respectable 5th place astride the [[Triumph Daytona 600|Smiths Triumph]] in the opening Supersport TT.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|url=http://www.iomtt.com/TT-Database/Events/Races.aspx?meet_code=ALL&ride_id=8430|title=Race Results: Guy Martin, Isle of Man TT official website|work=iomtt.com}}</ref> Switching back to his [[BMW S1000RR]] [[Superstock TT|Superstock]] machine, Martin came home in 7th place in the [[Superstock TT]].<ref name="ReferenceC" /> Brought in as a late replacement for the injured [[William Dunlop (motorcycle racer)|William Dunlop]] in the [[TT Zero]] Race, and with negligible practice time, Martin took his electrically powered Victory Racing machine to 4th place in his first participation in the class.<ref name="ReferenceC" /> He then secured his only podium place of the meeting, again on board the [[Triumph Daytona 600|Smiths Triumph Daytona]], when he claimed 3rd place in the second Supersport outing.<ref name="ReferenceC" /> Martin rounded off his 2015 campaign when he took the factory [[BMW S1000RR]] [[Superbike]] to 4th place in the [[Senior TT]] with an average race speed of 129.602 mph, but with a fastest lap average of 132.398 mph, a personal best for Martin and just two seconds slower than race winner and outright lap record holder [[John McGuinness (motorcycle racer)|John McGuinness]].<ref name="ReferenceC" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iomtt.com/News/2015/June/16/Guy-Martin-joins-132-club.aspx|title=Guy Martin joins 132mph club|work=iomtt.com}}</ref>
==== 2015 Southern 100 ==== [[File:Guy Martin & Dan Kneen.jpg|thumb|left|Guy Martin leads Dan Kneen and [[Michael Dunlop]] into Church Bends during the 2015 Diamond Jubilee [[Southern 100]]]]Martin arrived back on the [[Isle of Man]] in July in order to compete in the [[Southern 100|Southern 100 Races]] which were celebrating their [[Diamond Jubilee]]. Poor weather initially hampered the racing programme with the Corlett's Trophies 1000/600cc race red flagged in wet conditions.<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32">''Isle of Man Examiner'' p.32 July 14–20, 2015</ref> The race was re-run two days later, with Dan Kneen taking the lead for the opening two laps. However, Martin edged him out, taking the lead on lap 3 and thereafter dicing for the lead with Kneen and [[Michael Dunlop]].<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32" /> Leading at Stadium Corner on the final circuit, Martin looked favourite to take the honours. However, getting maximum drive out of the final corner, Dunlop snatched victory at the line by 0.087 seconds.<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32" />
Martin then began to take hold of the meeting. Onboard his [[BMW S1000RR]] Martin took to the grid for the finale to the event, the Southern 100 Solo Championship.<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32" /> Pushed hard during the 9 lap race by Dan Kneen, Martin led the pack by the end of the opening lap and continued to hold station at the end of lap 2. Lap 3 saw Martin maintain his lead, however [[Michael Dunlop|Dunlop]] low sided at [[Ballabeg|Ballabeg Hairpin]] putting him out of the race.<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32" /> The ensuing melee enabled Martin and Kneen to break free from the chasing pack and their two-way battle ensued into the following lap.<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32" /> As the race went into the final two laps, the rear echelon of the field started to have an effect on the front running riders, with Kneen being held up in an overtaking manoeuvre at [[Billown Circuit|Iron Gate]].<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32" /> This enabled Martin to stay clear on the final circuit taking the Southern 100 title for the third year in succession.<ref name="Man Examiner' p.32" /> [[File:Guy Martin at Church Bends.jpg|thumb|right|Martin at Church Bends during the 2015 [[Southern 100]].]] Following his victory, Guy Martin joined the late [[Joey Dunlop]] as the only riders to have won the Southern 100 Solo Championship Race for three years in succession.
==== 2015 Ulster GP crash ==== Martin crashed at high speed when leading the 2015 Dundrod 150 Superbike race (part of the Ulster GP) in August. On the final lap, being pursued by [[Bruce Anstey]], he left the course at Ireland's Corner, fracturing thoracic vertebrae, his sternum and a number of ribs and his throttle hand, requiring steel rods to be inserted into his back and a pin in his hand. He signed himself out of hospital four days later.<ref name=":8" />
Having no memory of the incident, being shown footage of the crash for the first time (as depicted on ''Guy Martin's Wall of Death: Live)'' confirmed his suspicion that he had been pushing hard for a perfect corner, due to the pressure from Anstey. He stated that while he had accidents that looked worse, this was the one that caused the most damage. The programme also detailed his recovery period at home, revealing his ice bath treatments in an outdoor pool to relieve the pain, which was affecting his sleep.
===2016 season=== In January 2016 Martin confirmed he would not be racing the 2016 Isle of Man TT as it clashed with a mountain bike race he wanted to compete in, and he would also not be racing the prior North West 200 due to the mountain bike training.<ref name=":17" />
It was hoped that Martin would be participating at the [[Southern 100]] motorcycle races, defending his solo title and increasing the event's profile. However following his participation in the [[Tour Divide]] it was subsequently announced that Martin would not be competing at the Southern 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energyfm.net/cms/news_story_436595.html|title=Guy Martin pulls out of Southern 100|publisher=}}</ref>
===2017 season=== It was uncertain whether Martin would retire from racing or return for the 2017 season, but it was announced on 18 January that he had signed for the Honda Racing, based in [[Louth, Lincolnshire]], and would compete alongside teammate [[John McGuinness (motorcycle racer)|John McGuinness]] at various national and international meetings including the [[North West 200]] and [[Isle of Man TT Races]].<ref name="itv.com"/>
In addition, it was confirmed on 20 March that Martin would compete at the 2017 [[Tandragee#Sport|Tandragee 100]] and the [[Cookstown 100]] events.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/northern-ireland/39326947|title=Guy Martin to return to Cookstown 100 and Tandragee 100 road races in April|date=20 March 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
====Tandragee 100==== Martin's first competitive appearance since 2015 was his debut for Honda at the [[Tandragee#Sport|Tandragee 100]] on 22 April, riding the new [[Honda CBR1000RR#2017 redesign|Honda Fireblade]] [[European Superstock 1000 Championship#Regulations|Superstock-class]] machine. During the first lap of the Open [[Superbike]] race, Martin was involved in a collision with another rider at Marlacoo corner. Both were unhurt, but retired from the race.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/northern-ireland/39679491|title=Guy Martin escapes injury as he crashes out of opening race at Tandragee 100|date=22 April 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/utv/2017-04-22/guy-martin-crashes-out-of-tandragee-comeback-race/|title=Guy Martin crashes out of Tandragee comeback race|publisher=}}</ref> Due to an incident involving an Italian rider and poor weather conditions, the rest of the meeting was cancelled.
====Spring Cup==== After the Tandragee races, Martin travelled overnight to make the start at [[Oliver's Mount]] for the annual Spring Cup races. Although he had been successful previously at the Scarborough circuit, this low key appearance was more about gaining race-time on the new Honda.
====Cookstown 100==== Martin's next outing of the season was on the [[European Superstock 1000 Championship#Regulations|Superstock]] Fireblade SP2 at the [[Cookstown|Cookstown 100]], additionally riding for the Wilson Craig Team in the [[Sport bike#Classes|Supersport]] class.<ref name="newsletter.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/sport/motorcycling/cookstown-100-william-dunlop-edges-supersport-thriller-1-7939162|title=Cookstown 100: William Dunlop edges Supersport thriller|publisher=}}</ref> After practice, Martin was qualified fifth fastest in the [[Sport bike#Classes|Supersport]], but failed to start in the race. Martin took the big Honda to fifth place in the first [[Superbike|Superbike Race]], however he again failed to start in the second race.<ref name="newsletter.co.uk"/>
====North West 200==== As at the Cookstown 100, it was confirmed Martin would ride for both the factory-supported Honda team, and in the Supersport 600 cc class for the Wilson Craig Team. Interviewed by [[BBC Sport#Motorcycling|''BBC Sport'']] ,<ref name="bbc.co.uk1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/northern-ireland/39505596|title=North West 200 practice|date=2 May 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> Martin was in upbeat mood, saying he hadn't pushed the machine too hard, and was quite happy with a "steady ride round." Martin's criticism of the course in regard to the chicanes was mentioned.<ref name="bbc.co.uk1"/> When queried on a previous statement made after the 2015 meeting that he would not return to the triangle circuit, Martin commented that the primary reason was to get the necessary race-time to enter the [[Isle of Man TT Races]]. He also confirmed that he enjoyed riding at the Northwest 200 and that he had development work to do with the new Honda.<ref name="bbc.co.uk1"/> When queried why he did not renew his association with the Irish Tyco BMW Team, Martin stated that after the 2015 accident, he had decided to retire from racing but still had respect for Tyco BMW, concluding during the [[Tour Divide]] cycle race that he no longer had passion for racing.<ref name="bbc.co.uk1"/> A reason Martin gave for signing for Honda, was that he could fulfill an ambition, as Honda had promised him he could race a vintage [[Honda RC181]].<ref name="bbc.co.uk1"/>
Practice produced mixed results for Martin. Following an accident in practice injuring teammate [[John McGuinness (motorcycle racer)|John McGuinness]] at Primrose Hill on 11 May, a decision was made by Honda Racing to withdraw Martin from that evening's Superstock race. Honda Racing, after further appraisal of the incident involving McGuinness, also withdrew from the remaining events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motorcyclenews.com/sport/tt-road-races/2017/may/tt-honda-in-crisis-after-mcguinness-crash/|title=TT: Honda in crisis after McGuinness crash|publisher=}}</ref>
On the Wilson Craig Honda 600 Martin qualified 16th fastest during first practice for the Supersport race, recording a fastest lap of 109.614 mph,<ref name="northwest200.org">http://www.northwest200.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/northwest2017_secondsupersport.pdf</ref> slipping to 27th fastest in the second qualifying period,<ref name="northwest200.org"/> which led to Martin starting the race from the ninth row on the grid, bringing his machine home in 23rd place.<ref>http://www.northwest200.org/2017-results/</ref>
====Isle of Man TT==== Following the North West 200 incident involving John McGuinness riding the new [[Honda CBR1000RR|Honda SP2]], tests were carried out by the Honda Racing Team prior to the bike arriving at the TT races. The 2017 Isle of Man TT qualifying week was disrupted by poor weather and Martin had little track time. The weather improved towards the end of the week, enabling a full practice session to take place on Friday 2 June. Due to of the lack of practice, the first race day was postponed with the time allotted to additional practice. On 3 June, in ideal conditions, Martin completed four practice laps recording the 26th fastest time, around the road course of {{convert|37.73|mi|km}} in a time of 18 minutes 11.69 seconds at an average speed of {{convert|124.403|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}}.
The opening race, the Superbike TT, was rescheduled for Sunday 4 June but Martin only got 8 miles into the race before he crashed at [[Doran's Bend]].<ref name="bikesportnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.bikesportnews.com/news/news-detail/tt-2017-bruised-wrist-for-martin-after-superbike-crash|title=TT 2017: Bruised wrist for Martin after Superbike crash|first=Road racing|last=desk|website=Bikesport News}}</ref> In an interview afterwards, Martin stated that as he attempted to change down the gearbox after [[Ballig|Ballig Bridge]] in order to negotiate the 4th gear left handed [[Doran's Bend]], he hit a ''false neutral''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motorcyclenews.com/sport/tt-road-races/2017/june/tt-2017-tough-start-for-honda-and-guy-martin/|title=TT 2017: Tough start for Honda and Guy Martin|publisher=}}</ref> Martin was unable to offer an opinion as to whether the bike would be safe to ride in the [[Senior TT]], merely describing the [[Honda CBR1000RR|SP2]] as a ''"[[Jonah]]"''.{{clarify|date=November 2017}} Despite crashing at around {{convert|135|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}}, Martin only sustained a bruised wrist.<ref name="bikesportnews.com"/> Following his spill in the opening race, Martin also failed to start in both the Supersport race and the Superstock event.
====Southern 100==== At the start of the season Martin confirmed his intention to compete at the 2017 [[Southern 100]] races on the Isle of Man. However following the problems with the Honda CBR1000RR SP2 at the TT races, Martin decided not to participate at the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/sport/other-sport/guy-martin-miss-southern-100-164732|title=No Southern comfort for Guy!|date=4 July 2017|publisher=|via=www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk}}</ref>
====Ulster Grand Prix==== On 21 July 2017, Honda Racing, an English company based in [[Louth, Lincolnshire|Louth]], [[Lincolnshire]] also known as ''Honda Racing CBR'',<ref>[http://www.hondaracingcbr.com/calendar/ Honda Racing, calendar 2017] Retrieved 29 August 2017</ref><ref>[http://business-directory.autosport.com/company/2586/honda-racing?cid=166 Honda Racing at Autosport Directory] Retrieved 29 August 2017</ref> issued a statement to the effect that Guy Martin would not be competing at the 2017 [[Ulster Grand Prix]]; the decision was described by an event organiser as "''Naturally I'm disappointed...but it's not altogether surprising given the difficulties the team has experienced throughout the season''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visordown.com/motorcycle-racing-news-road-racing/guy-martin-out-ulster-grand-prix|title=Guy Martin out of Ulster Grand Prix|publisher=}}</ref>
==Retirement from motorcycle racing== On 26 July 2017, it was officially announced that Guy Martin had retired from motorcycle racing. In an exclusive interview with the ''[[Motorcycle News]]'' Martin said:
{{cquote|Racing's been good to me, but I'm bored of it. You spend the early part of the year preparing for the season – testing, racing, talking about it, and then doing it all over again. It's like Groundhog Day. It's time to stop.''<ref>[https://www.motorcyclenews.com/sport/tt-road-races/2017/july/roads-guy-martin-calls-time-on-road-racing/ Exclusive: Guy Martin calls time on road racing]. ''Motor Cycle News''. Authors - Oli Rushby and Matt Wildee. Published 26 July 2017. Retrieved 30 July 2018.</ref>}}

==Mountain bike racing and Pedal cars== Martin has successfully raced [[mountain bike]]s in cross country, downhill races and endurance races. In June 2011, after two years of training, he raced in the [[Salzkammergut]] Trophy in Austria. With a time of 14 hours 40 minutes, he was the first British non-professional rider to finish.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-262200804.html|title=Relentless Suzuki by TAS Racing's Guy Martin left his leathers at home last weekend to tackle the toughest one-day Mountain Bike race in the world: the Salzkammergut Trophy in Austria.|website=www.highbeam.com|publisher=Sunday Life (Belfast, Northern Ireland)|access-date=2016-04-09}}</ref> He achieved his goal of a podium-finish during a 2013 British Championship event in [[Fort William, Highland|Fort William]], Scotland.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YCCrCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA167&lpg=PA167&dq=2013+championship+mountain+bike+cross+country+guy+martin#v=onepage&q=2013%20championship%20mountain%20bike%20cross%20country%20guy%20martin Guy Martin:My Autobiography] p.167, at Google books. Retrieved 21 November 2017</ref><ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/>
He placed second in the male solo rider category at the [[Strathpuffer]] 24-hour mountain bike race (held at [[Strathpeffer]], Scotland) in both 2014 and 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://singletrackworld.com/2016/01/12-days-of-christmas-day-11-the-king-and-the-joker/ |title=The King And The Joker – Guy Martin And Jason Miles | publisher=[[Singletrack (magazine)|Singletrack]] |date=5 January 2016 |accessdate=8 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ross-shirejournal.co.uk/Sport/Other-Sport/Snow-ice-blue-skies-and-darkness-make-for-the-perfect-Puffer-at-Strath-23012015.htm |title=Snow, ice, blue skies - and darkness - make for the perfect Puffer at Strath |first=John |last=Macleod |work=Ross-shire Journal |date=23 January 2015 |accessdate=8 April 2018}}</ref> [[File:Guy martin at Shenington.jpg|thumb|right|Martin racing an Apollo pedal car at Shenington]]
Martin achieved an ambition and competed in the 2016 [[Tour Divide]] mountain bike race, which runs from [[Banff, Alberta|Banff]], Canada to [[Antelope Wells, New Mexico|Antelope Wells]], [[New Mexico]], negotiating the [[Rocky Mountains]], beginning on June 11.<ref name=":17" /> He completed the course, taking 18 days, six hours and 23 minutes, with an average of 150 miles a day.<ref>[http://www.motorcyclenews.com/news/2016/july/guy-martin-finishes-worlds-toughest-mountain-bike-race/ Guy Martin finishes world’s toughest mountain bike race] ''[[Motorcycle News]]'', 1 July 2017. Retrieved 21 November 2017</ref>
Martin also competed as part of a [[Pedal Car Racing]] team in the 24-hour, 2015 British Pedal Car Championship event at the [[Shenington#RAF Edgehill|Shenington Kart circuit]] on 27/28 June, as part of the Team JMC/Hope Factory Racing Team.

=== Engineering ===
====''The Boat that Guy Built''==== This six-part series sees Martin renovates a narrow boat, called ''Reckless'', travelling on the canal network using the inventions of the [[Industrial Revolution]]. The programme includes reconstructions of early industrial processes such as smelting iron.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.historyextra.com/tv-and-radio/boat-guy-built|title=The Boat that Guy Built|publisher=BBC History Magazine|accessdate=2010-02-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924031546/http://www.historyextra.com/tv-and-radio/boat-guy-built|archive-date=24 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====''How Britain Worked''==== <!-- [[How Britain Worked]] links here --> This six-part series examined some of the important engineering advances at the time of the [[Industrial Revolution]]. Feeling the country had lost its reputation as the workshop of the world and "went soft" under the auspices of health and safety culture, through replicating original working methods in various practical projects, the series was to highlight the ordinary workers who were experiencing long hours while working to remarkable precision, "within a couple of thousandths of an inch".<ref name=":15"/>
===== Episode list ===== Source for episode titles and broadcast dates:<ref name=":12"/> {| class="wikitable" !Episode !Title !Original broadcast |- |1 |Severn Valley Railway |21 October 2012 |- |2 |Yorkshire Saw Mill |28 October 2012 |- |3 |Victorian Seaside Resort |4 November 2012 |- |4 |Newcomen Beam Engine |13 November 2012 |- |5 |Brixham Sailing Trawler |18 November 2012 |- |6 |Birmingham Botanical Gardens |25 November 2012 |}
===== Severn Valley Railway ===== In this episode, Martin helps to overhaul and later drives a steam locomotive on the [[Severn Valley Railway]], Shropshire, in the process working on its boiler, safety valves and a wheel. Using Victorian methods, he also lays some track, forges a coal shovel out of wrought iron, and repairs a 100-year-old train driver's pocket watch.
===== Yorkshire Saw Mill ===== In this episode, Martin helps to repair the world's oldest surviving [[water turbine]] used to power [[Gayle Mill, North Yorkshire|Gayle Mill]], a saw mill in Wensleydale, North Yorkshire. Felling a tree by hand, he transports the lumber to the mill by steam [[traction engine]], to build a replica of the first pedal-powered bicycles. Also covered is the migration of farm workers to city factories, displaced by mechanisation.
===== Victorian Seaside Resort ===== In this episode, Martin helps with winter maintenance on attractions in the Welsh resort of [[Llandudno]], working on [[Llandudno Pier|the pier]], a [[Helter skelter (ride)|helter-skelter]] ride, and the [[Great Orme Tramway]]. He also participates in a promenade concert, and covers the Victorian craze of [[sea bathing]].
===== Newcomen Beam Engine ===== In this episode, Martin helps to restore the [[Newcomen atmospheric engine|Newcomen beam engine]] in the [[Black Country Living Museum]], including making [[fire brick]]<nowiki/>s using the original methods, restoring the timber frame, renovate the mechanical parts and clean the boiler. Covering Victorian mining methods Martin goes down the museum's mine shaft.
===== Brixham Sailing Trawler ===== In this episode, Martin helps to restore the oldest surviving [[Brixham trawler|Brixham sailing trawler]], using traditional carpentry and rope making techniques (on rope making machines used for [[HMS Victory]]), as well as testing a self-made period life jacket. Examining the growth in popularity for [[fish and chips]], he takes a trip on a deep sea [[Fishing trawler|trawler]].
===== Birmingham Botanical Gardens ===== In this episode, Martin helps to restore [[Birmingham Botanical Gardens]], learning the Victorian method for [[glassblowing]] for the greenhouse panes, rebuilding the very first lawnmower, and for building a rockery. He covers the engineering behind the Victorian fashion for collecting plants from around the world, to be shown off in extravagant botanical gardens.
==== ''Guy Martin's Spitfire'' ==== Guy Martin joins the two-year build sequence of a replica [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire I]], N3200, coded 'QV', that was buried in a French beach for 46 years (1940–1986), and tells the [[Boy's Own]]-style story of its pilot, [[Geoffrey D. Stephenson|Squadron Leader Geoffrey Stephenson]]. Saltwater corrosion ensured very little (if anything) was safely usable on a flying replica.
====''Guy Martin: Last Flight of the Vulcan Bomber''==== In this feature length one off special, Martin follows the final flights of the Cold War era [[Avro Vulcan]] Delta winged jet bomber [[Avro Vulcan XH558|XH558 ''Spirit of Great Britain'']]. Having been restored to flight in 2007 by a charitable trust, it had been the last flying Vulcan, performing displays every year, until it was decided 2015 would be its last season due to its age and associated insurmountable engineering issues. Its last flight occurred on 28 October 2015. Martin joins the team with four months left, and once certified by the team's chief engineer, is permitted to assist in preparing it for a 1,000 mile farewell tour, as it is jacked up for a vertical alignment test. Examining the design and history, he also meets former Vulcan pilots and the [[Red Arrows]], who display with the aircraft, and aerial footage tracks it on the tours. Since in-flight cockpit access is only granted to Vulcan crew, he also flies alongside it in a formation with other aircraft. He also takes the controls of one of the other surviving Vulcans in taxiable condition, for a fast taxi manoeuvre (ground run to the point of nose lift).
=== Racing and speed ===
==== ''TT3D: Closer to the Edge'' ==== {{Main|TT3D: Closer to the Edge}} ''[[TT3D: Closer to the Edge]]'' is a documentary film about the Isle of Man TT races. The film examines what motivates the riders who race the TT and risk everything to become "King of the Mountain". Filmed in 3D, the film is a story about freedom of choice and the strength of human spirit. The film follows the leading riders in the 2010 race meeting, in particular Martin and [[Ian Hutchinson (motorcycle racer)|Ian Hutchinson]].
====''Speed with Guy Martin''==== {{Main|Speed with Guy Martin}} In this series, Martin attempts various challenges based on speed using a variety of vehicles, mostly featuring record attempts. Three series of four hour-long episode were broadcast, along with three special episodes. This was despite Martin's reluctance to film a thord series, saying that he would prefer to "move on while we are ahead", continuing with a few one off specials.<ref name=":92" />
===== Episode list ===== Source for episode titles and broadcast dates:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/speed-with-guy-martin|title=Speed with Guy Martin|website=Channel 4|access-date=23 October 2018}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" !Series !No. !Episode !Vehicle !Original broadcast |- | rowspan="4" |1 |1 |Britain's Fastest Cyclist |bicycle |29 December 2013 |- |2 |Hydroplaning Bike |motorcycle |5 January 2014 |- |3 |Human Powered Aircraft |aircraft |12 January 2014 |- |4 |World's Fastest Toboggan |gravity powered sled |19 January 2014 |- | rowspan="4" |2 |1 |Tandem |bicycle (tandem) |29 October 2014 |- |2 |Pike's Peak |motorcycle |2 November 2014 |- |3 |Hovercraft |hovercraft |9 November 2014 |- |4 |Gravity Racer |soapbox |16 November 2014 |- | colspan="2" |specials |F1 Special |motorcycle (against [[Red Bull RB8]] [[Formula One car]]) |17 March 2016 |- | rowspan="4" |3 |1 |Transit Van |[[Ford Transit#Fourth generation (2000–2014)|Transit van]] |4 September 2016 |- |2 |Pedal Power Airship |airship |25 September 2016 |- |3 |World's Fastest Human-Powered Boat |boat |2 October 2016 |- |4 |World's Fastest Motorbike |motorbike |9 October 2016 |- | colspan="2" |specials |F1 Challenge |pit crew at [[2017 Belgian Grand Prix]] |17 September 2017 |- | colspan="2" |specials |Classic F1 Special |[[Williams FW08C]], [[Williams FW08B]] |27 August 2018 |}
==== ''Guy Martin's Wall of Death: Live'' ==== In this live special, Martin attempted to set a world speed record on a purpose built version of the [[wall of death]] fairground attraction.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/27/guy-martin-wall-of-death-world-speed-record|title=Guy Martin attempts to beat wall of death speed record on live TV|last=Thorpe|first=Vanessa|date=2016-03-26|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-04-02}}</ref> It also featured recordings of Martin being trained by experienced rider Ken Fox on an existing wall to overcome dizziness, and being given aerial training to overcome the chief limiting factor, the effect of [[G-force]] on the human body. The science was explored by Hugh Hunt of Cambridge University, revealing the equation G=S<sup>2</sup>/(25*D), where G is G-Force, S is speed in mph, and D is diameter of the wall, in metres. This revealed the chosen location, a hangar on Manby Airfield, would be too small for Martin's desired target of 100 mph, but with a revised target of 80 mph while remaining below 7G, the 37.5 metre wall that was ultimately built would suffice. This would allow Martin to challenge a previous claimed record of around 70 mph, which the programme believed was wrong, determined through video analysis as having been 45 mph. For the show, Guinness World Records created a new record, Highest speed on a Wall of Death, and set an initial qualifying benchmark of 60 mph in one of two attempts. On a first attempt, using an [[Indian Scout (motorcycle)|Indian Scout]] motorcycle, Martin managed to achieve 70.33 mph, while on a second run, on a bike purposely built by Martin (a 1972 Rob North T160 Trident triple), he extended the record to 125.77 km/h (78.15 mph). Prior to Martin's attempt, on the smaller wall cyclist [[Shanaze Reade]] also set the Guinness record for Highest bicycle speed on a Wall of Death, at 42.94 km/h (26.68 mph).<ref name=":92" /><ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theconversation.com/science-behind-remarkable-new-wall-of-death-motorcycle-world-record-57018|title=Science behind remarkable new Wall of Death motorcycle world record|last=Hunt|first=Hugh|website=The Conversation|access-date=2016-04-02}}</ref>
=== Autobiographical ===
====''Guy Martin's Passion for Life''==== This one-off half hour programme explored various aspects of Martin's life. It was a repackaging of material previously released as four 7 minute long online only episodes, under Channel 4's Shorts brand, on their online platform [[All 4|4oD]]. Episodes "Prized Possession" and "TT Racer" were released on 18 August 2014, followed by "Inside the Mind of a Racer" and "Proud Mechanic" on 1 October 2014. Proud Possession focuses on his Merlin engine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/info/press/news/channel-4-announces-one-off-guy-martin-show-for-christmas|title=Channel 4 announces one-off Guy Martin show for Christmas - Channel 4 - Info - Press|website=www.channel4.com|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref>
==== ''Our Guy in Latvia'' ==== Guy travelled to [[Latvia]] to investigate the history of the Latvian side of his family – his deceased maternal grandfather, Walter Kidals, was a Latvian who had come to Britain in 1947 as a refugee from [[World War II]]. The family knew little about his story, even his wife had been unaware he was an orphan. Born Waldemars Kidals, the programme found that in 1941 he had been conscripted into the [[Latvian Legion]], part of the Axis Forces when Nazi Germany had occupied Latvia, and later spent two years in a Belgian prisoner-of-war camp. Having been exonerated by the post-war trials, and with Latvia now part of the Soviet Union, all surviving former Latvian conscripts were allowed to settle in the United States and Britain as political refugees – Walter opted for the UK, travelling to Hull.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5"/>
In the programme, Martin met surviving members of his family and visited the now cleared site of his family's former farmhouse. Travelling in a 1982 Lada 1300S, he also visited an immersive Cold War Russian prison experience, and watched a reenactment of a battle between the Legion forces and the Soviet Red Army.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5"/>
====''Our Guy In India''==== Guy Martin is shown embarking on a 1,000-mile motorbike trip, as he explores rarely seen aspects of modern [[India]] en route to [[Rider Mania]], described as "one of the world's maddest bike races".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/our-guy-in-india|title=Our Guy in India|work=Channel 4}}</ref>
====''Our Guy In China''==== Guy Martin's love of industry and endeavour leads him to [[China]], where he reveals the unseen side of its innovation, technological development and gigantic manufacturing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/our-guy-in-china/episode-guide|title=Our Guy in China|work=Channel 4}}</ref>
==Personal life== Martin lives in [[Kirmington]],<ref>[https://www.scunthorpetelegraph.co.uk/news/scunthorpe-news/guy-martin-reveals-north-lincolnshire-88109 Guy Martin reveals his North Lincolnshire home is where his heart is in new book, When You Dead, You Dead - Scunthorpe Telegraph] Retrieved 2018-02-14.</ref> a village around {{convert|19|mi}} away from his workplace in Grimsby.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/> At age 24 he was living on his girlfriend's parents' farm.<ref name=":28"/> {{as of|2015|February|}} he was preparing to move a short distance, to a smaller house, but with more shed space.<ref name=":28"/>
He has two sisters and a brother. His brother, Stuart, is also a truck mechanic and motorbike racer. His younger sister, Kate, was the first female mechanic in the BSB paddock before leaving to start a family with two-times TT sidecar winner, [[2013 Isle of Man TT#Race Results|Patrick Farrance]].
Aside from a summer living in [[Ireland]], Martin has always lived in [[North Lincolnshire]].
He lives with his partner, Sharon, whom he met at a moped race in Ireland; she was working for a publisher in Dublin, and moved over to Lincolnshire in 2014.<ref name=":28"/>
He likes the slightly backwards nature of Lincolnshire, comparing it to rural [[Cuba]] when he visited. His flying visits to London only make him appreciate home more.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/>
Martin was often joined by friends on his TV shows. In ''The Boat that Guy Built'' he was accompanied by childhood friend Mark "Mavis" Davies, who also appeared in two episodes of ''How Britain Worked'', as did his former girlfriend Stephanie when descending the museum's mine shaft with Martin in episode 4. In the Pike's Peak episode of ''Speed'' he is accompanied to the US by his friend Cameron Whitworth, a race mechanic with 17 TT wins, who declined to ride or even sit on the bike due to its power. Having never met before, Martin developed a friendship with [[David Coulthard]] while filming the F1 special of ''Speed'', leading to Couthard's later appearance as a guest in ''Guy Martin's Wall of Death: Live.'' Also appearing was Martin's partner, Sharon alongside his family as did friend and mentor, Ken Fox.
His best friend is Johnny Ellis, who has also been one of his race-mechanics at various times during his career. Although Ellis and Martin had attended the same school, Vale Academy, both being in the same year, they had not been close, Martin observing he was a "bit flash" when he once turned up at school on a motorbike. Their friendship developed after Martin joined John Hebb Volvo, where Ellis worked; both being keen to work on trucks during their free time outside school, never knowing their mutual interest.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YCCrCQAAQBAJ|title=Guy Martin: My Autobiography|last=Martin|first=Guy|date=2015-05-21|publisher=Virgin Books|isbn=9780753555033|page=52|language=en}}</ref>
Martin has a yellow [[Labrador Retriever]] called Nigel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.driving.co.uk/news/guy-martin-on-his-indian-motorbike-adventure/|title=Guy Martin on his Indian motorbike adventure|date=2 February 2015|work=driving.co.uk}}</ref> Following the inspiration for his own name, Martin has explained Nigel was "named in reference to his famous dog, although obviously I couldn't call him what [Guy] Gibson called his dog".<ref name=":92" />
Martin purchased the local 'Marrow Bone and Cleaver' [[pub]] in his home village of Kirmington. Dating back to 1871 with origins by a local butcher, it will have [[ale]] by Lincolnshire's [[Batemans Brewery]] and be run by Martin's elder sister Sally.<ref>[https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/speed-star-guy-martin-spares-9511909 Speed star Guy Martin 'breathes life back into' village where he grew up by buying the local pub] [[Daily Mirror|''Mirror'']], 24 December 2016. Retrieved 15 September 2017</ref>
He and partner Sharon have a daughter, named Dottie, who was born on 23 October 2017.<ref>[http://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/news/guy-martin-dad-partner-sharon-676497 Guy Martin is a dad as partner Sharon gives birth to daughter - and the baby's name is ace!] ''[[Grimsby Telegraph]]'', 25 October 2017. Retrieved 26 October 2017</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Iain Harrison | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[United Kingdom|UK]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = British / American | other_names = | known_for = Competitive shooter, winner of ''[[Top Shot]]'' [[Top Shot (season 1)|season 1]] | occupation = Construction manager | residence = [[Sherwood, Oregon]] | official website = }} '''Iain Harrison''' is a competitive shooter and former [[British Army]] Captain. He is known for being the winner of the [[Top Shot (season 1)|first season]] of [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]]'s marksmen competition ''[[Top Shot]]'' and the current editor of ''[[RECOIL (gun magazine)|RECOIL]]''. ==Biography== Harrison was born in the [[United Kingdom]]. He served as a recce platoon commander for the [[British Army]]. He moved to the [[United States]] and started working as a construction manager in [[Sherwood, Oregon]] after being forced to surrender his guns to the UK government, while pursuing competitive shooting.{{cite book|author=A+E Networks|editor=Colby Donaldson|title=Top Shot|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dLEgWataxHUC&pg=PT120|date= 2012|publisher=Penguin Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-101-60878-4|pages=120–125}} In 2009, Harrison finished second in Trooper Class in the 2009 MGM Ironman multi-gun competition. Being an amateur [[gunsmith]], the guns he used during the competition were made by himself. Harrison worked for [[Crimson Trace]] at this time.{{cite book|last=Adams|first=Chad|title=Complete Guide to 3-Gun Competition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r4_Jm938yX8C&pg=PA56|date=18 July 2012|publisher=Gun Digest Books|location=Iola, Wisconsin|isbn=1-4402-2867-1|page=56}} In December 2011, Harrison gained US citizenship.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanrifleman.org/articles/top-shot-winner-becomes-us-citizen/|title=Top Shot Winner Becomes U.S. Citizen|year=2011 |location=Joint Base Lewis McChord, Washington|publisher=American Rifleman|accessdate=22 October 2012}} Harrison became the editor of ''[[RECOIL (gun magazine)|RECOIL]]'' in January 2013; he writes several articles for each issue as well.{{cite web|url=http://soldiersystems.net/2013/06/07/recoil-issue-7-in-stores/|title= Recoil Issue 7 In Stores Now|accessdate=15 August 2013}} ===''Top Shot''=== In 2010, Harrison appeared in the [[Top Shot (season 1)|first season]] of [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]]'s marksmen competition ''[[Top Shot]]''. During the first half of the competition, Harrison competed as part of the Blue Team. His team ended up winning six challenges, and Harrison was only nominated for elimination once during that period. During the final half of the competition, Harrison won the last two individual challenges before the final. In the finale, he beat Chris Cerino to win the competition as well as $100,000. Harrison has since made three appearances on the show as a weapons trainer. His first appearance after winning was on the tenth episode of the [[Top Shot (season 2)|second season]] of the show. During one episode of the [[Top Shot (season 3)|third season]] of the show, Harrison appeared with Season 2 winner, [[Chris Reed (marksman)|Chris Reed]], serving as honorary team captains of the two current Blue and Red teams for one of the challenges. A $5,000 donation was made to a charity selected by the captain of the winning team, and Harrison chose the [[Wounded Warrior Project]]. However, his team lost to Chris Reed's Red team. He appeared again as a trainer during the [[Top Shot (season 4)|fourth season]]. {{s-start}} {{succession box|title=''[[Top Shot]]''
Winner|before=''None''|after=[[Chris Reed (marksman)|Chris Reed]]|years=Season 1 (2010)}} {{s-end}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.history.com/shows/top-shot/bios/iain-harrison# Iain Harrison Bio] on [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] * {{IMDb name|4356146}} {{Top Shot}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Harrison, Iain}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American male sport shooters]] [[Category:British Army officers]] [[Category:American magazine editors]] [[Category:American magazine staff writers]] [[Category:People from Sherwood, Oregon]] [[Category:Gun writers]] [[Category:British emigrants to the United States]]
