{{Infobox politician | name = Ihor Lutsenko | native_name = Ігор Луценко | native_name_lang = uk | office = [[Verkhovna Rada#Composition|People's Deputy of Ukraine]] | image = Луценко Ігор.JPG | imagesize = 200px | caption = Lutsenko in 2012 | term_start = 27 November 2014[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/583500/ CEC registers 357 newly elected deputies of 422] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204164227/http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/583500/ |date=2014-12-04 }}, [[National Radio Company of Ukraine]] (25 November 2014)
[http://www.unian.info/politics/1014078-parliament-to-form-leadership-and-coalition-on-november-27.html Parliament to form leadership and coalition on November 27], [[UNIAN]] (26 November 2014) | predecessor = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|11|10|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Kiev]], [[Ukrainian SSR]], Soviet Union | nationality = Ukrainian | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = | party = [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"]] | otherparty = | children = | alma_mater = | website = }} '''Ihor Viktorovych Lutsenko''' ({{lang-uk|І́гор Ві́кторович Луце́нко}}, born 10 November 1978) is a Ukrainian journalist and politician. In 2014, he was elected to the [[8th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|Verkhovna Rada]] on the party list of [[All-Ukrainian Union "Fatherland"|Batkivshchyna]]. Lutsenko took part in the [[Euromaidan]] protests in [[Kiev]]. In January 2014, he was abducted and beaten along with Yuriy Verbytsky who died. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite news |url= http://gapp.rada.gov.ua/mps/info/page/18054 |title= Луценко Ігор Вікторович |language= Ukrainian |trans-title=Ihor Viktorovych Lutsenko |publisher= [[Verkhovna Rada]] website }} {{cite news |url= http://www.rferl.org/content/abducted-euromaidan-supporter-dead-ukraine/25240225.html |title= Abducted And Left To Die: Euromaidan Supporter Found Dead In Forest |first= Claire |last= Bigg |first2= Iryna |last2= Shtogrin |work= [[RFERL]] |date= 23 January 2014 }} {{cite news |url= http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/a09e2716-8a69-11e3-ba54-00144feab7de.html |title= Tales of brutality emerge from Ukraine protests |first= Roman |last= Olearchyk |work= [[Financial Times]] |date= 31 January 2014 }} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lutsenko, Ihor}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kiev]] [[Category:Ukrainian journalists]] [[Category:Eighth convocation members of the Verkhovna Rada]] [[Category:People of the Euromaidan]] [[Category:Batkivshchyna politicians]] {{Ukraine-politician-stub}}

{{inline citations|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group=Ijaw |image=[[File:Ijaw statue.jpg|150px]] | image_caption = Ijaw statue depicting "the many faces of your enemies" | total = approx. 14 million | total_ref = {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GN5yv3-U6goC&pg=PA130&dq=ijaw+14+million&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKldSh69vVAhVoKcAKHUDOA-kQ6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=ijaw%2014%20million&f=false|title=Ethnic Groups of Africa and the Middle East: An Encyclopedia: An Encyclopedia|last=III|first=John A. Shoup|date=2011-10-17|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=|isbn=9781598843637|location=|pages=130|language=en}} |regions =[[Niger Delta]] |langs= [[Ijaw languages|Ijaw languages (Izon, Kalabari, Obolo, Ibani, Wakirike, Nkoroo, Nembe, Ogbian, Kabou, Buseni, Atala, Bille, Kula, Apoi, etc.)]] |rels= [[Christianity]] 98%
[[Islam]] 0.8%
[[Traditional African religions|Traditional]] 1.3%{{fact|date=May 2017}} |related-c= [[Ikwerre people|Ikwerre]], [[Ekpeye people|Ekpeye]], [[Ibibio people|Ibibio]], [[Ogoni people|Ogoni]], [[Isoko people|Isoko]], [[Igbo people|Igbo]] }} '''Ijaw people''' (also known by the subgroups "'''Ijo'''" or "'''Izon'''") are a collection of peoples [[indigenous peoples of Africa|indigenous]] to the [[Niger Delta]] in [[Nigeria]], inhabiting regions of the states of [[Ondo State|Ondo]], [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]], [[Delta State|Delta]], [[Edo State|Edo]], [[Akwa Ibom State|Akwa Ibom]] and [[Rivers State|Rivers]]. Many are found as migrant fishermen in camps as far west as [[Sierra Leone]] and as far east as [[Gabon]]. Population figures for the Ijo vary greatly,{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=A0XNvklcqbwC&pg=PA596&dq=ijaw+population&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjjnZye5dvVAhXGAMAKHZutAZIQ6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=ijaw%20population&f=false|title=Encyclopedia of Africa|last=Appiah|first=Anthony|last2=Gates|first2=Henry Louis|date=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780195337709|location=|pages=596|language=en}} though most range from 13 million to 15 million.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UNTig4CQ8JUC&pg=PA50&dq=ijaw+million&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiC96GG5tvVAhVXFMAKHcMVB20Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=ijaw%20million&f=false|title=Resource Rebels: Native Challenges to Mining and Oil Corporations|last=Gedicks|first=Al|date=2001|publisher=South End Press|year=|isbn=9780896086401|location=|pages=50|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bkRn6pl2fcwC&pg=PA55&dq=ijaw+13+million&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiej5bn7tvVAhXGJcAKHe_2BX8Q6AEILTAB#v=onepage&q=ijaw%2013%20million&f=false|title=The Marketing of Rebellion: Insurgents, Media, and International Activism|last=Bob|first=Clifford|date=2005-06-06|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780521607865|location=|pages=55|language=en}} They have long lived in locations near many sea trade routes, and they were well connected to other areas by trade as early as the 15th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.uiowa.edu/~africart/toc/people/Ijo.html |accessdate=April 15, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060206090831/http://www.uiowa.edu/~africart/toc/people/Ijo.html |archivedate=February 6, 2006 }} ==Language== {{main|Ijaw languages}} [[File:IjawHistory.jpeg|240px|Map showing Ijaw (Ijo) area in Nigeria|thumb]] The Ijaw speak nine closely related [[Niger–Congo languages]], all of which belong to the [[Ijoid languages|Ijoid]] branch of the Niger–Congo tree. The primary division between the [[Ijo languages]] is that between Eastern Ijo and Western Ijo, the most important of the former group of languages being [[Izon language|Izon]], which is spoken by about five million people. There are two prominent groupings of the Izon language. The first, termed either Western or Central Izon (Ijaw) consists of Western Ijaw speakers: [[Tuomo| Tuomo Clan]], [[Ekeremor clan|Ekeremor]], [[Mein clan|Sagbama (Mein)]], [[Bassan clan|Bassan]], [[Western Apoi clan|Apoi]], [[Arogbo clan|Arogbo]], [[Boma clan|Boma]] (Bumo), [[Kabo clan|Kabo (Kabuowei)]], Ogboin, Tarakiri, and Kolokuma-Opokuma.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} [[Nembe clan|Nembe]], [[Brass clan|Brass]] and [[Akassa clan|Akassa]] (Akaha) dialects represent Southeast Ijo (Izon).{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}}. [[Buseni clan|Buseni]] and [[Okordia clan|Okordia]] dialects are considered Inland Ijo.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} The other major Ijaw linguistic group is [[Kalabari people|Kalabari]]. Kalabari is considered an Eastern Ijaw language but the term "Eastern Ijaw" is not the normal nomenclature. Kalabari is the name of one of the Ijaw clans that reside on the eastern side of the Niger-Delta (Abonnema, Buguma, Bakana, Degema etc.) who form a major group in Rivers State, Other "Eastern" Ijaw clans are the Andoni, [[Okrika]], Ibani (the natives of Bonny, Finima and Opobo) and [[Nkoroo]]. They are neighbours to the [[Kalabari people]] in present-day [[Rivers State]], [[Nigeria]]. Other related Ijaw subgroups which have distinct languages but very close kinship, cultural and territorial ties with the rest of the Ijaw are the [[Epie-Atissa people|Epie-Atissa]], [[Engenni people|Engenni]] (also known as Ẹgẹnẹ), and [[Udekama|Degema]] (also called Udekama or Udekaama).Kari 2004 The [[Ogbia]] clan, as well as residents of Bukuma and Abuloma ([[Obulom]]).{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} It was discovered in the 1980s that a now extinct [[Berbice Creole Dutch]], spoken in Guyana, is partly based on Ijo [[lexicon]] and [[grammar]]. Its nearest relative seems to be Eastern Ijo, most likely Kalabari (Kouwenberg 1994). ==Clans== The Ijaw ethnic group consists of 50 loosely affiliated clans. These clans are based along kinship lines and/or shared cultural and religious traditions. {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:120px;"|Name ! style="width:120px;"|State ! style="width:120px;"|Alternate Names |- | '''[[Akassa tribe|Akassa]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Akaha, Akasa |- | '''[[Andoni people|Andoni]]''' || [[Rivers State|Rivers]]/[[Akwa Ibom State|Akwa Ibom]] || Obolo |- | '''[[Eastern Apoi tribe|Apoi (Eastern)]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Western Apoi tribe|Apoi (Western)]]''' || [[Ondo State|Ondo]] || |- | '''[[Arogbo tribe|Arogbo]]''' || [[Ondo State|Ondo]] || |- | '''[[Bassan tribe|Bassan]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Basan |- | '''[[Bille tribe|Bille]]''' || [[Rivers State|Rivers]] || Bile, Bili |- | tribe|Buseni]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Biseni |- | '''[[Egbema tribe|Egbema]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]]/[[Edo State|Edo]] || |- | '''[[Operemor tribe|Operemor]]''' || [[Delta '''[[Gbaranmatu tribe|Gbaranmatu]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || Gbaranmatu |- | '''[[Gbaran tribe|Gbaran]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Gbarain |- | '''[[Iduwini tribe|Iduwini]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]]/[[Delta State|Delta]] || |- | '''[[Isaba tribe|Isaba]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || |- | '''[[Kabo tribe|Kabo]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || Kabowei, Kabou |- | '''[[Kalabari tribe|Kalabari]]''' || [[Rivers State|Rivers]] || |- | '''[[Kolokuma tribe|Kolokuma]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Kou tribe|Kou]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |-Ijaw National Congress (INC) Constitution | '''[[Kula tribe (Nigeria)|Kula]]''' || [[Rivers State|Rivers]] || |- | '''[[Kumbo tribe|Kumbo]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || Kumbowei |- | '''[[Mein tribe|Mein]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]]/[[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Nembe Kingdom|Nembe]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Nkoro tribe|Nkoro]]''' || [[Rivers State|Rivers]] || Kala Kirika |- | '''[[Obotebe tribe|Obotebe]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || |- | '''[[Odimodi tribe|Odimodi]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || |- | '''[[Ogbe tribe|Ogbe]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || Ogbe-Ijoh |- | '''[[Ogbia clan|Ogbia]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Ogboin tribe|Ogboin]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Ogulagha tribe|Ogulagha]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || Ogula |- | '''[[Okordia tribe|Okordia]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Okodia, Akita |- | '''[[Okrika]]''' || [[Rivers State|Rivers]] || Wakirike |- | '''[[Eastern Olodiama tribe|Olodiama (East)]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Western Olodiama tribe|Olodiama (West)]]''' || [[Edo State|Edo]] || |- | '''[[Opobo tribe|Opobo]]''' || [[Rivers State|Rivers]] || |- | '''[[Opokuma]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Oporoma]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Oporomo |- | '''[[Oruma]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Tugbene |- | '''[[Oyakiri]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || Beni |- | '''[[Seimbiri]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || |- | '''[[Tarakiri East|Tarakiri (East)]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Tarakiri West|Tarakiri (West)]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta]] || |- | '''[[Tungbo]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |- | '''[[Tuomo Town |Tuomo]]''' || [[Delta State|Delta ]] / [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa ]] || T.T Clan |- | '''[[Ukomu]]''' || [[Edo State|Edo]] || |- | '''[[Zarama tribe|Zarama]]''' || [[Bayelsa State|Bayelsa]] || |} ==Traditional occupations== [[File:IjoMask1.jpg|200px|thumb|An Ijaw mask]] The Ijaw were one of the first of Nigeria's peoples to have contact with Westerners, and were active as go-betweens in the slave trade between visiting Europeans and the peoples of the interior, particularly in the era before the discovery of [[quinine]], when West Africa was still known as the "White Man's Graveyard" because of the endemic presence of [[malaria]]. Some of the kin-based trading lineages that arose among the Ijaw developed into substantial corporations which were known as "houses"; each house had an elected leader as well as a fleet of war canoes for use in protecting trade and fighting rivals. The other main occupation common among the Ijaw has traditionally been fishing and farming. Being a maritime people, many Ijaws were employed in the merchant shipping sector in the early and mid-20th century (pre-Nigerian independence). With the advent of oil and gas exploration in their territory, some are employed in that sector. Other main occupation are in the civil service of the Nigerian states of [[Bayelsa]] and [[Rivers]] where they are predominant. Extensive state-government sponsored overseas [[scholarship]] programs in the 1970s and 1980s have also led to a significant presence of Ijaw [[professionals]] in Europe and North America (the so-called Ijaw diaspora). Another contributing factor to this [[human capital flight]] is the abject poverty in their homeland of the [[Niger Delta]], resulting from decades of neglect by the Nigerian government and oil companies in spite of continuous petroleum prospecting in this region since the 1950s. ==Lifestyle== The Ijaw people live by fishing supplemented by farming [[Paddy field|paddy]]-[[rice]], [[Plantain (cooking)|plantains]], [[Cassava]], [[Yam (vegetable)|yams]], cocoyams, [[banana]]s and other vegetables as well as tropical fruits such as [[guava]], [[mangoes]] and [[pineapple]]s; and trading. Smoke-dried fish, [[timber]], [[palm oil]] and [[Arecaceae|palm]] [[seed|kernel]]s are processed for export. While some clans (those to the east- [[Akassa]], [[Nembe]], [[Kalabari]], [[Okrika]] and [[Kingdom of Bonny|Bonny]]) had powerful chiefs and a [[Social stratification|stratified society]], other clans are believed not to have had any centralized confederacies until the arrival of the British. However, owing to influence of the neighbouring [[Kingdom of Benin]] individual communities even in the western [[Niger Delta]] also had chiefs and governments at the village level. Marriages are completed by the payment of a bridal [[dowry]], which increases in size if the bride is from another village (so as to make up for that village's loss of her children). [[Funeral]] ceremonies, particularly for those who have accumulated wealth and respect, are often very dramatic. Traditional religious practices center around "Water spirits" in the Niger river, and around tribute to [[ancestors]]. ==Religion and cultural practices== Although the Ijaw are now primarily [[Christian]]s (65% profess to be), with [[Roman Catholicism]], [[Anglicanism]] and [[Pentecostal]] being the varieties of Christianity most prevalent among them, they also have elaborate traditional religious practices of their own. Veneration of ancestors plays a central role in Ijaw traditional religion, while water spirits, known as ''Owuamapu'' figure prominently in the Ijaw pantheon. In addition, the Ijaw practice a form of [[divination]] called ''Igbadai'', in which recently deceased individuals are interrogated on the causes of their death. Ijaw religious beliefs hold that water spirits are like humans in having personal strengths and shortcomings, and that humans dwell among the water spirits before being born. The role of prayer in the traditional Ijaw system of belief is to maintain the living in the good graces of the water spirits among whom they dwelt before being born into this world, and each year the Ijaw hold celebrations in honor the spirits lasting for several days. Central to the festivities is the role of masquerades, in which men wearing elaborate outfits and carved masks dance to the beat of drums and manifest the influence of the water spirits through the quality and intensity of their dancing. Particularly spectacular masqueraders are taken to actually be in the possession of the particular spirits on whose behalf they are dancing. The Ijaw are also known to practice [[ritual]] [[acculturation]] ([[enculturation]]), whereby an individual from a different, unrelated group undergoes rites to become Ijaw. An example of this is [[Jaja of Opobo]], the Igbo slave who rose to become a powerful [[Kingdom of Bonny|Ibani]] (Bonny) chief in the 19th century. There are also a small number of [[Converts to Islam]] the most notable being the founder of the [[Delta People Volunteer Force]], [[Mujahid Dokubo-Asari]]. [[Jeremiah Omoto Fufeyin]] comes from the Ijaw ethnic group. ==Food customs== Like many ethnic groups in Nigeria, the Ijaws have many local foods that are not widespread in Nigeria. Many of these foods involve fish and other seafoods such as clams, oysters and periwinkles; yams and plantains. Some of these foods are: *'''Polofiyai''' — A very rich soup made with yams and palm oil *'''Kekefiyai'''— A pottage made with chopped unripened (green) plantains, fish, other seafood or [[game]] [[meat]] ("[[bushmeat]]") and palm oil *'''Fried or roasted fish and plantain''' — Fish fried in palm oil and served with fried plantains *'''Gbe''' — The grub of the raffia-palm tree beetle that is eaten raw, dried, fried in groundnut oil or pickled in palm oil *'''Kalabari "sea-harvest" fulo'''— A rich mixed seafood soup or stew that is eaten with [[foofoo]], rice or yams *'''Owafiya (Beans Pottage)''' — A pottage made with [[Beans]], palm oil, fish or bushmeat, Yam or Plantain. Then taken with processed Cassava or Starch. *'''Geisha Soup''' — This a kind of soup cooked from the geisha fish, with just adding, pepe, salt, water and Boiling it for some minutes. *'''Opuru-fulou''' — Also referred to as prawn soup, prepared mainly with prawn, Ogbono ([[Irvingia_gabonensis|Irvingia gabonensis seeds]]), dried fish, table salt, crayfish, onions, fresh pepper, and red palm oil.{{cite journal |last1=Benjamin |first1=Amadi |last2=Dikhioye |first2=Peters |last3=Emmanuel |first3=Agomuo |last4=Peter |first4=Amadi |last5=Grace |first5=Denson |title=NUTRIENT COMPOSITION OF SOME SELECTED TRADITIONAL FOODS OF IJAW PEOPLE OF BAYELSA STATE |journal=Polish Journal of Natural Sciences |date=2018 |volume=33 |issue=1 |page=59-74 |url=http://www.uwm.edu.pl/polish-journal/issues/no-3312018}} *'''Kiri-igina''' — Prepared without cooking on fire with Ogbono ([[Irvingia gabonensis|Irvingia gabonensis seeds]]), dried fish, table salt, crayfish.{{cite journal |last1=Benjamin |first1=Amadi |last2=Dikhioye |first2=Peters |last3=Emmanuel |first3=Agomuo |last4=Peter |first4=Amadi |last5=Grace |first5=Denson |title=NUTRIENT COMPOSITION OF SOME SELECTED TRADITIONAL FOODS OF IJAW PEOPLE OF BAYELSA STATE |journal=Polish Journal of Natural Sciences |date=2018 |volume=33 |issue=1 |page=59-74 |url=http://www.uwm.edu.pl/polish-journal/issues/no-3312018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nacd.gov.ng/Bayelsa_State_Cuisines.htm |website=Bayesla State Cuisines}} *'''Ignabeni''' — A watery soup prepared with either yam or plantain seasoned with teabush leaves, pepper, goat meat, and fish.{{cite web |url=http://www.nacd.gov.ng/Bayelsa_State_Cuisines.htm |website=Bayesla State Cuisines}} ==Ethnic identity== Formerly organized into several loose clusters of villages ([[Confederation|confederacies]]) which cooperated to defend themselves against outsiders, the Ijaw increasingly view themselves as belonging to a single coherent nation, bound together by ties of language and culture. This tendency has been encouraged in large part by what are considered to be environmental degradations that have accompanied the exploitation of oil in the Niger delta region which the Ijaw call home, as well as by a revenue sharing formula with the Nigerian Federal government that is viewed by the Ijaw as manifestly unfair. The resulting sense of grievance has led to several high-profile clashes with the Nigerian Federal authorities, including kidnappings and in the course of which many lives have been lost. The Ijaw people are resilient and proud. Long before after the colonial era, the Ijaw people traveled by wooded boats and canoes to Cameroun, Ghana and other West African countries. They traveled up the River Niger from River Nun. ==Ijaw-Itsekiri conflicts== {{main| Warri Crisis}} One manifestation of ethnic violence on the part of the Ijaw has been an increase in the number and severity of clashes between Ijaw militants and those of [[Itsekiri]] origin, particularly in the town of [[Warri, Nigeria|Warri]]. Deadly conflicts had rocked the South-South region, especially in Delta State, where intertribal killings had resulted in death in both sides.{{cite web|url=http://www.informationng.com/2013/07/communal-clash-causes-tension-in-delta-as-ijaw-youths-kill-four-itsekiri.html |title=Communal Clash Causes Tension In Delta As Ijaw Youths Kill Four Itsekiri | INFORMATION NIGERIA |publisher=Informationng.com |date=2013-07-03 |accessdate=2016-02-09}} {{cite web|author= |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/new/brother-against-brother-reigniting-itsekiri-ijaw-tensions/ |title=Brother against brother: Reigniting Itsekiri, Ijaw tensions - The Nation Nigeria |publisher=Thenationonlineng.net |date=2014-11-23 |accessdate=2016-02-09}} In July 2013, local police discovered mutilated corpses of 13 Itsekiris killed by Ijaws, over dispute over the candidate for a local council chairman. Several Itsekiri villages, including Gbokoda, Udo, Ajamita, Obaghoro and Ayerode-Zion on the Benin river axis, were razed down while several Itsekiris lost their lives.{{cite web|url=http://saharareporters.com/2013/07/09/ijawitsekiri-crisis-police-recover-gory-corpses-slain-uduaghan-kinsmen |title=Ijaw/Itsekiri Crisis: Police Recover Gory Corpses Of Slain Uduaghan Kinsmen |publisher=Sahara Reporters |date=2013-07-09 |accessdate=2016-02-09}} ==Oil conflict== {{main|Nigerian Oil Crisis}} The December 1998 All Ijaw Youths Conference crystallized the struggle with the formation of the [[Ijaw Youth Movement]] (IYM) and the issuing of the [[Kaiama Declaration]]. In it, long-held Ijaw concerns about the loss of control of their homeland and their own lives to the oil companies were joined with a commitment to direct action. In the declaration, and in a letter to the companies, the Ijaws called for oil companies to suspend operations and withdraw from Ijaw territory. The IYM pledged “to struggle peacefully for freedom, self-determination and ecological justice,” and prepared a campaign of celebration, prayer, and direct action '[[Operation Climate Change]]' beginning December 28, 1998. In December 1998, two warships and 10-15,000 Nigerian troops occupied Bayelsa and Delta states as the [[Ijaw Youth Movement]] (IYM) mobilized for [[Operation Climate Change]]. Soldiers entering the Bayelsa state capital of Yenagoa announced they had come to attack the youths trying to stop the oil companies. On the morning of December 30, 1998, two thousand young people processed through Yenagoa, dressed in black, singing and dancing. Soldiers opened fire with rifles, machine guns, and tear gas, killing at least three protesters and arresting twenty-five more. After a march demanding the release of those detained was turned back by soldiers, three more protesters were shot dead including Nwashuku Okeri, Ghadafi Ezeifile and Onwinkron Ibe. The head of Yenagoa rebels- Chief Onwinkron Ibe- was burned alive in his mansion on December 28, 1998. Amongst his family members to flee the premises before complete ruins was his only son, Desmond Ibe. The military declared a state of emergency throughout Bayelsa state, imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew, and banned meetings. At military roadblocks, local residents were severely beaten or detained. At night, soldiers invaded private homes, terrorizing residents with beatings and women and girls with rape. On January 4, 1999 about one hundred soldiers from the military base at [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]]’s Escravos facility attacked [[Opia]] and [[Ikiyan]], two Ijaw communities in Delta State. [[Bright Pablogba]], the traditional leader of Ikiyan, who came to the river to negotiate with the soldiers, was shot along with a seven-year-old girl and possibly dozens of others. Of the approximately 1,000 people living in the two villages, four people were found dead and sixty-two were still missing months after the attack. The same soldiers set the villages ablaze, destroyed canoes and fishing equipment, killed livestock, and destroyed churches and religious shrines. Nonetheless, Operation Climate Change continued, and disrupted Nigerian oil supplies through much of 1999 by turning off valves through Ijaw territory. In the context of high conflict between the Ijaw and the Nigerian Federal Government (and its police and army), the military carried out the [[Odi massacre]], killing scores if not hundreds of Ijaws. Recent actions by Ijaws against the oil industry have included both renewed efforts at nonviolent action and militarized attacks on oil installations but with no human casualties to foreign oil workers despite hostage-takings. These attacks are usually in response to non-fulfilment by oil companies of memoranda of understanding with their host communities. ==Notable Ijaw People== *[[Goodluck Jonathan]], Politician and former President *[[J.P. Clark]], Poet and Playwright *[[Owoye Andrew Azazi]], Former Army general and National Security Adviser *[[Timi Dakolo]], Nigerian singer-songwriter *[[Ibinabo Fiberesima]], Nigerian Nollywood actress *[[Julius Arebo]], Nigerian Web Developer *[[Ben Murray-Bruce]], Nigerian Media mogul and Senator *[[Finidi George]], Nigerian football legend *[[Samson Siasia]], former Nigerian footballer and coach ==Ijaw organisations== * [[Andoni Forum USA (AFUSA)]] * [[Ijaw Youth Council]] * [[Ijaw National Congress]] * [[Ijaw Elders Forum]] * [[Ijaw Youth Congress]] * [[Congress of Niger Delta Youths]] * [[National Union of Izon-Ebe Students]] * [[Tuomo Town|Tuomo Youth Congress]] * [[Sagbama Youth Movement]] * [[Ekine Sekiapu Ogbo]] * [[Bomadi Decides]] * Bayelsa Youths Council * The Ogbia brotherhood *Izon Progressive Congress (IPC) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Other sources== * Human Rights Watch, “Delta Crackdown,” May 1999 * Ijaw Youth Movement, letter to “All Managing Directors and Chief Executives of transnational oil companies operating in Ijawland,” December 18, 1998 * Project Underground, "Visit the World of Chevron: Niger Delta", 1999 * Kari, Ethelbert Emmanuel. 2004. A reference grammar of Degema. Köln: Rüdiger Köppe Verlag. * Hlaváčová, Anna: Three Points of View of Masquerades among the Ijo of the Niger River Delta.In: Playful Performers: African Children's Masquerades. Ottenberg, S.- Binkley, D. (Eds.) ==External links== {{Portal|Nigeria}} *[http://www.ijawfoundation.org/people.htm Ijaw Foundation] *[http://www.ijawdictionaryonline.com The Ijaw Language Dictionary Online] *[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_family.asp?subid=2430 Ethnologue: Ijaw Linguistic Tree] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060206090831/http://www.uiowa.edu/~africart/toc/people/Ijo.html Ijo People] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20040515163556/http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/sokari/ American Museum of Natural History: The Art of the Kalabari Masquerade] *[https://www.hrw.org/reports/2003/nigeria1103/index.htm The Warri Crisis: Fueling Violence - Human Rights Watch Report, November 2003] *[http://www.adakaboro.org The Adaka Boro Centre] *[http://www.vanityfair.com/politics/features/2007/02/junger200702 "Blood Oil"] by [[Sebastian Junger]] in ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', February 2007 (accessed 28/1/2007), deals partly with the Ijaw {{coord|5|21|00|N|5|30|30|E|region:NG-DE_type:city|display=title}} {{Ethnic groups in Nigeria}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ijaw People}} [[Category:Ijaw people| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Nigeria]] [[Category:Fossil fuels in Nigeria]] [[Category:History of Nigeria]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of the Niger Delta]]

revision.comment: Typo correction in the name of one of Hale's novels.
revision.text:
'''Janet Campbell Hale''' (born January 11, 1946, [[Riverside, California]])<ref>''U.S. Public Records Index'' Vol 1 & 2 (Provo, UT: Ancestry.com Operations, Inc.), 2010.</ref> is a [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] writer. Her father was a full-blood [[Coeur d'Alene people|Coeur d'Alene]], and her mother was of [[Ktunaxa|Kootenay]], [[Cree]] and Irish descent<ref>http://www.hanksville.org/storytellers/jchale/.</ref>
In a sparse style that has been compared to Hemingway,<ref>http://oldmolekboo.blogspot.com/1998/02/jailing-of-cecelia-capture-by-janet.html</ref> Hale's work often explores issues of Native American identity and discusses poverty, abuse, and the condition of women in society. She wrote ''Bloodlines: Odyssey of a Native Daughter'' (1993), which includes a discussion of the Native American experience as well as stories from her own life. She also wrote ''The Owl's Song'' (1974), ''The Jailing of Cecelia Capture'' (which was nominated for the Pulitzer Prize in 1985), ''Women on the Run'' (1999), and ''Custer Lives in Humboldt County & Other Poems'' (1978).<ref>http://www.britannica.com/biography/Janet-Campbell-Hale</ref>
Janet Campbell Hale has taught at Northwest Indian College,<ref>http://www.hanksville.org/storytellers/jchale/</ref> Iowa State University, College of Illinois, and University of California at Santa Cruz,<ref>http://www.ipl.org/div/natam/bin/browse.pl/A36</ref> and has served as resident writer at University of Oregon and University of Washington.<ref>http://www.hanksville.org/storytellers/jchale/</ref> Hale currently lives on the [[Coeur d'Alene Reservation]] in [[Benewah County, Idaho|De Smet, Idaho]].
==Themes== ''Capture'' is a major theme in Janet Campbell Hale's writing. The name of the protagonist in the eponymous ''Jailing of Cecelia Capture'' is named for ''capture,'' but is also both literally and figuratively captured at different points in the narrative. Part of the dynamics of ''Bloodlines'' is to invert the white narratives about the capture of white people by Native Americans, into an account of capture of Native peoples by European-descended people.<ref>http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/ail/summary/v019/19.3finnegan.html</ref> Escape and transformation of capture figure in several of her works.
==See also== {{Portal bar|Native American culture |Poetry}} <!-- delete the word "bar" if there are enough ordinary See also --> * [[List of writers from peoples indigenous to the Americas]]
==References== {{reflist <!--|25em not yet enough refs--> }}
*Kratzert, M. "Native American Literature: Expanding the Canon", ''Collection Building'', volume 17/1 (1998), page 4 *Dennis, Helen M. ''Native American Literature: Towards a Spatialized Reading''. London, Routledge Publ., (2006), pp. 90–103
==External links== * [http://www.nativewiki.org/Janet_Campbell_Hale Janet Campbell Hale] at NativeWiki * {{LCAuth|n80007705|Janet Campbell Hale|10|}} * [http://www.hanksville.org/storytellers/jchale/writing/DoraLee.html "Dora Lee in Love"] (excerpt from her novel, ''Dora Lee'') * [https://conservancy.umn.edu/bitstream/handle/11299/166177/Hale,%20Janet%20Campbell.pdf Biography by Maria-Theresia Holub, at University of Minnesota]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hale, Janet Campbell}} [[Category:Writers from Idaho]] [[Category:Writers from Riverside, California]] [[Category:People from Benewah County, Idaho]] [[Category:Native American women writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Native American children's writers]] [[Category:American children's writers]] [[Category:American women children's writers]] [[Category:American Book Award winners]] [[Category:Coeur d'Alene people]] [[Category:Ktunaxa people]] [[Category:Cree people]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} <!--When adding names to the list, please include a reliable source that describes the person added as "Albanian" or "Albanian American" (or a source where the person describes themselves as such), in accordance with Wikipedia's [[No Original Research]] policies.--> {{Americans}} This is a list of '''notable [[Albanian American]]s''', including both original immigrants who obtained American citizenship and their American descendants.
<small>'''Note:''' An asterisk (*) next to a name indicates that the person is [[Arbëreshe]], an Albanian subgroup from Italy.</small><!-- Please do not add yourself, non-notable people or fictional characters. Please add citations where appropriate. --->
==Politics== * [[Joseph J. DioGuardi]]* – Congressman<ref>{{cite web|author=Susan Araki Vergnani|url=http://www.jrn.columbia.edu/studentwork/cityscape/2002/littleitaly.asp|title=Albanian Merchants Add Verve to Bronx's "Little Italy"|publisher=Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism|date=2002|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060515051934/http://www.jrn.columbia.edu/studentwork/cityscape/2002/littleitaly.asp|archivedate=May 15, 2006}}</ref> * [[Richard Caliguiri]] – politician * [[Mark Gjonaj]] – Assemblyman, New York * [[Sal Albanese]] – politician * [[Nicholas Scutari]] – [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] politician * [[Midhat Frashëri]] – diplomat, writer and politician * [[Hasan Dosti]] – jurist and politician * [[Victor Dosti]] – politician * [[Spiridon Ilo]] – nationalist, politician * [[Rexhep Krasniqi]] – historian, teacher, nationalist, and anti-communist politician and activist * [[Petro Nini Luarasi]] – priest, writer, teacher, nationalist * [[Kolë Tromara]] – nationalist and political figure of the first half of the 20th century. * [[Bilal Xhaferri]] – poet and novelist, political * [[Konstantina Lukes]] – former mayor of Worcester, Massachusetts * [[Fan S. Noli]] – former [[Prime Minister of Albania]] and founder of the [[Albanian Orthodox Church]] * John Papajani – former [[Washington State Senate]] member<ref name="Qyteza">{{citation|accessdate=October 13, 2013|url=http://www.qyteza.org/|publisher=Qyteza.org|language=Albanian|title=Main Page|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161025173438/http://www.qyteza.org/|archivedate=October 25, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=273053|title=Our Campaigns – Candidate – John Papajani|work=ourcampaigns.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_bV5ncXNke4C&pg=PA379&lpg=PA379&dq=john+papajani&source=bl&ots=hyxC1lnp1z&sig=S3efn2Lyt--8igRzFTXhSjTWrt0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=NCu6UomnF4fnsAS2y4LoAg&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=john%20papajani&f=false|title=MI6|work=google.com}}</ref> *[[Victor H. Schiro]]* – politician, 55th Mayor of New Orleans, Louisiana *Bardhyl Tirana – co-chair of the Presidential Inaugural Committee (1976–1977) and director of the Defense Civil Preparedness Agency (1977–1979)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/multi/A-Br/Albanian-Americans.html|title=Albanian Americans – History, The first Albanians in america, Significant immigration waves|work=everyculture.com}}</ref><ref name="Jacques">{{citation|accessdate=November 9, 2013| author=Edwin Jacques|page=xi| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IJ2s9sQ9bGkC&pg=PA82&dq=bardhyl+tirana&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_bd-UseKIo_d4AO5s4CAAg&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=bardhyl%20tirana&f=false| title=The Albanians: An Ethnic History from Prehistoric Times to the Present| volume=2|isbn=978-0786442386|date=January 16, 2009| publisher= McFarland}}</ref>
==Science and academia== * [[William G. Gregory]] – astronaut * [[Carol Folt]] – biologist and first woman leader of the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] * [[Laura Mersini-Houghton]] – cosmologist * [[Ferid Murad]] – medical researcher [[Nobel laureate]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frosina.org/about/infobits.asp?id=138|title= Ferid Murad: Albanian-American Nobel Prize Winner|publisher=frosina.org|date=6 August 2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714082619/http://www.frosina.org/about/infobits.asp?id=138|archivedate=14 July 2011}}</ref> * [[Arshi Pipa]] – philosopher, writer, poet and literary critic<ref>{{cite web|last=Elsie|first=Robert|title=Arshi Pipa|url=http://www.albanianliterature.net/authors_modern1/pipa.html|publisher=Robert Elsie|accessdate=January 9, 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.albanianliterature.net%2Fauthors_modern1%2Fpipa.html&date=2012-01-09|archivedate=January 9, 2012|quote=Writer and scholar, Arshi Pipa (1920–1997) ..studied philosophy...published... poetry}}</ref> * [[Andrea Shundi]] – agronomist * [[Stavro Skëndi]] – linguist and historian<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=5002366533 |title=The Teaching of Albanian at Columbia University by Peter Prifti, Rafaela Kondi |publisher=Questia.com |date= |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref>

==Media== * [[Fadil Berisha]] – photographer * [[Emin Kadi]] – photographer, journalist, art director * [[Florina Kaja]] – singer and reality TV actress, ''The Bad Girls Club'' Season 4 * [[Bill Kovach]] – journalist and editor * [[Donald Lambro]] – journalist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/multi/A-Br/Albanian-Americans.html |title=Albanian Americans |publisher=Everyculture.com |date= |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref> * [[Eric Margolis (journalist)|Eric Margolis]] – journalist and editor of the ''[[Toronto Sun]]''; mother is Albanian<ref>{{cite web|url=http://albanianliterature.com/authors3/AA3-46.html |title=Robert Elsie: Albanian Literature in Translation |publisher=Albanianliterature.com |date=December 15, 2010 |accessdate=February 15, 2011}}</ref> * [[Gjekë Marinaj]] – author and translator * [[Gjon Mili]] – photographer * [[Burim Myftiu]] – photographer * [[Tom Perrotta]]* – novelist and screenwriter<ref>{{cite news|author=John Crace |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/feb/21/tom-perrotta-interview |title=Tom Perrotta interview |publisher=Guardian |date= February 21, 2009|accessdate=February 15, 2011 |location=London}}</ref> * [[Molly Qerim]] – moderator, reporter * [[George Tames]] – photographer for ''The New York Times''<ref>{{cite news|last=Binder|first=David|author-link=David Binder (journalist)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/24/obituaries/george-tames-photographer-dies-at-75.html|title=George Tames, Photographer, Dies at 75|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=February 24, 1994|accessdate=May 21, 2017}}</ref> * [[Nick Tosches]]* – journalist, novelist, biographer, and poet * [[Nexhmie Zaimi]] – journalist * [[Iliriana Sulkuqi]] – journalist
==Science and technology== * [[Donald Leka]] – pioneer in cloud computing and creator of the award-winning [[Glide OS]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allthingsd.com/20080529/transmedia/|title=Demo: TransMedia’s Glide|work=AllThingsD}}</ref><ref>[http://frosinainfo.blogspot.com/search?q=Donald+Leka "Albanian-American Donald Leka Selected Among 300 of the World's Most Respected Innovators"] Frosina.org</ref>

==Religion== * [[Nikon Liolin]] – [[Orthodox Church in America|OCA]]'s Bishop of [[Orthodox Church in America Diocese of New England|Diocese of New England]], [[Locum tenens]] of [[Orthodox Church in America Diocese of the South|Diocese of the South]], and Archbishop of [[Orthodox Church in America Albanian Archdiocese|American Albanian Archdiocese]]

revision.text:
'''Mick Dodge''', also known as "The Barefoot Sensei", "the Barefoot Nomad" and "Walking Mountain"<ref name="PDNews">{{cite journal | last = Smilie | first = Joe | title = Mountain man Mick Dodge loves the wild but isn't a 'wild man' (CORRECTED) | journal = Peninsula Daily News | date =19 February 2014 | url = http://www.peninsuladailynews.com/article/20140119/NEWS/301199998/mountain-man-mick-dodge-loves-the-wild-but-isnt-a-wild-man | accessdate = 21 October 2014 }} </ref> is a television personality and rainforest-dweller in [[Washington_(state)|Washington]].
==Early life== He is a native of the [[Olympic Peninsula]]. His great-grandparents settled in the region and Dodge grew up there as a child. He loved the outdoors. Dodge also lived in many other places around the country and the world as the son of a career Marine,<ref name="Barefoot">[http://www.odditycentral.com/news/the-barefoot-sensei-former-marine-left-everything-behind-to-live-in-the-forest-barefoot.html "The Barefoot Sensei – Former Marine Left Everything Behind to Live in the Forest"], ''Oddity Central'', January 30th, 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.thenewstribune.com/2014/01/07/2981340_mick-dodge-rain-forest-dweller.html?rh=1 "Mick Dodge, rain forest dweller"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826114808/http://www.thenewstribune.com/2014/01/07/2981340_mick-dodge-rain-forest-dweller.html?rh=1 |date=2014-08-26 }} ''The News Tribune'', January 7, 2014.</ref> Ronald L. Dodge.<ref name="PDNews" /> The younger Dodge graduated from high school in Okinawa, Japan. He enlisted in the Marine Corps and served for six years.<ref name="PDNews" />
==In the forest== Dodge decided to leave the modern world and retreat to the dense forest due to the stress of modern living.<ref>[http://www.mnn.com/earth-matters/wilderness-resources/stories/he-lives-in-a-tree-doesnt-wear-shoes-and-brushes-his "He lives in a tree, doesn't wear shoes, and brushes his teeth with a pinecone], ''[[MNN.com]]'' January 07, 2014.</ref> He was nicknamed "The Barefoot Sensei" due to his preference to not wear shoes or sandals when walking in the forest. Since 1991, he has been living barefoot, a decision that he believed helped cure him of [[plantar fasciitis]], back pain and [[hammer toe]]s. He also felt that it helped him connect more intuitively with the natural world.<ref name="Barefoot" />
==EarthGym program== Despite the preference to be separated from modern civilization, Dodge is still involved with the community. In 1994, he and Jacquie Chandler created an earth-based fitness program they called The EarthGym, a fitness program in the forest where nature provides most of the equipment for physical training.<ref>cat man [http://www.theearthgym.com/#!mick-dodge/c24jz "Mick Dodge bio, the Barefoot Sensei - The EarthGym"], Retrieved on 16 September 2014.</ref>
==Media== Dodge is the subject of the [[National Geographic Channel]] reality TV series ''[[The Legend of Mick Dodge]]'', about his unusual life dwelling in a forest.<ref name="NG">[http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/the-legend-of-mick-dodge/articles/meet-mick-dodge/ "The Legend of Mick Dodge | National Geographic Channel"], ''National Geographic Channel''</ref>
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dodge, Mick}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Survivalists]] [[Category:United States Marines]]

{{other uses}} {{one source | date = April 2015 }} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox book | name = The Fortunes and Misfortunes of the Famous Moll Flanders | author = [[Daniel Defoe]] | language =English | country = [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] | genre = [[Novel]], [[picaresque]] | published = 1722 | publisher = [[William Rufus Chetwood]] | image = Mollflanders-brighter.jpg | image_size = 150px | caption = |set_in=[[England]] and [[Virginia Colony]], 1618–1683 | media_type = Print: [[octavo]] | pages =xiii,424 | wikisource = Moll Flanders | isbn = <!-- Released before ISBN system implemented --> |oclc=702355312 |dewey=823.5 |congress=PR3404.M6 }} '''''The Fortunes and Misfortunes of the Famous Moll Flanders Who was born in Newgate, and during a life of continu'd Variety for Threescore Years, besides her Childhood, was Twelve Years a Whore, five times a Wife (whereof once to her brother) Twelve Years a Thief, Eight Years a Transported Felon in Virginia, at last grew Rich, liv'd Honest and died a Penitent''''' (commonly known simply as '''''Moll Flanders''''') is a novel by [[Daniel Defoe]], first published in 1722. It purports to be the true account of the life of the eponymous Moll, detailing her exploits from birth until old age.
By 1721, Defoe had become a recognised novelist, with the success of ''[[Robinson Crusoe]]'' in 1719. His political work was tapering off at this point, due to the fall of both [[British Whig Party|Whig]] and [[British Tory Party|Tory]] party leaders with whom he had been associated; [[Robert Walpole]] was beginning his rise, and Defoe was never fully at home with the Walpole group. Defoe's Whig views are nevertheless evident in the story of Moll, and the novel's full title gives some insight into this and the outline of the plot:<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The fortunes and misfortunes of the famous Moll Flanders, &c. Who was born in Newgate, and during a Life of continu'd Variety for Threescore Years, besides her Childhood, was Twelve Year a Whore, five times a Wife (whereof once to her own Brother) Twelve Year a Thief, Eight Year a Transported Felon in Virginia, at last grew Rich, liv'd Honest, and died a Penitent, Written from her own memorandums.|last=Defoe|first=Daniel|publisher=W. Chetwood|year=1722|isbn=|location=Eighteenth Century Collections Online|pages=}}</ref>
It is usually assumed that the novel was written by Daniel Defoe, and his name is commonly given as the author in modern printings of the novel. However, the original printing did not have an author, as it was an apparent autobiography.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pbslearningmedia.org/resource/xjf440699eng/title-page-for-moll-flanders-by-daniel-defoe-published-1722-xjf440699-eng/#.Wfd3Zmd-6-w|title=Title Page for 'Moll Flanders' by Daniel Defoe, published 1722|website=PBS LearningMedia|language=en|access-date=2017-10-30}}</ref> The attribution of ''Moll Flanders'' to Defoe was made by bookseller Francis Noble in 1770, after Defoe's death in 1731.<ref>Furbank and Owens "The Canonisation of Daniel Defoe" (1988); "Defoe De-Attributions" (1994) and "A Critical Bibliography of Daniel Defoe" (1998)</ref>
The novel is based partially on the life of [[Elizabeth Adkins|Moll King]], a London criminal whom Defoe met while visiting [[Newgate Prison]].
==Plot summary== [[File:Moll Flanders.png|thumb|left|upright|250px|Illustration of an 18th-century chapbook.]] Moll's mother is a convict in [[Newgate Prison]] in London who is given a reprieve by "[[pleading the belly|pleading her belly]]," a reference to the custom of staying the executions of pregnant criminals. Her mother is eventually [[convict transportation|transported]] to [[Colonial United States]], and Moll Flanders (not her birth name, she emphasizes, taking care not to reveal it) is raised from the age of three until adolescence by a kindly foster mother. Thereafter she gets attached to a household as a servant where she is loved by both sons, the elder of whom convinces her to "act like they were married" in bed. Unwilling to marry her, he persuades her to marry his younger brother. After five years of marriage, she then is widowed, leaves her children in the care of in-laws, and begins honing the skill of passing herself off as a fortuned widow to attract a man who will marry her and provide her with security.
The first time she does this, her "gentleman-tradesman" spendthrift husband goes bankrupt and flees to the Continent, leaving her on her own with his blessing to do the best she can to forget him. (They had one child together, but "it was buried.") The second time, she makes a match that leads her to [[Colony of Virginia|Virginia Colony]] with a kindly man who introduces her to his mother. After three children (one dies), Moll learns that her mother-in-law is actually her biological mother, which makes her husband her half-brother. She dissolves their marriage and after continuing to live with her brother for three years, travels back to England, leaving her two children behind, and goes to live in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]] to seek a new husband.
Again she returns to her [[confidence trick|con skills]] and develops a relationship with a man in Bath whose wife is elsewhere confined due to insanity. Their relationship is at first platonic, but eventually develops into Moll becoming something of a "[[kept woman]]" in [[Hammersmith]], London. They have three children (one lives), but after a severe illness he repents, breaks off the arrangement, and commits to his wife. However, he assures Moll that their son will be well cared for, so she leaves yet another child behind.
Moll, now 42, resorts to another beau, a bank clerk, who while still married to an adulterous wife (a "whore"), proposes to Moll after she entrusts him with her financial holdings. While waiting for the banker to divorce, Moll pretends to have a great fortune to attract another wealthy husband [[Lancashire]], assisted by a new female acquaintance who attests to Moll's (erroneous) social standing. The ruse is successful and she marries a supposedly rich man who claims to own property in Ireland. They each quickly realize that they were both conned and manipulated by the before mentioned new acquaintance. He discharges her from the marriage, telling her nevertheless that she should inherit any money he might ever get. After enjoying each other's company for about a month, they part ways, but Moll soon discovers that she is pregnant. She gives birth and the [[midwife]] gives a tripartite scale of the costs of bearing a child, with one value level per social class. She continues to correspond with the bank clerk, hoping he will still have her.
Moll leaves her newborn in the care of a countrywoman in exchange for the sum of £5 a year. Moll marries the banker, but realizes "what an abominable creature I am! and how this innocent gentleman is going to be abused by me!" They live in happiness for five years before he becomes bankrupt and dies of despair, the fate of their two children left unstated.
Truly desperate now, Moll begins a career of artful thievery, which, by employing her wits, beauty, charm, and femininity, as well as hard-heartedness and wickedness, brings her the financial security she has always sought. She becomes well known among those "in the trade," and is given the name Moll Flanders. She is helped throughout her career as a thief by her Governess, who also acts as [[Fence (criminal)|receiver]]. (During this time she briefly becomes the mistress of a man she robbed.) Moll is finally caught by two maids whilst trying to steal from a house.
In Newgate she is led to her repentance. At the same time, she reunites with her soulmate, her "Lancashire husband", who is also jailed for his robberies (before and after they first met, he acknowledges). Moll is found guilty of felony, but not burglary, the second charge; still, the sentence is death in any case. Yet Moll convinces a minister of her repentance, and together with her Lancashire husband is transported to [[Thirteen Colonies|the Colonies]] to avoid hanging, where they live happily together (she even talks the ship's captain into not being with the convicts sold upon arrival, but instead in the captain's quarters). Once in the colonies, Moll learns her mother has left her a plantation and that her own son (by her brother) is alive, as is her husband/brother.
Moll carefully introduces herself to her brother and their son, in disguise. With the help of a Quaker, the two found a farm with 50 servants in [[Province of Maryland|Maryland]]. Moll reveals herself now to her son in [[Colony of Virginia|Virginia]] and he gives her her mother's inheritance, a farm for which he will now be her steward, providing £100 a year income for her. In turn, she makes him her heir and gives him a (stolen) gold watch.
At last, her life of conniving and desperation seems to be over. After her husband/brother dies, Moll tells her (Lancashire) husband the entire story and he is "perfectly easy on that account... For, said he, it was no fault of yours, nor of his; it was a mistake impossible to be prevented." Aged 69 (in 1683), the two return to England to live "in sincere penitence for the wicked lives we have lived."
== Marriages, relationships, and children== Throughout the novel, Moll goes through a series of relationships, legitimate and not, and through these relationships she bears many children. The lack of character names and Defoe’s inability to keep clear distinctions between his many, nameless characters give the reader the difficult task of keeping track of not just characters as a whole, but specifically Moll’s marriages, relationships, and children, which make up a majority of her life’s story. The following maps out Moll’s relationships and marriages in the order that they appeared in the novel as well as any children that might have been born as a result of their union.<ref name=":0" />
Eldest brother * Relationship Robin, younger brother of previous, eldest brother * He dies * Two children * Leaves children with in-laws The Draper * He dies * One child * Child dies The Plantation Owner/her brother * Leaves him * Three children * Leaves children with husband Becomes the mistress to married man * He leaves her * Three children * 2 children die * Leaves the one surviving child with the father James * Mutually agree to separate * One child * Has child in secret, without the knowledge of James, and sells the child to another family through the help of her midwife. The Banker * He dies * Two children * The children are mentioned a few times after The Banker’s death but then there is no more mention of their whereabouts. James, again * Moll and James find each other once again and rekindle their love. * They move to America where Moll reunites with a son from her marriage to The Plantation Owner/her brother
“Official” marriages: 6 times to 5 different men
Unofficial marriages: x1
Mistress: x1
Husband deaths: x3
Child deaths: x3
Children accounted for: x7
Children unaccounted for: x2
Children she sees again: x1
==Film, TV, or theatrical adaptations== * A 1965 film adaptation titled ''[[The Amorous Adventures of Moll Flanders]]'' starred [[Kim Novak]] as Moll Flanders and [[Richard Johnson (actor)|Richard Johnson]] as Jemmy with [[Angela Lansbury]] as Lady Blystone, with [[George Sanders]] as the banker, and [[Lilli Palmer]] as Dutchy. Some of the scenes were shot in [[Castle Lodge, Ludlow|Castle Lodge]], a [[Tudor style architecture|Tudor]] house in the centre of [[Ludlow]], Shropshire. * A 1975 two-part [[BBC]] [[television|TV]] adaptation, ''Moll Flanders'', adapted by [[Hugh Whitemore]], directed by Donald McWhinnie, and starring [[Julia Foster]] as Moll and [[Kenneth Haigh]] as Jemmy. * A musical adaptation was recorded in 1993 starring [[Josie Lawrence]] as Moll Flanders, with Musical Direction by Tony Castro. * A later American adaptation, [[Moll Flanders (1996 film)|''Moll Flanders'' (1996)]] starred [[Robin Wright (actress)|Robin Wright Penn]] as Moll Flanders and [[Morgan Freeman]] as Hibble, with [[Stockard Channing]] as Mrs. Allworthy. This adaptation Shares only the title character, as most elements of the original novel are missing. * A second British television adaptation, broadcast by [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] in 1996, titled ''[[The Fortunes and Misfortunes of Moll Flanders (TV series)|The Fortunes and Misfortunes of Moll Flanders]]'', with [[Alex Kingston]] starring as Moll and [[Daniel Craig]] as Jemmy. This film is one of the closest adaptations to the novel, though it ends when she is still a relatively young woman.
{{wikiquote|Moll Flanders}}

Includes a chapter on ''Moll Flanders''. * Watt, Ian “The Recent Critical Fortunes of Moll Flanders.” Eighteenth-Century Studies, vol. 1, no. 1, 1967.

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Murut people |image = [[File:KgKuaiKandazon Sabah Monsopiad-Cultural-Village-23.jpg|300px]] |caption = A Murut man in Monsopiad Cultural Village, Kg. Kuai Kandazon, [[Penampang]], [[Sabah]]. |population = 120,000 |popplace = {{flagcountry|MYS}}
{{smaller|[[Sabah]] including [[Labuan]]: 100,631 (2010){{cite web|url=http://www.statistics.gov.my/portal/download_Population/files/census2010/Taburan_Penduduk_dan_Ciri-ciri_Asas_Demografi.pdf|title= 2010 Population and Housing Census of Malaysia|language=Malay, English|accessdate=17 June 2012|publisher=Department of Statistics, Malaysia|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011081938/http://www.statistics.gov.my/portal/download_Population/files/census2010/Taburan_Penduduk_dan_Ciri-ciri_Asas_Demografi.pdf|archivedate=11 October 2012|deadurl=yes}} p. 107
[[Sarawak]]: 9,500 (1980){{cite book|author=William W. Bevis|title=Borneo Log: The Struggle For Sarawak's Forests|year=1995|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=0-2959-7416-8|page=152}}}}
{{flagcountry|IDN}}
{{smaller|[[Nunukan]], [[North Kalimantan]]: 56 513 (2016) , [[East Kalimantan]]}}
{{flagcountry|BRU}}
{{smaller|[[Temburong District|Temburong]]}} |langs = [[Murutic languages]], [[Malaysian language|Malaysian]] (those resident in Sabah, Sarawak and Labuan), [[English language|English]], [[Brunei Malay]] (those living in Temburong district) and [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] (those resident in Kalimantan) |rels = [[Christianity]] (predominantly), [[Islam]], [[Animism]] |related = [[Dayak people|Dayak]], [[Tidung people|Tidung]], [[Kelabit people|Kelabit]], [[Kayan people (Borneo)|Kayan]], [[Kenyah]], [[Melanau]], [[Lun Bawang]], [[Bidayuh]], [[Penan]], [[Punan]], [[Tagal]], [[Lun Bawang|Lundayeh]], [[Orang Ulu]] and other [[Austronesian people]]s }} The '''Murut''' are an indigenous [[ethnic group]], comprising 29 sub-ethnic groups inhabiting northern inland regions of [[Borneo]]. == Etymology == The literal translation of ''murut'' is "hill people".[http://indonesiatraveling.com/kalimantan/kalimantan-tribes/529-east-kalimantan-48-tribes.html literal translation of Murut] == Demographics == A large percentage of the Murut communities are in the southwest interior of [[Sabah]], [[East Malaysia]], specifically the districts of [[Keningau]], [[Tenom]], [[Nabawan]] and [[Beaufort, Malaysia|Beaufort]] along the Sapulut and Padas rivers. They can also be found inhabiting the border areas of [[Sarawak]], (especially around the [[Lawas]] and [[Limbang]] areas, where they are also referred to as Tagal people), [[North Kalimantan]] (traditionally concentrated in [[Malinau Regency|Malinau]] and [[Nunukan Regency|Nunukan]]) and [[Brunei]]. The Murut population in [[Brunei]] is mainly found in the sparsely populated [[Temburong]] district. They once supplied military might to the Sultans of Brunei. Their population has dwindled in recent years.[http://www.hawaii.edu/cseas/pubs/brunei/brunei.html Brunei: The Abode of Peace] - Retrieved 20 April 2007 They are defined as one of the seven indigenous groups that are considered to be [[Bumiputera (Brunei)|Bumiputera]] in Brunei. The Murut are divided between lowland (Timugon) and highland (Tagol) subgroups. They speak the [[Murutic languages]], a branch of the [[Austronesian languages|Austronesian family]]. The [[Tagol Murut language]] serves as their ''[[lingua franca]]''. ==Customs and religion== {{bar box |title=Religions of Muruts (Malaysians only) |titlebar= |left1=Religion |right1=Percent |float=right |bars= {{bar percent|[[Christianity]]|DodgerBlue|80.19}} {{bar percent|[[Islam]]|LimeGreen|18.04}} {{bar percent|[[Folk religion]] / Other religions|MediumVioletRed|0.21}} {{bar percent|[[Irreligion|No religion / Unknown]]|Gray|1.56}} }} The Murut were the last of Sabah's ethnic groups to renounce [[headhunting]]. As with the [[Iban people|Iban]] of [[Sarawak]], collecting heads of enemies traditionally served a very important role in Murut spiritual beliefs. For example, a man could only get married after he presented at least one head to the family of the desired girl. [[File:Sarawak; Murut tribeswomen at a head feast. Photograph. Wellcome V0037457.jpg|thumb|left|Murut tribeswomen at a head feast in [[Sarawak]], [[Malaysia]].]] The Murut were shifting cultivators of hill [[Rice|padi]] and [[tapioca]], supplementing their diet with [[Blowgun|blowpipe]] hunting and with some [[fishing]]. They live in communal [[longhouse]]s, usually near rivers, using the rivers as their highways. Most have now converted to [[Christianity]], with about a fifth of the population being Muslims. However they still maintain their culture. Traditional dress for men was a jacket made of tree bark (Artocarpus tamaran), a red [[loincloth]], and a headdress decorated with Argus [[pheasant]] feathers. Women wore a black sleeveless blouse and [[sarong]], which fell just below the knees. Like most of the other indigenous groups in Sabah, the Murut decorated their clothing with distinctive [[beadwork]] and also made belts out of old [[silver]] coins. Another belt made of reddish-brown glass beads plus yellow and blue beads was hung loosely around the waist. [[File:KgKuaiKandazon Sabah Monsopiad-Cultural-Village-24.jpg|thumb|right|Murut in traditional attire.]] Murut wedding or funeral feasts can last several days. Ancient Chinese jars hold a prominent status in Murut customs. Jars are also a place of spirits, and larger jars were formerly used as coffins. ===Musical heritage=== {{main|Agung}} The Murut have a musical heritage consisting of various types of [[Agung#In agung ensembles|agung ensembles]] - ensembles composed of large hanging, suspended or held, bossed/knobbed [[gong]]s which act as drone without any accompanying melodic instrument.{{cite web | last = Mercurio | first = Philip Dominguez | authorlink = | coauthors = | year = 2006 | url = http://www.pnoyandthecity.blogspot.com | title = Traditional Music of the Southern Philippines | work = PnoyAndTheCity: A center for Kulintang - A home for Pasikings | publisher = | accessdate = 25 February 2006 }}Matusky, Patricia. "An Introduction to the Major Instruments and Forms of Traditional Malay Music." Asian Music Vol 16. No. 2. (Spring-Summer 1985), pp. 121-182. Murut also used bamboo as a musical instrument, by using bamboo to compose a songs. Some musical instrument like tangkung (similar to that of a guitar, except it has only two strings) is made from wood. Tangkung is usually played during their leisure time. ===Antanum=== {{main|Antanum}} Antanum was a famous and influential Murut warrior from Sabah who according to local oral history claimed to have supernatural powers. Because of this he was able to receive support from the chiefs and villagers from around Keningau, Tenom, Pensiangan and [[Rundum]] and led the [[Rundum uprising]] against the [[British North Borneo Company]] but was killed during fighting with the company army in Sungai Selangit near Pensiangan.*{{Cite book | year=2008 | title=Federal-state relations in Sabah, Malaysia: the Berjaya administration, 1976-85 | author1=Regina Lim | author2= Institute of Southeast Asian Studies | publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies | isbn=9789812308122 | page=29 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bM4HifRARgYC&pg=PA29&dq=%22Antanum%22 | postscript=}} ==Sub-ethnic groups== [[File:Penampang Sabah HongkodKoisaanMuseum MurutLonghouse-01.jpg|thumb|right|Traditional Murut longhouse in [[Penampang]], [[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]].]] The Murut people are divided into three linguistic groups, namely:- * [[Murutic languages]] cluster: ** [[Okolod language|Okolod]] ([[North Kalimantan]], [[Indonesia]]) ** [[Keningau Murut language|Keningau Murut]] ([[Keningau]], [[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) ** [[Tagal Murut language|Tagal Murut]] ([[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) ** [[Paluan language|Paluan]] ([[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) ** [[Selungai Murut language|Selungai Murut]] ([[North Kalimantan]], [[Indonesia]]) ** [[Timugon language|Timugon Murut]] ([[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) * Northern languages cluster: ** [[Bookan language|Bookan]] ([[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) * [[Tidong languages]] cluster: ** [[Tidung people]] ([[Tarakan, North Kalimantan]], [[Indonesia]]) ** Bulungan people ([[Bulungan Regency]], [[North Kalimantan]], [[Indonesia]]) ** [[Kalabakan language|Kalabakan]] ([[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) ** [[Sembakung language|Tagal Dayaks / Sembakung Murut]] ([[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) ** [[Serudung language|Serudung Murut]] ([[Sabah]], [[Malaysia]]) ==Notable Figures== *[[Antanum]] - Murut warrior against the [[British North Borneo Company]] but was killed during fighting with the company army in Sungai Selangit near Pensiangan. *[[Ahmad Koroh]] - The fifth of [[Yang di-Pertua Negeri|Head of State]] of Sabah. *[[Mohamad Adnan Robert]] - The Sixth of [[Yang di-Pertua Negeri|Head of State]] of Sabah. *[[John Daukom]], Olympic sprinter.{{cite Sports-Reference |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/da/john-daukom-1.html |title=John Daukom Olympic Results |accessdate=15 August 2017}} == References == {{reflist}} {{Ethnic groups in Malaysia}} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Portal bar|Malaysia|Indonesia|Brunei|Society}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Malaysia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Sabah]] [[Category:Dayak people]] [[Category:Headhunting]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name= Naiche |birth_date= c. 1857 |death_date= {{death date|1919|3|16}} |image= Chief Naiche.png |caption= Chiricahua Chokonen N'de Chief Naiche, Arizona |nickname= |birth_place= Chiricahua country |death_place= [[Mescalero, New Mexico]]|cause of death= natural causes |resting_place= |allegiance=Chiricahua Apache Indians |serviceyears= 1880–1886 |rank= Chief or Leader of Chiricahua Apaches |unit= |commands= |battles=[[Apache Wars]] |awards= |relations=[[Cochise]] (father) |laterwork=artist }} '''Chief Naiche''' (ca. 1857-1919) was the final hereditary [[Tribal chief|chief]] of the [[Chiricahua]] band of [[Apache Indians]].<ref name=ohs>Johansen, Bruce E. [http://digital.library.okstate.edu/encyclopedia/entries/N/NA003.html "Naiche (ca. 1857—1919)."] ''Oklahoma Historical Society's Encyclopedia of Oklahoma History and Culture.'' (retrieved 25 Sept 2011)</ref>
==Background== Naiche, whose name in English means "meddlesome one" or "mischief maker", is alternately spelled Nache, Nachi, or Natchez.<ref name=ohs/>
He was the youngest son of [[Cochise]] and his wife [[Dos-teh-seh]] (''Dos-tes-ey'', - "Something-at-the-campfire-already-cooked", b. 1838), His older brother was [[Tah-zay]] aka [[Chief Taza]].<ref name="Delgadillo2013">{{cite book|last=Delgadillo|first=Alicia|title=From Fort Marion to Fort Sill: A Documentary History of the Chiricahua Apache Prisoners of War, 1886-1913|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iIrWsLDXRqUC&pg=PA193|date=1 June 2013|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=978-0-8032-4625-6|pages=193–}}</ref>
Naiche was described as a tall, handsome man with a dignified bearing that reflected the Apache equivalent of a royal bloodline as the son of Cochise (leader of the Chihuicahui local group of the Chokonen and principal chief of the Chokonen band of the Chiricahua Apache) and Dos-teh-seh, daughter of the great Warm Spring/Mimbreño Chief Mangas Coloradas.<ref name="Robinson2016"/> [[Britton Davis]] described him as being 6'1" inheight, which was tall for an Apache.<ref name="Delgadillo2013"/>
He had three wives: Haozinne, E-Clah-heh and Na-deh-yole and six children.<ref name="Robinson2016">{{cite book|last=Robinson|first=Sherry|title=Apache Voices: Their Stories of Survival as Told to Eve Ball|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LjFIDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT77|date=25 April 2016|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-1848-0|page=77}}</ref>
==Career== Upon the death of his father Cochise in 1874, Naiche's brother Taza became the chief; however, Taza died a few years later in 1876, and the office went to Naiche. In the 1880s, Naiche and Geronimo successfully went to war together.<ref name="Delgadillo2013"/>
In 1880, Naiche traveled to [[Mexico]] with [[Geronimo]]'s band, to avoid [[forced relocation]] to the [[San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation]] in [[Arizona]]. They surrendered in 1883 but escaped the reservation in 1885, back into Mexico.<ref name="Sheridan1998">{{cite book|last=Sheridan|first=Thomas E.|title=A History of the Southwest: The Land and Its People|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=msXwj_0eVRYC&pg=PA41|year=1998|publisher=Western National Parks Association|isbn=978-1-877856-76-1|pages=41–42}}</ref>
Officially the leader of the last band of renegade Apaches in the Southwest, Naiche and Geronimo surrendered to General Nelson Miles in 1886.<ref name="Kraft2000">{{cite book|last=Kraft|first=Louis|title=Gatewood and Geronimo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fIW7CwAAQBAJ&pg=PT203|date=1 June 2000|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=978-0-8263-5405-1|page=203}}</ref>
Naiche and other Apaches requested to return to [[Arizona]], while still imprisoned in Fort Marion. The US did not allow their return, but [[Kiowa]] and [[Comanche]] tribes offered to share their reservations in southwestern [[Oklahoma]] with the Chiricahua, so Naiche and 295 members of his band moved to [[Fort Sill, Oklahoma]], where they became the [[Fort Sill Apache Tribe]]. In 1913, Naiche moved to the [[Mescalero Indian Reservation]] in [[New Mexico]].<ref name="Champagne1994">{{cite book|last=Champagne|first=Duane|title=Chronology of Native North American History: From Pre-Columbian Times to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=210YAAAAIAAJ|year=1994|publisher=Gale Research|isbn=978-0-8103-9195-6|page=184}}</ref> [[File:Naiche ChiriApache hidepainting 1900 OHS.jpg|right|thumb|150x150px|Naiche's painting]] Naiche had the reputation of being the finest Indian artist of that period. He painted his pictures on deer skin in color. His subjects were flowers, deer, other wild animals, turkey, and various objects of nature, as he saw them. He also carved canes from wood and painted them in different colors.<ref name="Griffin-Pierce2013">{{cite book|last=Griffin-Pierce|first=Trudy|title=The Columbia Guide to American Indians of the Southwest|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LdrmWsXR7poC&pg=PA124|date=13 August 2013|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0-231-52010-2|page=124}}</ref>
==Death== Naiche died of influenza on March 16, 1919 in [[Mescalero, New Mexico]].<ref name=ohs/>
Among his descendents: *[[Elbys Onea Naiche Hugar]] *[[Silas Cohise]]
==In fiction== Naiche is one of the central characters in the novel ''Cry of Eagles'' by [[William W. Johnstone]]. The story features Naiche leading a renegade band of Apache in open warfare against white settlers and miners as they attempt to join Geronimo in Mexico. In the final chapter Naiche is killed by the books protagonist, Falcon MacCallister.<ref>William W. Johnstone ''Cry of Eagles''. Published October 1999, Pinnacle Books/Kennsington Publishing Corp.</ref> Naiche is played by [[Rex Reason]] in [[Douglas Sirk]]'s film ''[[Taza, Son of Cochise]]''.
Naiche identified as "Chief Nachez" was a character in Season 6 Episode 22 of "The Life And Legend of Wyatt Earp". This episode aired on March 7, 1961. In the episode the Chief Nachez character turns to [[Wyatt Earp]] for help in stopping the selling of liquor to members of his tribe. The "Nachez" character was played by George Keymas.<ref name="Lentz1997">{{cite book|last=Lentz|first=Harris M.|title=Television Westerns Episode Guide: All United States Series, 1949-1996|date=1 January 1997|publisher=McFarland & Company|isbn=978-0-7864-0377-6|page=272}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
