{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{redirect|Lord Wei|other uses|Wei (surname)}} {{Infobox Politician |honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] |name = The Lord Wei |native_name = {{lang|zh-Hant|韋鳴恩/韦鸣恩}} |native_name_lang = |honorific-suffix = |image = Official portrait of Lord Wei crop 2.jpg |imagesize = |smallimage = |caption = |office = [[Members of the House of Lords|Member]] of the [[House of Lords]]
[[Lords Temporal|Lord Temporal]] |term_start = 28 May 2010
[[Life peer|Life Peerage]] |term_end = |birthname = Nathanael Ming-Yan Wei |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1977|1|19}} |birth_place = [[Watford]], Hertfordshire, England |residence = [[Shoreditch]], London, England |death_date = |death_place = |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |nationality = British |party = [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] |occupation = Member of the [[House of Lords]]
[[Social entrepreneur]] |spouse = Cynthia Wei |children = 2 |education= [[Bachelor of Arts#United Kingdom and Ireland|BA]] (Hons) French and German | alma_mater = [[Jesus College, Oxford]] }} '''Nathanael Ming-Yan Wei, Baron Wei''' ({{zh|t=韋鳴恩|s=韦鸣恩|p=Wéi Míng'ēn|j=Wai5 Ming4 Jan1|first=t}}){{cite web|title=視頻：英國華裔男爵韋鳴恩專訪一|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/zhongwen/trad/multimedia/2010/06/100616_vid_nat_wei_1.shtml|work=BBC 中文网|publisher=BBC|accessdate=30 September 2011|author=BBC 中文网|authorlink=BBC|date=17 June 2010|trans-title=Video: British Chinese baron Nat Wei Exclusive Interview 1}} (born 19 January 1977), also known as '''Nat Wei''', is an English [[social entrepreneur]] with an interest in [[social reform]]. He is the first British-born person of Chinese origin to have become a member of the [[House of Lords]], sitting as a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]]. He was also the youngest member of the House from 2010 to 2016.[http://www.parliament.uk/about/faqs/house-of-lords-faqs/lords-members/ UK Parliament] He was previously an adviser to the [[UK Government]] on their [[Big Society]] project.{{cite press release |url=http://www.number10.gov.uk/news/topstorynews/2010/05/big-society-50248 |title=Government launches Big Society programme |publisher=No 10 (British Prime Minister's Office) |date=18 May 2010 |accessdate=6 February 2011}} Lord Wei is the founding and former{{cite web |author=Lord Wei|authorlink=Nat Wei, Baron Wei| url=http://www.bigsociety.sidekickstudios.net/wp-content/uploads/2010/07/Letter-to-Francis-Maude-Acceptance-from-Lord-Wei.pdf |title=Letter to Francis Maude : Acceptance of appointment as Government adviser for Big Society |date=1 July 2010 |publisher=Big Society Network |accessdate=6 February 2011}} partner of the Shaftesbury Partnership,{{cite news|title=Pass notes No 2,921: Lord Wei|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2011/feb/02/pass-notes-lord-wei|accessdate=30 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2 February 2011 |location=London}} a member of the founding team of [[Teach First]] and a former adviser at [[Absolute Return For Kids]].{{cite news|last=Ramesh|first=Randeep|title=Interview with Mr Big Society|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/jun/22/nat-wei-big-society-adviser-conservatives|accessdate=30 September 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=22 June 2010|location=London}} He is a former fellow of the [[Young Foundation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.youngfoundation.org/news/young-foundation-fellow-appointed-new-advisor-government|title=Young Foundation fellow appointed new advisor to Government|publisher=The Young Foundation|accessdate=30 September 2011|authorlink=Young Foundation|date=19 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930100416/http://www.youngfoundation.org/news/young-foundation-fellow-appointed-new-advisor-government|archivedate=30 September 2011|df=dmy-all}} and a [[World Economic Forum|World Economic Forum Young Global Leader]]. Lord Wei is also the Chairman of the [[Conservative Friends of the Chinese]]. ==Early life== Lord Wei is the son of [[British Hong Kong|Hongkong]] parents[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201011/ldhansrd/text/100616-0006.htm] with [[Hakka]] Chinese ancestry.{{cite web |url=http://www.neehao.co.uk/2012/01/lord-weis-speech-on-the-role-of-overseas-chinese-in-britain/ |title=There is a saying, in Hakka, When everyone collects firewood, the flames rise high }}{{cite web |url=http://www.cbg88.co.uk/ygxw/2012/06-27/129.shtml |title=33岁华人新贵——韦鸣恩 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016005223/http://www.cbg88.co.uk/ygxw/2012/06-27/129.shtml |archivedate=16 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/jun/22/nat-wei-big-society-adviser-conservatives |title=Interview with Mr Big Society |date=22 June 2010 |work=The Guardian |first=Randeep |last=Ramesh |accessdate=6 February 2011 |location=London}} Wei's father was a pastor who moved to Britain in the 1970s.{{cn|date=September 2016}} He was born in [[Watford]] and grew up in [[Milton Keynes]] and [[Tooting]], London.{{cn|date=September 2016}} ==Education== Lord Wei was educated at the Sir Frank Markham Community School, a state comprehensive school in [[Milton Keynes]] (since closed, and replaced by the [[Milton Keynes Academy]] on the same site),[http://www.miltonkeynes.co.uk/news/local/end-of-an-era-as-school-s-out-for-the-last-time-1-869843 End of an Era as School's Out for the Last Time] Published by: MiltonKeynes.co.uk Date: 21 July 2009. Retrieved 27 November 2012 where some of the pupils snorted cocaine and even burned down a wing of the school, and bullied him for taking his studies seriously.{{cite news |url=http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/news/Article/1073408/Rosamund-McCarthy-baiting-Lord-Wei-unsavoury---hes-no-saint-offer/ |title=Nat Wei in Third Sector |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326133840/http://www.thirdsector.co.uk/news/Article/1073408/Rosamund-McCarthy-baiting-Lord-Wei-unsavoury---hes-no-saint-offer/ |archivedate=26 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} However, in a later account of his school life, Wei appeared to contradict this account, stating that as he 'got good grades, but was also sporty', he was never targeted or bullied. The only pupil from his school year to attend the [[University of Oxford]], he studied [[Modern Languages]] at [[Jesus College, Oxford|Jesus College]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/jun/22/nat-wei-big-society-adviser-conservatives |title=Nat Wei Big Society Adviser Conservative | location=London | work=The Guardian |first=Randeep |last=Ramesh |date=22 June 2010}} He is also actively learning [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] at the [[London School of Economics]], and has a working knowledge of [[Cantonese]], French and German.{{cn|date=September 2016}} ==Life and career== After graduating from Jesus College, Oxford, Wei worked at [[McKinsey & Company]] for three years,{{cite web |url=http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/content/lord-wei-shoreditch-london-borough-hackney |title=Lord Nat Wei, Government Adviser for Big Society |publisher=Cabinet Office |accessdate=6 February 2011}} where he came to know Brett Wigdortz, who founded [[Teach First]] in 2002.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} In 2006, after three years at Teach First and a short stint in [[social venture capital]], Wei joined the children's charity [[Absolute Return for Kids]] (ARK) where he helped to set up [[Future Leaders]],{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2007/jan/02/schools.uk |title=Preparing for power |work=The Guardian |date=2 January 2007 |first=Polly |last=Curtis |accessdate=6 February 2011 |location=London}} a programme seeking to attract, develop and place high-potential teachers and future leaders of urban schools. ===Founding the Shaftesbury Partnership=== Around the same time as helping to set up Future Leaders, in early 2006, Wei founded the Shaftesbury Partnership, an organisation which seeks to emulate the great [[social reform]]ers of the [[Victorian era]] by creating scalable social reforms. The Shaftesbury Partnership are currently working on a number of projects around [[House|housing]], unemployment and healthcare. Through the Shaftesbury Partnership, Wei co-founded The Challenge Network,{{cite news |first=John |last=Rentoul |title=Like it or not, there it is. A Tory policy |work=The Independent |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/john-rentoul/john-rentoul-like-it-or-not-there-it-is-a-tory-policy-1825377.html |date=22 November 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2011 |location=London}} an independent charity which exists to "inspire and connect people to strengthen their community". The Challenge Network runs a two-month civic service programme called The Challenge which has attracted strong interest from both government and opposition.{{cite news |first=Janaki |last=Mahadevan |url=http://www.cypnow.co.uk/news/ByDiscipline/Youth-Work/895212/Charity-test-concept-National-Citizen-Service/ |title=Charity to test the concept of National Citizen Service |date=2 April 2009 |accessdate=6 February 2011}} In 2011, the Shaftesbury Partnership working with [[Johnson & Johnson]] and [[Queen's Nursing Institute|Queens Nursing Institute]] and [[Buckinghamshire New University]] piloted NurseFirst{{cite web |url=http://www.nursefirst.org.uk |title=NurseFirst}} – a clinicians in the community development programme to produce a network of innovators who can create real change for patients, people and communities. In 2013, a report{{cite report |url=http://www.nursefirst.org.uk/twoyearson.pdf |title=Nurse First two years on |date=31 May 2013}} on the pilot, 2 years on, concluded that first cohort of clinicians showed quantitative and qualitative improvements in their confidence, their leadership skills, their ability to innovate and their ability to make clinical innovation happen. They produced financially sustainable business plans for £1.2 million of cash releasing savings over 3 years. The programme is now being scaled up. For the individual, retirement – like many other life transitions – can be a challenging time, involving difficult lifestyle changes and choices. This is often compounded by other transitions such as starting to care for grandchildren, relocation, illness, and bereavement. Against the current backdrop of austerity and rising health and social care needs, there is an urgent need to support retirees in managing these transitions. Since summer 2013, after the publication of a report by Lord Wei entitled, "Next steps: Life transitions and retirement in the 21st century”{{cite report |url=http://natwei.com/social-reform/transitions-retirement/ |title=Next steps: Life transitions and retirement in the 21st century |date=1 July 2013}} supported by the [[Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation]], Shaftesbury Partnership have been developing a Retirement Transition Initiative, designed to equip people who are around the retirement transition with the information, networks, resilience, and opportunities they need to continue purposeful activity post-retirement. It will aim to improve the economic outcomes, health, and wellbeing of both the individual and their community. === Social reform === On 18 May 2010 at the launch of the [[Conservative – Liberal Democrat Coalition Agreement|New Coalition Government policies]] on [[Big Society]] to a group of community leaders, Lord Wei was appointed as an unpaid [[:wikt:advisor|Government Adviser]] on [[Big Society]]. He was based at the [[Office for Civil Society]] in the [[Cabinet Office]]{{cite press release |url=http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/newsroom/news_releases/2010/100518-news-nat-wei.aspx |archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100708170347/http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/newsroom/news_releases/2010/100518-news-nat-wei.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2010-07-08 |title=Big Society champion appointed Government advisor |date=18 May 2010 |publisher=Cabinet Office |accessdate=6 February 2011}} where he worked one day a week{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08zc1z9|title=Lord Wei in Milton Keynes, Series 1, A Place Called Home - BBC Radio 4|website=BBC|access-date=2017-08-06}}, and advised the Government on all aspects of taking forward the Big Society and driving implementation across government. [[File:Lord Wei Nomination.jpg|thumb|Press Release: General statement in response to Nat Wei’s nomination to House of Lords and appointment as advisor to the Government on Big Society]]At the launch event, the Prime Minister, [[David Cameron]], announced that Wei would also be appointed a [[life peer]]. He was [[Introduction (House of Lords)|introduced]] in the House of Lords on 3 June 2010 as '''Baron Wei''', of [[Shoreditch]] in the [[London Borough of Hackney]].{{London Gazette|issue=59437 |date=3 June 2010 |page=10273 }}{{cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201011/ldhansrd/text/100603-0001.htm#10060340000777 |title=House of Lords debates (3 June 2010, 11:00 am): Introduction: Lord Wei |publisher=Hansard : House of Lords : 3 June 2010 : Column 365 |accessdate=6 February 2011}} He is the third person of Chinese ethnic origin to become a member of the House of Lords, after [[Lydia Dunn, Baroness Dunn|Baroness Dunn]] (who is not domiciled in the UK) and the late [[Michael Chan, Baron Chan|Lord Chan]]; the third person of Hong Kong ancestry to become a House of Lords member, after Baroness Dunn and the late [[Lord Kadoorie]]; and the first-ever member of Chinese origin to be British born. He is also one of the youngest people to have been made a life peer, at the age of 33.[[Rupert Mitford, 6th Baron Redesdale|Lord Redesdale]] was slightly younger than Wei when he was made a life peer in 2000; however he had sat in the House of Lords as a hereditary peer prior to the reforms of 1999. {{cite journal |last=Randall |first=Nicholas |title=Youngest peer to take his seat |journal=The House Magazine |date= 28 May 2010 |url=http://www.epolitix.com/house-magazine/housemag-article/newsarticle/youngest-peer-to-take-his-seat/ |accessdate=13 February 2011}} Due to his role as Government Advisor Lord Wei stepped down from any direct, formal involvement in the organisations he had previously been involved with. On 24 May 2011, Lord Wei announced his decision to step down from his role as Government Advisor on Big Society to help as a volunteer to drive the practical development of Big Society ideas in communities.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-13529808|title=PM's Big Society tsar stands down|date=24 May 2011 | publisher=BBC News}}{{cite web |url=http://www.natwei.com/ |title=Nat Wei's website }} The Prime Minister, [[David Cameron]] said 'Nat has worked incredibly hard over two years to help develop policies that support the Big Society. He has played an important role in delivering key initiatives like Community Organisers, [[National Citizen Service]], and the [[Big Society Capital|Big Society Bank]]."{{cite press release |url=http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/news/lord-wei-stands-down|title=Lord Wei stands down}} Previously, Lord Wei had also cited personal financial difficulties that he had suffered as a result of the demands of his part-time position.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/how-my-top-government-job-left-me-almost-penniless-and-unable-to-support-my-family-6563509.html|title=How my top government job left me almost penniless and unable to|date=2011-02-04|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-08-06|language=en-GB}} Subsequently, Lord Wei has been involved in a number of initiatives involving networks of individuals who have a vision to improve society, address poverty, and tackle injustice. These have been in three main areas; work to establish training and research to help people, particularly from or interested in having entrepreneurial, financial, and business backgrounds to become active and effective social reformers finding and promoting scalable solutions for today's social challenges, work to harness the power of faith based action, work to promote philanthropy among corporate business owners, to share wealth through sharing ownership to tackle poverty. === Chinese background === Lord Wei's ancestry can be traced back to a village in [[Zhuhai]], on the southern coast of the [[Guangdong]]. His ancestral home is two villages away from that of [[Sun Yat-sen]], the founding father of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]], about whom incidentally, Wei enjoys reading and learning. As the only current ethnic Chinese peer in The House of Lords, and the first member of Chinese ethnic origin to have been born and brought up in the UK, Lord Wei takes an interest in [[British Chinese]] community issues, particularly in social reform. He is also interested in economic and cultural ties between the UK and China. He is the most senior ethnic Chinese politician in the European Union. Lord Wei states "Global growth has been powered by and will continue to be boosted by Asia, particularly China and other parts of the region including increasingly South East Asia. Much of Britain and other Western countries future jobs and growth will come from engaging with the East by harnessing its investment and entering its markets.” His focus in working with East Asia comprises now of work within the Conservative Party{{cite web |url=http://www.conservativefriendsofthechinese.co.uk/ |title=Conservative Friends of the Chinese}} to help engage ethnic East Asian voters and help them gain the voice, representation and participation that they need as Britain's third largest minority group. Up to July 2015, he worked in Parliament through the All Party Parliamentary Group [[APPG]] for East Asian Business which he chaired, the All Party Parliamentary China Group{{cite web |url=http://appcg.org.uk/ |title=All Party Parliamentary China Group}} of which he was the vice-Chair (special focus on Hong Kong), and the All Party Parliamentary Group for Trade and Investment{{cite web |url=http://trade.appg.co.uk/ |title=All Party Parliamentary Group for Trade and Investment}} of which he was treasurer to promote better trade and political and cultural links between the UK and East Asia and work to encourage the next generation of East Asians and other diaspora to develop the leadership skills to play a greater role in public life, in society, and business, and in harnessing the resources that East Asians have globally and locally both financial and non-financial to address global and local problems today.These groups were discontinued after the May 2015 election. In 2012, [[Manchester]] local government commissioned Lord Wei to write a report on how Manchester can best engage with China. Following that Report,{{cite web |url=http://neweconomymanchester.com/stories/1651 |title=The Wei Report}} a Manchester-China Forum{{cite web |url=http://www.investinmanchester.com/services/networks/manchester-china-forum/ |title=Manchester China Forum}} was established which hosts regular activities to help member businesses share information and knowledge, including seminars, meet-the-buyer events, and other networking opportunities. Lord Wei continues to work as a non-executive director of the Forum.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} === Other === In 2013, Lord Wei was invited to become a [[World Economic Forum|World Economic Forum Young Global Leader]]. In 2015, Lord Wei became a member of the [[European Union Committee|House of Lords EU Internal Affairs Sub-Committee]].{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/lords-select/eu-internal-market-subcommittee/ |title=EU Internal Affairs Sub-Committee}} He stepped down from this Committee in June 2018. ==Personal life== Lord Wei is a Christian.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2010/jun/22/nat-wei-big-society-adviser-conservatives|title=Interview with Mr Big Society|first=Randeep|last=Ramesh|date=23 June 2010|work=The Guardian}} He is married and has two sons.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/how-my-top-government-job-left-me-almost-penniless-and-unable-to-support-my-family-6563509.html|title=How my top government job left me almost penniless and unable to|date=2011-02-04|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-08-06|language=en-GB}} ==See also== * [[European politicians of Chinese descent]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.natwei.com/ Official website] * [http://www.shaftesburypartnership.org The Shaftesbury Partnership] * [http://www.arkonline.org Absolute Return for Kids] * [http://www.the-challenge.org The Challenge] * [http://www.teachfirst.org.uk Teach First] * [http://www.future-leaders.org.uk Future Leaders] * [http://www.conservativefriendsofthechinese.co.uk/ Conservative Friends of the Chinese] * [http://appcg.org.uk/ All Party Parliamentary China Group] * [http://trade.appg.co.uk/ All Party Parliamentary Group for Trade and Investment] ===Videos=== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v524XxVmTn4 Nat Wei, executive chair of The Big Society Network] {{DEFAULTSORT:Wei, Nat}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:British people of Chinese descent]] Jesus College, Oxford]] [[Category:British political consultants]] [[Category:British management consultants]] [[Category:Social entrepreneurs]] [[Category:British politicians of Hong Kong descent]] revision.text:
[[File:Fr 20120813152520d-100.jpg|thumb|upright|Nathan Jackson at work in his studio in August 2012.]] '''Nathan Jackson''' (born August 29, 1938)<ref name=nea/> is an [[Alaska Natives|Alaska Native]] artist. He is among the most important living [[Tlingit people|Tlingit]] artists<ref>{{cite web|title=Contemporary artists: Tlingit|url=http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/totems/contemporary/tlingit.php|publisher=[[American Museum of Natural History]]|accessdate=April 2, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429233939/http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/totems/contemporary/tlingit.php|archivedate=April 29, 2011|df=}}</ref> and the most important [[Alaska]]n artists.<ref name=je>{{cite news|last=Dunham|first=Mike|title=Tlingit 'peace' headpiece now in Juneau museum|url=http://juneauempire.com/stories/083110/loc_702538776.shtml|newspaper=[[Juneau Empire]]|date=August 31, 2010}}</ref> He is best known for his [[totem pole]]s, but works in a variety of media.
Jackson belongs to the Sockeye [[Tlingit clans|clan]] on the Raven side of the Chilkoot Tlingit.<ref name=nea/> As a young adult, he served in the military in [[Germany]], and then became involved in commercial fishing. While ill with [[pneumonia]] and unable to fish, he began to carve miniature totem poles. His interest in art was piqued, and he enrolled in the [[Institute of American Indian Arts]] in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]], [[New Mexico]]. Since then, Jackson's work has included large totem poles, canoes, carved doors, wood panel clan crests, masks, and jewelry. Jackson has worked to pass on traditional Tlingit carving skills to younger artists, and has offered many demonstrations and workshops in Alaska and the Pacific Northwest.<ref name=nea/>
Jackson has created more than 50 totem poles,<ref name=via>{{cite news|last=Rennicke|first=Jeff|title=Totem poles|url=http://www.viamagazine.com/attractions/totem-poles|newspaper=Via|publisher=AAA Northern California, Nevada and Utah|date=May–June 2008}}</ref> some of which are on display in the [[National Museum of the American Indian]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Kaats (depicting the story of a man who lived with a bear family)|url=http://www.nmai.si.edu/searchcollections/item.aspx?irn=280007&catids=0&areaid=16&src=1-1&size=75&page=12|publisher=[[National Museum of the American Indian]]|accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref> the [[Field Museum]] in Chicago,<ref name=field>{{cite news|title=Field Museum's new totem pole erected|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/17919655/ns/travel-destination_travel/|newspaper=MSNBC.com (Associated Press)|date=April 2, 2007}}</ref> [[Harvard University]]'s [[Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology|Peabody Museum]],<ref>{{cite web|title=NAGPRA in the Museum GalleriesNAGPRA in the Museum Galleries|url=http://www.peabody.harvard.edu/node/313|publisher=[[Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology]]|accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref> and other museums in the United States, Europe, and Japan.<ref name=nea/> Other totem poles stand outside [[Juneau-Douglas High School]],<ref name=list/> Juneau's [[Centennial Hall]],<ref name=list/><ref name="Stewart1993">{{cite book|author=Hilary Stewart|title=Looking at totem poles|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WSueEr81v0IC&pg=PA183|year=1993|publisher=Douglas & McIntyre|isbn=978-1-55054-074-1|pages=171, 183}}</ref> in Juneau's [[Sealaska]] Building,<ref name=list>{{cite news|title=A list of local totem poles|url=http://juneauempire.com/stories/082610/art_700570930.shtml|newspaper=[[Juneau Empire]]|date=August 26, 2010}}</ref> in [[Totem Bight State Historical Park]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Totem Poles at Totem Bight State Historical Park|url=http://dnr.alaska.gov/parks/units/totempol.htm|publisher=Alaska Division of Parks and Outdoor Recreation|accessdate=April 2, 2011}}</ref> at the [[Alaska Native Heritage Center]],<ref name=je/> at [[Saxman Totem Park]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Holing|first=Dwight|title=Totems speak of another way|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0mUaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iCoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6877,4938021|newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal]]|date=February 22, 1987|page=H1}}</ref> and at the [[Totem Heritage Center]] in [[Ketchikan]].<ref name="Stewart1993"/>
He is a recipient of a 1995 [[National Heritage Fellowship]] from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]],<ref name=nea>{{cite web |url=https://www.arts.gov/honors/heritage/fellows/nathan-jackson |title=Nathan Jackson |author=<!--Not stated--> |website=www.arts.gov |publisher=[[National Endowment for the Arts]]|access-date=November 22, 2017}}</ref> a [[Rasmuson Foundation]] Distinguished Artist Award (2009),<ref name=rasmuson>{{cite web|last=Stalzer|first=Cassandra|title=Nathan Jackson receives $25,000 Distinguished Artist Award; Foundation Also Names Eight Fellows, 17 Project Grants|url=http://www.rasmuson.org/PressRelease/index.php?switch=view_pressrelease&iReleaseID=206|publisher=[[Rasmuson Foundation]]|accessdate=April 2, 2011|date=May 15, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720174414/http://www.rasmuson.org/PressRelease/index.php?switch=view_pressrelease&iReleaseID=206|archivedate=July 20, 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Dunham|first=Mike|title=Rasmuson Grants are announced|url=http://www.adn.com/2009/05/16/798087/rasmuson-grants-are-announced.html|newspaper=[[Anchorage Daily News]]|date=May 16, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004053407/http://www.adn.com/2009/05/16/798087/rasmuson-grants-are-announced.html|archivedate=October 4, 2012|df=}}</ref> and an honorary doctorate in humanities from the [[University of Alaska Southeast]].<ref name=nea/>
Jackson currently resides in Ketchikan, Alaska.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nathan Jackson receives $25,000 Distinguished Artist Award|url=http://www.capitalcityweekly.com/stories/052009/new_442015051.shtml|accessdate=April 3, 2011|newspaper=[[Capital City Weekly]]|date=May 20, 2009}}</ref> His wife and son are also artists.<ref name=field/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{Infobox person |name = Nathaniel Reed |image = Texasjack.jpg |image_size = |caption = A photograph of Reed which appeared on the title page of his 1936 autobiography ''The Life of Texas Jack''. |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1862|3|23}} |birth_place = [[Madison County, Arkansas]], United States |death_date = {{death date and age|1950|1|7|1862|3|23}} |death_place = [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = American |other_names = Texas Jack Reed |known_for = Outlaw and train robber in the Indian Territory during the 1880s and 1890s |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |home_town = |title = |salary = |networth = |height = |weight = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }}
'''Nathaniel "Texas Jack" Reed''' (March 23, 1862 – January 7, 1950) was a 19th-century American outlaw responsible for many stagecoach, bank, and train robberies throughout the [[American Southwest]] during the 1880s and '90s. He acted on his own and also led a bandit gang, operating particularly in the [[Rocky Mountains]] and [[Indian Territory]].
Reed is claimed to have been the last survivor of the ''"47 most notorious outlaws"'' of Indian Territory.<ref name="County News">Haile, Bartee. [http://www.dibollfreepress.com/news/2008/0102/news/010.html "This Week in Texas: Old West relic dies in his sleep"], ''Diboll Free Press'', January 2, 2008. Accessed June 3, 2008. "Texas Jack started the new century by turning over a new leaf. Trading his sixguns for a Bible, he preached the gospel as an itinerant evangelist."</ref> He became an [[Evangelism|evangelist]] in his later years, and could often be seen on the streets of Tulsa preaching against the dangers of following a "life of crime".<ref name="County News"/><ref>"TEXAS JACK, 87, ONCE SOUTHWEST OUTLAW", ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 9, 1950. "The penitent badman then became an evangelist and toured the country with a wagon and team of horses"</ref> His memoirs were published in the 1930s, and are considered valuable collectors' items (one copy was reportedly sold on the [[internet]] for $1,500 in 2007).<ref name="Tulsa World"/> He claimed to have ridden with the [[Dalton gang]], [[Bill Doolin]], [[Henry Starr]] and other outlaws and bandits of the old west. He may have also helped [[Cherokee Bill]], a fellow outlaw from the Indian Territory, in his escape from [[Fort Smith National Historic Site|Fort Smith]] during the 1880s.<ref name="Tulsa World"/>
As with many others of the era, Reed's colorful stories of his almost 10-year career as an outlaw were probably exaggerated by later writers.<ref name="Tulsa World"/> He claimed to have ridden briefly with the Daltons, and participated in their dual bank robberies in [[Coffeyville]] in 1892, as well as in the infamous 1893 [[Battle of Ingalls|gunfight at Ingalls]]. However, there is no corroborating evidence that he was involved in either of those events.<ref name="Tulsa World"/>
==Biography== ===Early life=== Reed was born in [[Madison County, Arkansas]]. His father, Mason Henry Reed, was killed in action fighting for the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War]], probably at the [[Battle of Campbell's Station]] on November 16, 1863.<ref name="County News"/> His mother was Sarah Elizabeth Prater. Reed lived with a number of relatives, including his maternal grandparents, until 1883 when, at the age of 21, he moved to the American frontier.<ref name="Great Train Robberies">Wilson, R. Michael. ''Great Train Robberies of the Old West''. Guilford, Connecticut: Globe Pequot, 2007. (pg. 94-101) {{ISBN|0-7627-4150-3}}</ref> He worked at various jobs in [[Idaho]], [[Wyoming]], [[Colorado]], [[Texas]] until he reached [[Oklahoma]], where he became a ranch hand for the Tarry outfit.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/>
During the summer of 1885, his foreman recruited him to rob a train at [[La Junta, Colorado]].<ref name="County News"/> In the course of the robbery, Reed entered the passenger car firing his pistol to keep the passengers under control.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> He later received $6,000 for his part in the hold up.<ref name="County News"/><ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> Encouraged by this success, Reed gave up working as a cowboy and became an outlaw. During the next nine years he and his gang robbed trains, stagecoaches, banks and, on one occasion, captured a large shipment of bullion in California.<ref name="Drago">Drago, Harry Sinclair. ''The Organized Bands of Bank and Train Robbers Who Terrorized the Prairie Towns of Missouri, Kansas, Indian Territory and Oklahoma for Half a Century''. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1998. (pg. 195-199) {{ISBN|0-8032-6612-X}}</ref>
===Robbery at Blackstone Switch=== During the early 1890s, when he was living near [[Muskogee, Oklahoma]],<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> Reed learned that a gold shipment was leaving [[Dallas, Texas]] on November 13, 1894. He recruited [[Buz Luckey]], [[William Smith (outlaw)|William "Will" Smith]] and [[Tom Root (outlaw)|Tom Root]], and selected [[Blackstone Switch]] at [[Wybark]] as the site for the robbery. The plan was for Reed to throw the switch as the train approached then, as it entered onto a sidetrack, the gang would use dynamite to enter the express car. Root, a full-blooded Cherokee known for his size and strength, would enter the express car, break open the strong boxes, and bring out the gold. Smith would hold a gun on the engineer and fireman while Luckey stayed with the horses.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/>
Despite their practice staged-robbery the previous day,<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> as the ''Katy No. 2'' approached, Reed threw the switch too early. Engineer Joseph Hotchkiss stopped the train when he saw the signal light change,<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> far short of the siding. Reed and the others were forced to run towards the train yelling and shooting. Hotchkiss and the fireman alerted the messengers using the bell cord connected to the car and jumped off the train to hide in a small ravine nearby.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/>
The railroad company had anticipated the possibility of a robbery, and had moved the gold to another train, putting in its place several armed messengers to guard the express car including [[Bud Ledbetter]], [[Paden Tolbert]], [[Sid Johnson]], [[Frank Jones (lawman)|Frank Jones]].<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> When Reed and the others approached the express car, he called for the messengers to leave the car. When they refused, Reed and Root took cover behind some trees and began shooting into the car. The messengers returned fire, resulting in a gunfight that lasted for nearly an hour. Eventually one of Reed's men was killed; Reed jumped onto the train and went through the passenger cars forcing passengers to put their valuables into a sack before he and his gang fled.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/>
As they rode away, Reed was shot by Bud Ledbetter; the pain from his wound grew so severe that his partners were forced to leave him behind for the night. He gave them some of his loot, and kept the rest of it in a sack to use as a pillow.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> He lay on a blanket hiding under a rock ledge until he was found by an Indian woman, who nursed him back to health.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/><ref name="Drago"/>
The [[American Express Company]] offered a reward of $250 for the arrest and conviction of each member of the gang.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> An extensive manhunt was conducted by [[U.S. Marshal]]s [[George Crump (lawman)|George Crump]] and [[S. Morton Rutherford]], and large groups of deputies were sent into the Indian Territory and [[Creek Nation]]. While burning the [[Sugarcane|cane]]brakes in the [[Verdigris|Verdigris bottoms]], one deputy found the burnt remains of Reed's saddle and threatened to destroy the crops of local residents if they did not turn over Reed and his men.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> This was considered a legal act, authorized by "The Hanging Judge" [[Isaac Parker]] himself, but no one came forward with information.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> Reed was warned of the search and decided to leave the territory as soon as he was able. He arrived in [[Seneca, Missouri]] on December 9, where Bill Lawrence took care of him.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/>
Once fully recovered from his wounds Reed returned to Arkansas in February 1895, where he stayed with his brother in [[Madison County, Arkansas|Madison County]].<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/> Having decided to retire from a life of crime, he wrote to Judge Isaac Parker, agreeing to testify against the man who planned the robbery in exchange for [[probation]], although he did not participate in the proceedings.<ref name="Drago"/> Smith managed to disappear, but U.S. Marshal [[Newton LaForce]] was successful in tracking down Luckey and Root to the latter's home in [[Broken Arrow, Oklahoma|Broken Arrow]], 15 miles south of [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]. The two fugitives were subsequently killed in a gunfight with LaForce and his men on December 4, 1894.<ref name="Great Train Robberies"/>
===Later years=== Despite Parker's promise of immunity, Reed was convicted and sentenced to serve five years in prison.<ref name="Drago"/> However, he served less than one, as shortly before his own death Parker granted Reed his parole, in November 1896.<ref name="Drago"/> Reed subsequently carried his signed parole from Judge Parker around with him, along with a letter signed by Ledbetter acknowledging that Ledbetter had shot him.<ref name="Drago"/>
After his release Reed became an [[Evangelism|evangelist]], preaching the rewards of living a respectable, law-abiding life.<ref name="County News"/> He also toured the country with a series of [[Wild West]] shows.<ref name="Drago"/> His memoirs, ''The Life of Texas Jack'', were published in 1936, and 35,000 copies of several published pamphlets and [[dime novels]] describing his life as an outlaw were sold before his death at home in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], at the age of 87.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} He was buried in [[St. Paul, Arkansas]].<ref name="Tulsa World">{{cite web |url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/webextra/itemsofinterest/centennial/centennial_storypage.asp?ID=070601_1_A4_spanc32475 |title=Only in Oklahoma: Outlaw left life of crime for lecture circuit |accessdate= |author=Curtis, Gene |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2007-06-01 |year= |month= |format= |work= |publisher=[[Tulsa World]] |pages= |language= |doi= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== ===Books=== *Croy, Homer. ''He Hanged Them High: An Authentic Account of the Fanatical Judge who Hanged Eighty-Eight Men''. New York: Duel, Sloan & Pierce, 1952. *Drago, Harry Sinclair. ''The Organized Bands of Bank and Train Robbers Who Terrorized the Middle West for Half a Century''. New York: Bramhall House, 1964.
===Magazine articles=== *Cain, Lianne. "'Texas Jack' and the Blackstone Train Robbery". ''True West''. (January 1996): 14. *Reed, Nathaniel. "Train Holdup at Blackstone Switch". ''The West''. (May 1964): 16. *Shirley, Glenn. "The Bungled Job at Blackstone Switch". ''True West''. (June 1966): 40.
==External links== * [http://www.jcs-group.com/oldwest/outlaw/jack.html The Spell of the West: Outlaws - Texas Jack] * [http://www.legendsofamerica.com/WE-OutlawList-R.html Legends of America - Old West Outlaws]
{{Authority control}}

{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Olga FitzGeorge | birth_name = Olga Mary Adelaide FitzGeorge | image = FitzGeorge Family Four Generations Portrait 1900.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = FitzGeorge (centre) photographed with her grandfather [[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge]], her father [[Adolphus FitzGeorge|Sir Adolphus FitzGeorge]], and her son [[George FitzGeorge Hamilton]] in 1900. | spouse = [[Sir Archibald Hamilton, 5th Baronet|Archibald Hamilton]] (m. 1897; div. 1902)
Robert Charlton Lane (m. 1905) | children = '''With Hamilton:'''
[[George FitzGeorge Hamilton]]
unnamed daughter
'''With Lane:'''
Jane Lane Hohler Scrivener | family = '''By birth:'''
[[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge|FitzGeorge family]], a [[Morganatic marriage|morganatic branch]] of the [[House of Hanover]]
'''By marriage:'''
[[Hamilton baronets|Hamilton family]] | father = [[Adolphus FitzGeorge|Sir Adolphus FitzGeorge]] | mother = Sophia Jane Holden | birth_date = {{Birth date|1877|06|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Athens]], [[Kingdom of Greece]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1928|10|25|1877|06|11|df=y}} | death_place = [[Rouen]], [[French Third Republic|France]] | resting_place = Glebe Manor, [[Warblington]], [[Hampshire]] | relatives = [[George FitzGeorge]] (uncle)
[[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge]] (grandfather)
[[Sarah Fairbrother]] (grandmother)
[[Prince Adolphus, Duke of Cambridge]] (great-grandfather)
[[Princess Augusta of Hesse-Kassel]] (great-grandmother)
[[George III of the United Kingdom]] (great-great-grandfather) | residence = {{bulleted list| Rotherhill, [[Midhurst]], [[Sussex]] | Queens Mansions, [[Victoria, London|Victoria]] | [[Eaton Square]], [[Belgravia]] | Glebe Manor, Warblington, Hampshire }} }} '''Olga FitzGeorge''' ('''Olga Mary Adelaide FitzGeorge Hamilton Lane'''; 11 June 1877 – 15 October 1928) was a British socialite, businessperson, and [[Morganatic marriage|morganatic]] descendant of [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III]] through her grandfather, [[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge]]. FitzGeorge was the only daughter and child of [[Rear admiral (Royal Navy)|Rear Admiral]] [[Adolphus FitzGeorge|Sir Adolphus FitzGeorge]] and his wife Sophia Jane Holden FitzGeorge. Born in [[Athens]] while her father was serving with the [[Mediterranean Fleet]], FitzGeorge was a goddaughter of [[Olga Constantinovna of Russia|Queen Olga of Greece]] and her great aunt [[Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge|Mary Adelaide, Duchess of Teck]]. During her childhood, FitzGeorge's parents allowed her to perform in plays for charitable events despite the misgivings of her great-grandmother [[Princess Augusta of Hesse-Kassel|Augusta, Duchess of Cambridge]], and her grandfather, the Duke of Cambridge. FitzGeorge was married first to Charles Edward ''Archibald'' Watkin Hamilton (later [[Sir Archibald Hamilton, 5th Baronet]]) in 1897. FitzGeorge was known for her lavish lifestyle, and she continued her extravagant behavior throughout the course of this marriage, which increased her husband's debts and caused marital strife when Hamilton attempted to limit her expenditures. In order to achieve financial independence, FitzGeorge established a [[manicure]] and beauty salon on [[Bond Street|New Bond Street]] in London despite its annoyance to both the Hamilton family and the [[British royal family]]. FitzGeorge's first marriage, which ended in a highly-publicized divorce in 1902, produced two children: a son, [[George FitzGeorge Hamilton|''George'' Edward Archibald Augustus FitzGeorge Hamilton]], in 1898 and an unnamed daughter who died shortly after her birth. FitzGeorge's son died in 1918 while serving with the [[Grenadier Guards]] in France during [[World War I]]. FitzGeorge married lawyer Robert Charlton Lane in 1905, and the couple had a daughter, Mary Alice Olga Sofia ''Jane'' Lane Hohler Scrivener, in 1919. In 1908 FitzGeorge made headlines for her alleged affair with Arthur Clark Kennedy and was named in his divorce proceedings with his second wife. FitzGeorge died of an [[embolism]] at age 51 in [[Rouen]], France, in 1928 and was interred at her Glebe Manor estate in [[Warblington]], [[Hampshire]]. In her will, she bequeathed £1,000 to [[Winchester College]] for the establishment of the George FitzGeorge Hamilton Fund to assist in the education of the children of Wykehamists who died in World War{{nbsp}}I. FitzGeorge's daughter Jane, who later married British ambassador Ronald Stratford Scrivener, died in 2014. ==Early life and family== Olga Mary Adelaide FitzGeorge was born on 11 June 1877 as the daughter and only child of [[Rear admiral (Royal Navy)|Rear Admiral]] [[Adolphus FitzGeorge|Sir Adolphus FitzGeorge]] (1846–1922) and his first wife Sophia Jane Holden FitzGeorge (1857–1920).{{Harvnb|Weir|1989|p=296.}}{{Harvnb|McNaughton|1973|p=520.}}{{cite news | title = Marriage of the Duke of Cambridge's Granddaughter. | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | publication-place = Manchester | date = 20 December 1897 | page = 5 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22702290/marriage_of_the_duke_of_cambridges/ | accessdate = 11 August 2018 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180811163219/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22702290/marriage_of_the_duke_of_cambridges/ | archivedate = 11 August 2018 | df = dmy-all }} She was born in [[Athens]], where her father was serving with the [[Mediterranean Fleet]] of the [[Royal Navy]].{{cite news | title = Great Grandson of Royal Duke | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | publication-place = Washington, D.C. | date = 17 June 1918 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22702059/great_grandson_of_royal_duke/ | accessdate = 11 August 2018 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180811162302/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22702059/great_grandson_of_royal_duke/ | archivedate = 11 August 2018 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | title = Sons of the Old Duke: King Edward Confers Knighthood Upon Two of the Fitzgeorges. | newspaper = [[New-York Tribune]] | publication-place = New York | date = 8 April 1904 | page = 9 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22702412/sons_of_the_old_duke_king_edward/ | accessdate = 11 August 2018 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180811163745/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22702412/sons_of_the_old_duke_king_edward/ | archivedate = 11 August 2018 | df = dmy-all }} FitzGeorge was named for her two [[Godparent|godmothers]]: the queen consort in her birthplace, [[Olga Constantinovna of Russia|Queen Olga of Greece]] (1851–1926), and her great aunt [[Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge|Mary Adelaide, Duchess of Teck]] (1833–1897). Queen Olga gifted FitzGeorge with a pearl heart at her [[baptism]].{{cite news | title = Two Brothers in Royal Favor | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | publication-place = Washington, D.C. | date = 19 September 1907 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/31605582/ | accessdate = 13 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201044219/https://www.newspapers.com/image/31605582/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | title = Rear Admiral FitzGeorge at 76 Marries Second Wife | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | publication-place = Washington, D.C. | date = 20 November 1920 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/28889747/ | accessdate = 17 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201035455/https://www.newspapers.com/image/28889747/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} Through her father, FitzGeorge was a granddaughter of [[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge]] (1819–1904), [[Commander-in-Chief of the Forces]] from 1856 to 1895, and his wife [[Sarah Fairbrother]] (1816–1890).{{Harvnb|Stock|1904|p=6.}} Because her paternal grandparents' marriage was in contravention to the [[Royal Marriages Act 1772|Royal Marriages Act of 1772]], FitzGeorge's father and her uncles [[Colonel]] [[George FitzGeorge]] (1843–1907) and Colonel Sir Augustus FitzGeorge (1847–1933) were ineligible to inherit the [[Duke of Cambridge|Dukedom of Cambridge]].{{Harvnb|Stock|1904|pp=6-7.}} Also through her father, FitzGeorge was a male-line descendant of [[Prince Adolphus, Duke of Cambridge]] (1774–1850) and [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III]] (1738–1820).{{Harvnb|Stock|1904|pp=5-6.}} As a descendant of George{{nbsp}}III, FitzGeorge was also a [[cousin|first cousin twice-removed]] of [[Queen Victoria]] (1819–1901) and a first cousin once-removed of [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]] (1867–1953), who was the daughter of her godmother the Duchess of Teck. Through her mother, FitzGeorge was the granddaughter of Thomas Holden and his wife Penelope Sofiano Holden.{{Harvnb|Stock|1904|p=7.}}{{Harvnb|Huberty|1981|p=186.}} Holden was a wealthy businessman from whom FitzGeorge's parents received much of their fortune.{{cite news | title = Cobalt Mine Owner of Royal Descent | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | publication-place = Washington, D.C. | date = 5 September 1913 | page = 4 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/28854609/ | accessdate = 17 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201082232/https://www.newspapers.com/image/28854609/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} == Childhood and adolescence == As a child, FitzGeorge's parents allowed her to perform in plays and musicals for the benefit of charitable causes. In June 1882 she and her father performed in three plays at the Corn Exchange in [[Newark-on-Trent]] to raise funds for the construction of a local hospital there.{{Harvnb|Scott|1882|p=126.}} FitzGeorge's grandfather, the Duke of Cambridge, was urged by his mother [[Princess Augusta of Hesse-Kassel|Augusta, Duchess of Cambridge]], to interfere in FitzGeorge's upbringing by her parents, and discouraged them from allowing her to participate in performances and public events.{{Harvnb|St. Aubyn|1963|p=279.}} In 1884 the Duke worried about FitzGeorge's presence at a charity bazaar hosted by her mother at [[St James's Palace]], despite it being patronized by [[Edward VII|Albert Edward, Prince of Wales]], and his wife [[Alexandra of Denmark|Alexandra, Princess of Wales]]. The Duke wrote to FitzGeorge's father on 15 July 1884, insisting that she should be "quietly dressed" at the bazaar and that "appearing on the stage is not desirable for this nice little girl". In 1886 Olga served as a bridesmaid at the wedding of her maternal aunt Hélène Cecil Holden to John Louis Mitchell.{{Harvnb|Duff|1938|p=275.}} She also attended a state ball hosted by Queen Victoria at [[Buckingham Palace]] in May 1895.{{cite news | title = State Ball. | newspaper = [[The Times]] | publication-place = London | date = 30 May 1895 | page = 10 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/32647386/ | accessdate = 13 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201041903/https://www.newspapers.com/image/32647386/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} == First marriage == [[File:London, UK (August 2014) - 020.JPG|thumb|right|[[St Peter's Church, Eaton Square]]]] FitzGeorge was married first to Charles Edward ''Archibald'' Watkin Hamilton (10 December 1876{{snd}}18 March 1939), later to become [[Sir Archibald Hamilton, 5th Baronet]], on 18 December 1897.{{cite news | title = Marriage of Miss FitzGeorge. | newspaper = [[The Observer]] | publication-place = London | date = 19 December 1897 | page = 4 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/258075344/ | accessdate = 17 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201082004/https://www.newspapers.com/image/258075344/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | title = In Saint Peter's Church, Eaton-square... | newspaper = [[The Times]] | publication-place = London | date = 20 December 1897 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/33184528/ | accessdate = 18 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201081719/https://www.newspapers.com/image/33184528/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} Hamilton was the son of Sir Edward Archibald Hamilton, 4th Baronet, and his wife Mary Elizabeth Gill. Their wedding was held at [[St Peter's Church, Eaton Square|St Peter's Church]], [[Eaton Square]], [[Belgravia]], and the wedding ceremony was presided over by Reverend [[Edgar Sheppard]], Sub-Dean of the Chapels Royal, who was assisted by FitzGeorge's great uncle Reverend Anthony Bailey and parish vicar Reverend [[John Storrs (priest)|John Storrs]]. FitzGeorge was given away by her father, and was attended by her cousins George FitzGeorge and Guy Holden and by eight bridesmaids: Violet Hodgson (her cousin), Baroness Fay de{{nbsp}}Steigar (Hamilton's cousin), Stella Faudel-Phillips, Wynford "Winnie" Kemball (daughter of General [[Arnold Burrowes Kemball]]), Lady Mary Pery, Lady Evelyn Bertie, and FitzGeorge's young cousins Iris and Daphne FitzGeorge. Hamilton's best man was a Mr.{{nbsp}}Earle. FitzGeorge's veil of [[Honiton lace]] was a family heirloom previously worn by her mother, and was ornamented with [[orange blossom]]s specially sent from [[Cannes]]. She only wore one jewel, which was the pearl heart given to her at her baptism by her godmother Queen Olga of Greece. The train of her dress was carried by her pages, who wore sailor uniforms and hats labeled with "H.M.S. Olga." The wedding reception was held at the home of FitzGeorge's parents at 12{{nbsp}}Eaton Square, Belgravia, and the couple honeymooned in Paris afterward. Attendees at their wedding included FitzGeorge's grandfather the Duke of Cambridge, her uncle Colonel George FitzGeorge, the Prince and Princess of Wales, the Duchess of York, the Count and Countess of Casa Valencia, the Countess of Cottenham and her daughter Lady Mary Pepys, the [[William Pery, 3rd Earl of Limerick|Dowager Countess of Limerick]], and her daughter Lady Florence Pery, the [[Montague Bertie, 11th Earl of Lindsey|Countess of Lindsey]], the Count and Countess de{{nbsp}}Morel, [[Prince Edward of Saxe-Weimar]], the Duke and Duchess of Stackpoole, the Baron and Baroness de{{nbsp}}Steigar, [[Sir Walter Barttelot, 2nd Baronet]], and Lady Barttelot, [[General (United Kingdom)|General]] [[Sir Henry de Bathe, 4th Baronet]], and Lady de{{nbsp}}Bathe, [[Lieutenant-general (United Kingdom)|Lieutenant-General]] [[Julian Hall]], and [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] [[Reginald Macdonald|Sir Reginald Macdonald]] and Lady Macdonald.{{cite news | title = Hamilton Estate Sold. | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | publication-place = Washington, D.C. | date = 14 August 1919 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/28964967/ | accessdate = 17 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201131231/https://www.newspapers.com/image/28964967/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} FitzGeorge received a gold chain bracelet with sapphires and diamonds from the Prince and Princess of Wales; a diamond and green enamel double horseshoe brooch from her godmother Queen Olga of Greece; a diamond pendant from her grandfather the Duke of Cambridge; a white [[Brussels lace]] fan from [[George V|Prince George, Duke of York]] and Mary, Duchess of York; a bottle of perfume in a silver case from [[Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]]; a white gauze fan inlaid with gold from her great aunt [[Princess Augusta of Cambridge|Augusta, Grand Duchess of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]]; two gold [[bangle]]s with diamond pendants from [[Victor Duleep Singh|Prince Victor Duleep Singh]]; a green enamel and gold muff chain from the Prince and Princess of Löwenstein-Wertheim; and a silver [[sugar caster]] from [[Adolphus Cambridge, 1st Marquess of Cambridge|Prince Adolphus of Teck]], [[Margaret Cambridge, Marchioness of Cambridge|Princess Adolphus of Teck]], and [[Alexander Cambridge, 1st Earl of Athlone|Prince Alexander of Teck]]. Prince Adolphus and Prince Alexander were the sons of FitzGeorge's great aunt and godmother, the Duchess of Teck, who died the October preceding her wedding.{{Harvnb|Stock|1904|pp=8-9.}} After their wedding, FitzGeorge and Hamilton resided at Rotherhill in [[Midhurst]], [[Sussex]].{{cite archive |item = J 77/760/3121 - Divorce Court File: 3121. Appellant: Olga Mary Adelaide Hamilton. Respondent: Charles Edward Watkin Hamilton. Type: Wife's petition |item-url = http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C7996403 |item-id = |year = 1902 |fonds = |file = |box= |collection = Records of the Supreme Court of Judicature and related courts |collection-url = |repository = |institution = [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] |location = [[Kew]], [[London Borough of Richmond|Richmond]], [[Greater London]] |accession= }} The following year, FitzGeorge and her husband held a celebration in honor of her grandfather the Duke of Cambridge at their residence in July 1898, which included Prince and [[Princess Edward of Saxe-Weimar]], [[Maurice Gifford]], and Sir Edward Archibald Hamilton, 4th Baronet.{{cite news | title = News and Observations: Original and Selected. | newspaper = [[The Aberystwyth Observer]] | publication-place = Aberystwyth | date = 14 July 1898 | page = 2 | url = http://newspapers.library.wales/view/3047882/3047884/8/ | accessdate = 21 November 2017 | via = [[National Library of Wales]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201044619/http://newspapers.library.wales/view/3047882/3047884/8/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} FitzGeorge and Hamilton had two children together: [[George FitzGeorge Hamilton|''George'' Edward Archibald Augustus FitzGeorge Hamilton]] (30 December 1898{{snd}}18 May 1918) and an unnamed daughter who was born and died on 5 May 1902. At the baptism of their son George, the Duke of Cambridge and the Duke and Duchess of York stood as sponsors in person.{{Harvnb|Dod's Peerage, Ltd.|1917|p=368.}}{{Harvnb|Selsey57 Voluntary Community WWI Project|2017}} In 1900 a photographic portrait of FitzGeorge with her grandfather, father, and her son George on her knee, which was entitled "Four Generations" was published in multiple periodicals in the United Kingdom and the United States.{{cite news | title = Queens Daughter in a Divorce Suit | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | publication-place = Washington, D.C. | date = 13 February 1908 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/28811530/ | accessdate = 18 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171203131239/https://www.newspapers.com/image/28811530/ | archivedate = 3 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} === Divorce === Prior to their marriage, FitzGeorge was known for her lavish lifestyle. She continued her extravagant behavior throughout the course of the marriage, which increased her husband's debts and caused marital strife when Hamilton attempted to limit her expenditures. In order to attain financial independence from Hamilton, FitzGeorge established a [[manicure]] and beauty salon on [[Bond Street|New Bond Street]] in London with her married name over the establishment's front door. Her business proved to be an annoyance for both her husband's family and the British royal family. Following its opening, Hamilton left and separated from FitzGeorge. In May 1901 Hamilton returned to his parents' residence at [[Devonshire Place]] while FitzGeorge resided at their marital residence at 15{{nbsp}}Queens Mansions, Victoria Street in [[Victoria, London|Victoria]], London.{{cite news | title = A Duke's Grand-Daughter's Suit. | newspaper = [[The New Zealand Herald]] | publication-place = Auckland | date = 6 September 1902 | page = 2 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19020906.2.83.21 | accessdate = 19 November 2017 | via = [[National Library of New Zealand]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201081154/https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19020906.2.83.21 | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite archive |item = J 77/754/2963 - Divorce Court File: 2963. Appellant: Olga Mary Adelaide Hamilton. Respondent: Charles Edward Archibald Watkins Hamilton. Type: Wife's petition |item-url = http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C7996245 |item-id = |year = 1902 |fonds = |file = |box= |collection = Records of the Supreme Court of Judicature and related courts |collection-url = |repository = |institution = [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] |location = [[Kew]], [[London Borough of Richmond|Richmond]], [[Greater London]] |accession= }} Hamilton occasionally visited his wife and child, but his visits eventually ceased. In response to his desertion, FitzGeorge filed for and was granted a decree of [[restitution of conjugal rights]] by [[Francis Jeune, 1st Baron St Helier|Sir Francis Jeune]] in a divorce court on 28 July 1902. FitzGeorge was also granted custody of their son, George. Despite efforts by the royal family to reconcile FitzGeorge with her husband, she filed a petition for divorce from Hamilton. FitzGeorge was granted a divorce from Hamilton on 3 November 1902 on the grounds that her husband had abandoned FitzGeorge and engaged in extramarital misconduct with an unknown woman.{{cite news | title = Mrs. Hamilton Divorced | newspaper = [[The Baltimore Sun]] | publication-place = Baltimore | date = 4 November 1902 | page = 9 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/214593000/ | accessdate = 18 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201035410/https://www.newspapers.com/image/214593000/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} Several of their wedding guests were present in the courtroom for their divorce ruling.{{cite news | title = Royalty in the Divorce Court. | newspaper = Pittston Gazette | publication-place = [[Pittston, Pennsylvania]] | date = 4 November 1902 | page = 1 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/51596594/ | accessdate = 18 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201032701/https://www.newspapers.com/image/51596594/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} == Second marriage == Three years later, FitzGeorge married lawyer Robert Charlton Lane (26 January 1873{{snd}}23 May 1943), son of Charles Thomas Lane, on 5 January 1905 in London.{{Harvnb|McNaughton|1973|p=527.}} Following their marriage, FitzGeorge frequently traveled to New York. FitzGeorge and Lane had a residence at 1{{nbsp}}South Eaton Place in Belgravia and an estate named Glebe Manor in [[Warblington]] near [[Havant]] in [[Hampshire]].{{cite news | title = Recent Wills. | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | publication-place = Manchester | date = 15 February 1929 | page = 7 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/258569698/ | accessdate = 18 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171203131210/https://www.newspapers.com/image/258569698/ | archivedate = 3 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} In early 1908 FitzGeorge became involved in a divorce proceeding in [[Edinburgh]] between Arthur Clark Kennedy and his second wife, partly due to FitzGeorge's alleged relationship with Kennedy.{{cite news | title = Smart Divorce Case. | newspaper = [[The Weekly Mail]] | publication-place = Cardiff | date = 1 February 1908 | page = 3 | url = http://newspapers.library.wales/view/3378682/3378685/68/ | accessdate = 20 November 2017 | via = [[National Library of Wales]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201044549/http://newspapers.library.wales/view/3378682/3378685/68/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} Kennedy's wife claimed that FitzGeorge and Kennedy had traveled together to cities in Great Britain, Ireland, and France in 1906, and resided together in [[Bury St Edmunds]] in March and April of that year. FitzGeorge's own mother wrote a letter of sympathy to Kennedy's wife in which she stated, "I find we have no power to stop Olga's money. We cannot stop anybody doing anything, but can only pray for the best. Take care of yourself." Kennedy was not present for the divorce proceeding, and his wife was ultimately granted a divorce. Throughout the trial, FitzGeorge vacationed in [[Jamaica]]. In 1916, during [[World War I]], FitzGeorge's son George entered the [[Royal Military Academy Sandhurst]], and in late 1917 he obtained a commission as a [[Second lieutenant]] in the [[British Army]]'s [[Grenadier Guards]], in which his great-grandfather the Duke of Cambridge had served.{{Harvnb|Winchester College|2017}} Only a few months later, on 18 May 1918, George was killed by a bomb from an airplane at Warlincourt near [[Arras]], France.{{Harvnb|Winchester College|2017}} He was [[burial|interred]] at Warlincourt Halte British Cemetery near [[Saulty]]. Following the war, FitzGeorge and Lane became the parents of a daughter, Mary Alice Olga Sofia ''Jane'' Lane (4 June 1919{{snd}}20 September 2014).{{Harvnb|McNaughton|1973|p=523.}} FitzGeorge's mother Sophia died on 3 February 1920. She bequeathed certain items of jewellery (a gold bracelet that had belonged to Augusta, Duchess of Cambridge, and other diamond ornaments) in [[life interest]] to FitzGeorge with the remainder to Jane.{{cite news | title = Mementoes of the Late Duke of Cambridge. | newspaper = [[The Times]] | publication-place = London | date = 21 September 1920 | page = 13 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/32604425/ | accessdate = 19 November 2017 | via = [[Newspapers.com]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171203131200/https://www.newspapers.com/image/32604425/ | archivedate = 3 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} FitzGeorge's father (at the age of 76) married ''Margaret'' Beatrice Daisy Watson in October 1920 in [[Pimlico]];{{Harvnb|Weir|1989|p=297.}} he died on 17 December 1922 in London.{{Harvnb|Weir|1989|p=298.}} ==Later life, death, and legacy== FitzGeorge died on 15 October 1928 at age 51 in [[Rouen]], [[French Third Republic]].{{cite news | title = Re Olga Mary Adelaide Lane, Deceased. | newspaper = [[The London Gazette]] | publication-place = London | issue = 33468 | date = 19 February 1929 | page = 1230 | url = https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/33468/page/1230 | accessdate = 17 November 2017 | via = [[The London Gazette]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171203131159/https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/33468/page/1230 | archivedate = 3 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite archive |item = Olga Mary Adelaide FitzGeorge Lane Death Certificate |item-url = |item-id = |year = 1928 |fonds = |series = RG 32 |file = Piece 14 |box= |collection = General Register Office: Miscellaneous Foreign Returns |collection-url = |repository = |institution = [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|The National Archives]] |location = [[Kew]], [[London Borough of Richmond|Richmond]], [[Greater London]] |accession= }} After a tour of [[Bayeux]] and a two-day stay at the Vieux Logis on Rue Saint Romain in Rouen, FitzGeorge died suddenly of an [[embolism]] as she was boarding her car to depart for [[Le Havre]].{{cite news | title = Deuil | newspaper = [[Journal des débats]] | publication-place = Paris | language = French | date = 20 October 1928 | page = 2 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k505664t/ | accessdate = 21 November 2017 | via = [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201064649/http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k505664t/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | title = Une cousine du roi d'Angleterre meurt subitement | newspaper = L'Homme libre | publication-place = Paris | language = French | date = 19 October 1928 | page = 3 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k75917084/ | accessdate = 21 November 2017 | via = [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201125941/http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k75917084/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }}{{cite news | title = Nécrologie | newspaper = [[Le Gaulois]] | publication-place = Paris | language = French | date = 20 October 1928 | page = 2 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k541409w/ | accessdate = 21 November 2017 | via = [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201093809/http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k541409w/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} Her remains were transferred from Le{{nbsp}}Havre to [[Southampton]] on 17 October, and she was [[burial|interred]] at her Glebe Manor estate in Warblington, Hampshire.{{cite news | title = Mort subite. | newspaper = [[Le Temps (Paris)|Le Temps]] | publication-place = Paris | language = French | date = 20 October 1928 | page = 4 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k247222b/ | accessdate = 21 November 2017 | via = [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171201085541/http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k247222b/ | archivedate = 1 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} FitzGeorge's will was proved in the Principal Probate Registry on 9 February 1929 by her named executors: her husband and Edgar Oliver Goss. In her will, FitzGeorge left a gold cup presented to her son George by the Duke of Cambridge to the [[Mess#United Kingdom|officers' mess]] of the 1st Battalion, Grenadier Guards, £100 to the Princess Louise Home for Girls in [[Kingston Vale|Kingston Hill]], annuities of £15 each to her nurses Emily Hawkins and Nanny Gertrude Mills, and £40 to Robert Walker. FitzGeorge also left £1,000 to [[Winchester College]] for the establishment of the George FitzGeorge Hamilton Fund to assist in the education of the children of Wykehamists who had died in World War{{nbsp}}I. She left unsettled property totaling £20,150. FitzGeorge's daughter Jane married first to Edward Christopher Hohler (22 January 1917{{snd}}15 February 1997), son of [[Lieutenant colonel (United Kingdom)|Lieutenant Colonel]] Arthur Preston Hohler and Laline Annette Astell,{{Harvnb|Townend|1965|p=393.}} on 14 November 1939 at Warblington, Hampshire.{{Harvnb|McNaughton|1973|p=524.}} She and Hohler divorced in July 1961 in London. Jane then married Ronald Stratford Scrivener, son of Sir Patrick Scrivener, on 14 May 1962 in London.{{Harvnb|McNaughton|1973|p=533.}} Scrivener served as the [[List of ambassadors of the United Kingdom to Panama|Ambassador of the United Kingdom to Panama]].{{cite news | title = Foreign and Commonwealth Office | newspaper = [[The London Gazette]] | publication-place = London | issue = 44893 | date = 10 July 1969 | page = 7143 | url = https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/44893/page/7143 | accessdate = 19 November 2017 | via = [[The London Gazette]] | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171203131213/https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/44893/page/7143 | archivedate = 3 December 2017 | df = dmy-all }} Jane died on 20 September 2014 at age 95, and her funeral service was held at St.{{nbsp}}Etheldreda's in [[Fulham]].{{cite news| title = Death Announcement: Scrivener, Jane | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | publication-place = London | date = October 2014 | url = http://announcements.telegraph.co.uk/deaths/181969/scrivener-jane | accessdate = 19 November 2017 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20171119151758/http://announcements.telegraph.co.uk/deaths/181969/scrivener-jane | archive-date = 19 November 2017 | via = [[The Daily Telegraph]]}} She had four children with her first husband, Edward Christopher Hohler: Olga Mary Hohler Bland (born 11 October 1940), Philippa Caroline Jane Hohler Sanders Snowdon (born 13 January 1942), Frederick Christopher Gerald Hohler (born 30 August 1943), and Robert Henry Adolphus Hohler (born 2 October 1947). At the time of her death, Jane had 13 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |title=Ancestors of Olga FitzGeorge{{Harvnb|Stock|1904|pp=5-9.}}{{Harvnb|Weir|1989|pp=285-297.}} |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. '''Olga FitzGeorge''' |2= 2. [[Adolphus FitzGeorge|Sir Adolphus FitzGeorge]] |3= 3. Sophia Jane Holden |4= 4. [[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge]] |5= 5. [[Sarah Fairbrother]] |6= 6. Thomas Holden |7= 7. Penelope Sofiano |8= 8. [[Prince Adolphus, Duke of Cambridge]] |9= 9. [[Princess Augusta of Hesse-Kassel]] |10= 10. John Fairbrother{{Harvnb|Camp|2007|pp=330-8.}} |11= 11. Mary Tucker |16= 16. [[George III of the United Kingdom]] |17= 17. [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]] |18= 18. [[Prince Frederick of Hesse-Kassel]] |19= 19. {{Infobox artist/sandbox | birth_date = ''c.'' 1613 | death_date = June 1678 | monogram = OTMS or OMS (only on drawings) }} [[Image:Otto Marseus van Schrieck 001.jpg|thumb|300px|''[[Morning glory]], [[toad]], and [[insect]]s'', 1660]]
'''Otto Marseus van Schrieck''' (ca. 1613, in [[Nijmegen]] – buried 22 June 1678, in [[Amsterdam]]) was a painter in the [[Dutch Golden Age]]. He is best known for his paintings of forest [[flora (plants)|flora]] and [[fauna (animals)|fauna]].
==Biography== Marseus van Schrieck spent the years 1652-1657 in [[Rome]] and [[Florence]] with the painters [[Matthias Withoos]] and [[Willem van Aelst]], and there joined the Dutch Guild of Artists. Later he worked at the court of the Grand Duke of Tuscany and traveled throughout England and France, after which he settled in Amsterdam.<ref name="Caldwell"/> On 25 April 1664, he married Margarita Gysels (the daughter of Cornelius Gysels, an engraver).<ref name="Caldwell">{{Citation|last = Caldwell|first = Joan|contribution = Otto Marseus van Schrieck|year = 1995|title = Handbook of the Collection of New Orleans Museum of Art|editor-last = Bullard|editor-first = E. John|pages = 41|place = New Orleans|publisher = New Orleans Museum of Art}}</ref> [[Arnold Houbraken]]'s biography of Otto mentions that he joined the [[Bentvueghels]] in Rome and was called the ''snuffelaer'', or "sniffer", because he was always sniffing strange lizards and snakes.{{Clarify|date=August 2018}} Houbraken quotes Otto's wife, who survived him by two husbands and was still alive when he wrote the book; according to her, Otto kept snakes and lizards in a shed at the back of his house, and also on a piece of land outside the city that was walled in for this purpose.
==Works== Many of his paintings are dark studies of plants, often with lizards at the base and insects on the leaves and branches. According to the RKD, his followers were [[Willem van Aelst]], [[Anthonie van Borssom]], [[Elias van den Broeck]], J Falk, Carl Wilhelm de Hamilton, Trajan Hughes, [[Nicolaes Lachtropius]], [[Jacob Marrel]], [[Abraham Mignon]], [[Rachel Ruysch]], [[Christiaen Striep]], [[Isac Vromans]], [[Matthias Withoos]], and [[Pieter Withoos]].<ref>[https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/52810 Otto Marseus van Schrieck] in the [[RKD]]</ref> A notable omission in this list is the daughter and sister of the last two mentioned, [[Alida Withoos]], who collaborated with him on creating paintings of the garden of Vijverhof for [[Agnes Block]]'s collection of garden albums.
==References== {{reflist}} * {{Link language|nl}}<!--Middle Dutch--> [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/houb005groo01_01/houb005groo01_01_0170.htm Otto Marcelis biography] in ''De groote schouburgh der Nederlantsche konstschilders en schilderessen'' (1718) by [[Arnold Houbraken]], courtesy of the [[Digital library for Dutch literature]]
==External links== {{Commons category|Otto Marseus van Schrieck}} * [http://www.artcyclopedia.com/artists/marseus_van_schrieck_otto.html Artcyclopedia entry with many links] * [http://www.pubhist.com/person/545/otto-marseus-van-schrieck Works and literature] on PubHist
